did.unittitle:
Charles Campbell Papers,
1743-1896.
did.abstract: Papers received or collected by Charles Campbell (1807-1876), Virginia Historian, as well as letters and other papers, 1743-1896. Includes the business correspondence of Charles Campbell with various editors of The Southern Literary Messenger, several historical societies, publishing firms, historians and authors, with Petersburg, Virginia. Items also relate to organizations and institutions with which he was affiliated, to the school that he conducted in Petersburg and to his personal correspondence with friends and members of his family. Diaries and notebooks both kept by Charles Campbell and his wife Anna Burdsall Campbell, plus 18 scrapbooks, autographs, historical notes, etc. are also found in the collection.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: Charles Campbell (1807-1876) was born on 1 May 1807, in Petersburg, Virginia, the firstborn child of parents John Wilson Campbell (d.1842), and Mildred Walker Moore Campbell. John, a bookstore owner, was also a historian. In 1831 he published the History of Virginia to 1781. Later, he held the position of Federal Collector of Customs in Petersburg, Virginia. Mildred taught at the Petersburg Classical Academy in the 1840's. In addition to Charles, the couple also had two younger children, Alexander (Aleck) S. Campbell, and Elizabeth (Betty) Campbell Maben (d.1871).

Charles' mother, Mildred Walker Moore Campbell, was the granddaughter of Virginia lieutenant governor Alexander Spotswood (1676-1740). Mildred Walker Moore Campbell and her siblings Mary Fairfax Moore Keller, Dr. Alexander Spotswood Moore, Ann Evelina Moore Henley, William Agustin Moore, Eliza Moore McDonald, and Lavinia Moore McPheeters wrote and received numerous pieces of personal correspondence that are available in this collection.

Charles Campbell attended the College of New Jersey (later Princeton University) from 1823-1825. Upon graduation he enrolled in Henry St. George Tucker's School of Law in Winchester, Virginia. However, he suffered from chronic headaches which caused him severe physical and mental exhaustion. By 1829, these health issues would force him to leave the law profession.

Following his departure from law, Campbell worked as an engineer of the Petersburg Railroad. Later he ran a private school for boys in Glencoe, Alabama. On 13 September 1836, he married Elvira N. Callaway (1819-1837) of Monroe County, Tennessee. In 1837, Elvira died shortly after the birth of a son, Callaway Campbell (b.1837). In his distress, Campbell left his son with Elivira's siblings, Thomas and Lucinda Callaway. Later, this would result in a court case to regain custody of his child.

Following the death of his wife, Campbell worked as a clerk in the office of the Collector of Custom in Petersburg, Virginia (a position he obtained from his father John Campbell). From 1840-1843, Campbell also owned, published, and edited a Petersburg newspaper, The American Statesman. He returned to teaching in 1842 by opening a classical school in Petersburg, becoming both teacher and administrator in the Anderson Seminary. He would hold these positions until the formation of free public schools in 1870.

Campbell remarried in 1850 to Miss Anna Birdsall of Rahway, New Jersey. They had four children, Mary Spotswood Campbell Robinson (b.1852), Nanny Campbell (b.1854), Charles Campbell (b.1856), and Fanny Campbell (1858-1860's).
Charles Campbell was committed to Western Lunatic Asylum at Staunton, Virginia, in 1873 where he remained until his death on July 11, 1876. He was buried at Blandford Church Cemetery, Petersburg.

Like his father, Campbell was a historian. He began contributing to journals in 1834. Some of the journals to which he frequently contributed included; The Southern Literary Messengeror The Southern and Western Literary Messenger and Review; The Farmer's Register; The New Yorker; and the Petersburg Intelligencer. His most important work, however, was the History of the Colony and Ancient Dominion of Virginia. This work built upon his father's book and concerned Virginia history from the colony's founding to the Revolutionary War.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: The Charles Campbell papers consist of papers received or collected by Charles Campbell (1807-1876) Virginia historian. The papers fall into four general headings: historical papers collected by Charles Campbell, correspondence, manuscript volumes, and miscellaneous. These include personal and professional correspondence as well as eighteenth century documents collected by Charles Campbell, newspaper clippings, diaries, scrapbooks, and notebooks, covering then period 1743-1896. The papers reflect Charles Campbell's interests in history, teaching, newspaper editing, railroad engineering, politics, genealogy, publication of his works, and the town of Petersburg where he lived for most of his life.

The personal papers include Charles Campbell's correspondence with his father John Wilson Campbell, brother Alexander Campbell, sister, wife and children as well as cousins in Tennessee, Alabama, and Virginia. These include copies of Charles Campbell's letters, as well as letters received by him; biographical material; genealogical material; autograph collecting material; and letters received by Charles Campbell's second wife Anna Burdsall Campbell. These also include correspondence relating to organizations with which he was affiliated, such as the Petersburg Library and the Petersburg Lyceum.

His professional correspondence consists of letters to the editors of the Southern Literary Messenger, to historical societies, to publishing firms, and to other historians and authors. The writing, publishing and critic of Charles Campbell's book Virginia History, concerns much of these material. Charles Campbell also corresponded with genealogists and antiquarians interested in Virginia history.

The eighteenth century documents collected by Charles Campbell include letters by John Quarles, John Byrd, George Dabney, William Degge, Edward Hill, John Jameson, Alexander Moore, William Aylett, and Theodorick Bland, as well as parts of William Aylett's account books (1770-1776).

The manuscript volumes include Charles Campbell's diaries (1861-1864), Anna Burdsall Campbell diaries (1840-1870), scrapbooks, Charles Campbell's historical notes, newspaper clippings, Anderson Seminary account books, Charles Campbell's pupil exercise books, pamphlets, copies of Charles Campbell's articles, and household account books (1848-1863).
There are many letters from Mary B. Carter of "Shirley," Charles City County, Virginia to Mildred Walker (Moore) Campbell, Charles Campbell's mother.

arrangement.head: Organization
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into five series. Series 1 contains historical manuscripts; Series 2 contains family and professional papers; Series 3 contains manuscript volumes; Series 4 contains miscellaneous material; and Series 5 contains the addition 1992.33b.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged into series and then chronologically by date. Series 3, containing family and professional papers, is arranged into subseries by decade and then into additional subseries by individual year.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials at Duke University Library
relatedmaterial.p: The materials at Duke are comprised of copies of historical documents and letters, and personal papers of Charles Campbell (1807-1876), historian, editor, and antiquarian. Included are original letters from St. George Tucker, Lewis Cass, Pierre Soule, Edward Everett, Beverley Randolph, Andrew Jackson, Robert Beverley, and others, as well as copies of letters from Richard Henry Lee, Arthur Lee, Theodorick Bland, Jr., Captain John Smith, John Randolph of Roanoke, John Adams, Powhatan Ellis, Patrick Henry, John Jay, and others. The papers also contain rough drafts and preliminary notes for Campbell's publications, a number of manuscript poems, and a transcription of the minute book of the city council of Richmond, Virginia, 1782-1795. The volumes contain personal accounts, records of Anderson Academy, Petersburg, Virginia, of which Campbell was principal, and historical notes.

scopecontent.p: Speaks of Charles Campbell's father's upcoming visit to New York and New England, possibility of Charles Campbell's going along.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Princeton, to [John W. Campbell, Petersburg], 28 September 1823.

scopecontent.p: Received $10 from William Bradford. Grades received: he has done well. News of commencement.

did.unittitle: [Mrs.] M[ildred] W. Campbell,Petersburg to Charles [Campbell] at [Princeton], 5 December 1823.

scopecontent.p: Inquires after Charles Campbell's health, etc. Recommends he read "Watts' on the mind".

did.unittitle: J[ohn] W. Campbell,Petersburg, to Charles Campbell, Princeton, 11 March 1824.

scopecontent.p: Mother returned after 3 weeks at Shirley. Asks him to come home at end of session.

did.unittitle: A[nthony] Lamb,Princeton, to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 6 May 1824.

scopecontent.p: Arrived at Princeton last Tuesday; is happy to be back. Encloses list of students and the grades they attained.

did.unittitle: J[ohn] W. Campbell,Petersburg, to Charles [Campbell], [Princeton], 26 July 1824.

scopecontent.p: Alexander suffering from toothache. Mother leaving for New York in August. Social news.

did.unittitle: J[ohn] W. Campbell,Petersburg, to Charles [Campbell], 13 October 1824.

scopecontent.p: Encloses $200. Social news.

did.unittitle: J[ohn] W. Campbell,Petersburg, to Charles Campbell, Princeton, 23 August 1824.

scopecontent.p: Town healthy, contrary to other places. Asks if he has seen General La Fayette. Social news.

did.unittitle: [?], (signature clipped), Princeton, to Charles [Campbell], 8 May 1824.

scopecontent.p: Uncertain as to whether he will enroll or not. Princeton very dull during vacation, only a few students remaining.

did.unittitle: Ch[arles] Campbell, Princeton, to [John W. Campbell] [Petersburg], 24 [January] 1825.

scopecontent.p: Received $50. Is considering various topics for speech he must give at end of school session.

did.unittitle: Letter, n.d.

scopecontent.p: Asks if he is studying law. Recalls days spent together in college. Unsigned.

did.unittitle: Ch[arles] Campbell, Petersburg to [a college friend], 10 October 1825.

scopecontent.p: Arrived last Sunday. Speaks of their commencement.

did.unittitle: M[ildred] W. Campbell,Petersburg, to Charles [Campbell], [Princeton], 25 January 1825.

scopecontent.p: Deepest snow she has ever seen (2 ft) has just fallen. Social news. Asks him to write to Sister Betty.

did.unittitle: J[ohn] W. Campbell,Petersburg, to Charles [Campbell], [Princeton], 18 April 1825.

scopecontent.p: Inquires if he received letter and $20.00 note. Encloses $50.00. He has had a severe attack of rheumatism.

did.unittitle: J[ohn] W. Campbell,Petersburg, to Charles [Campbell] [Princeton], 12 May 1825.

scopecontent.p: Encloses check for $100. Has been ill.

did.unittitle: J[ohn] W. Campbell,Petersburg, to Charles [Campbell] [Princeton], 17 May 1825.

scopecontent.p: Encloses $40. Social news.

did.unittitle: J[ohn] W. Campbell,Petersburg, to Charles [Campbell], 9 August 1825.

scopecontent.p: Encloses $50. Family is healthy although town is sickly. Mother has given up idea of visiting Philadelphia.

did.unittitle: Jo[h]n H. Lee,Charlottesville, to Charles [Campbell], Princeton, New Jersey, 15 August 1825.

scopecontent.p: Is attending lectures, in foreign languages, history, and physiology; remembers his days at Princeton with Charles Campbell; LaFayette expected to visit Monticello.

did.unittitle: J[ohn] W. Campbell,Petersburg to Charles Campbell, Princeton, New Jersey, 21 September 1825.

scopecontent.p: Encloses money, and warns him to be economical. Mother and children still in Scottsville. Business is slow season.

did.unittitle: Char[le]s Campbell, Winchester to E[lizabeth] M. Campbell,Petersburg, [31 May?] [c. 1826].

scopecontent.p: Closing and signature of letter.

did.unittitle: Jo[hn] H. Lee,Orange County to Charles Campbell, Winchester, Virginia, 26 December 1826.

scopecontent.p: Expresses friendship for Charles Campbell; wishes him luck with law studies.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell to Mildred W. Campbell, Petersburg, [Postmarked 10 January 1827].

scopecontent.p: News of studies of law. Would like to go to Washington during vacation but will be unable. Inquiries after Elizabeth Ruffin.

did.unittitle: [J. B. Pressley], Simpsonsville, South Carolina, to [Charles] Campbell, Winchester, 10 January 1827.

scopecontent.p: Expects to get married April 1828 and to be licensed to practice law, urges Charles Campbell to visit him, tell him about the lectures at Winchester. Discussion of Virginia and South Carolina politics: mention of John Randolph.

did.unittitle: Mrs. M[ildred] W. Campbell,Petersburg, to Charles [Campbell] Winchester, Virginia, 15 January 1827.

scopecontent.p: Speaks of Charles Campbell's love for an unnamed person, and expresses hope he will remain single until he is 21. Speaks of John Tyler's defeat of John Randolph of Roanoke in Senate Election. News of suicide of "old Rambaut".

did.unittitle: Cha[rle]s Campbell, Winchester, to Elizabeth M. Campbell, Petersburg, 29 January 1827.

scopecontent.p: Judge [Henry St. George] Tuckerreturned, vacation ended. Social news: party attended. Expresses indifference to career in law, and interest in politics, mentions John Randolph.

did.unittitle: J[ohn] W[ilson] Campbell,Petersburg, [Virginia] to Charles [Campbell], 20 February 1827.
Charles Campbell, Winchester, Virginia to father [John Wilson Campbell], 27 February 1827.

scopecontent.p: Estimates his expenses at $186; will not stay with Judge Tucker for the summer; students are so crowded at Tucker's that "we read but little".

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Winchester [Virginia] to father [John Wilson Campbell], 18 March 1827.

scopecontent.p: Received John Wilson Campbell's check for $75; Judge Tucker declined an invitation to run for Congress; has received report of John Wilson Campbell's Jackson Committee but is still anti-Jackson and gives his reasons for his position, "I trust that all the endeavors of the Jacksonites will fail."

did.unittitle: J. B. Pressley, Simpsonsville, South Carolina, to Charles Campbell, Winchester, 2 April 1827.

scopecontent.p: Wishes he was with him studying law at Winchester, advantages of studying under private lawyer, philosophical discussion, discussion of Virginia and South Carolina politics.

did.unittitle: S. L. Campbell, Rockbridge, to John W[ilson] Campbell,Petersburg, Virginia, 18 April 1827.

scopecontent.p: Sold their father's plantation for $7.50 an acre; mother is ill; father being swayed by a bad advisor.

did.unittitle: M[ildred] W. Campbell,Winchester to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 2 May 1827.

scopecontent.p: News of meeting of Hanover presbytery. Expresses hope Charles Campbell has become religious. Opinion of father that he return home immediately. Postscript: Elizabeth Ruffin to Charles Campbell. Thanking him for writing. Expressions of her affection for him.

did.unittitle: [?], Lexington to [?] [Charles Campbell], 18 May 1827.

scopecontent.p: Glad he is doing well in Law School; Family news.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, near White Sulphur Springs to [father?], 2 September [c. 1827].

scopecontent.p: His health "continued very wretched"; is taking the waters at the Springs; wants to have all his law books sold except the one presented to him by Judge Tucker.

did.unittitle: Cha[rles] Campbell, Petersburg, to [?], November 1827.

scopecontent.p: Thanks her for her fine treatment of him in Princeton. Describes his trip home. Social news.

did.unittitle: J[ohn] N. Campbell,Petersburg, to Charles [Campbell], 12 July 1828.

scopecontent.p: May to Philadelphia this summer. Business very good. Has forwarded money to him through William Bradford.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to Mrs. Mildred W. Campbell, New Haven, Connecticut, 21 September 1828.

scopecontent.p: Various social news. News of a new steam ferry. Asks her to buy book Geographyby Malte Brun.

did.unittitle: M[ildred] W. Campbell,Petersburg, to Alexander A. Campbell, New Haven, 2 June 1829.

scopecontent.p: Father just returned from New Haven. Glad to hear he is doing well, especially in French.

did.unittitle: S. R. C. [?], Rock Castle, Lexington, Virginia to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 5 July 1829.

scopecontent.p: Angry because he hasn't written family members moving west.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell] to [?], [c. 1830's].

scopecontent.p: Trying to find a career, is considering engineering.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Lexington, Virginia to Mrs. Mildred W. Campbell, Petersburg, 25 August 1830.

scopecontent.p: News of his uncertain health and his trip to Lexington.

did.unittitle: T[homas] Vincent,Lawrenceville, Virginia, to W. Campbell, Petersburg, [Virginia], 5 September 1830.

scopecontent.p: Asks for books; dispute over payment of money.

did.unittitle: H[enry] S[t]. G[eorge] Tucker,[Winchesters, Virginia] to [John W.] Campbell,Petersburg, [Virginia], 1831.

scopecontent.p: Sends copies of his works; sorry Charles Campbell is not well.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth M. Campbell, Raleigh, to John W. Campbell, Petersburg, 15 November 1832.

scopecontent.p: Recently arrived in Raleigh, received his letter. Will return home middle of next week.

did.unittitle: List of proceeds from sale of estate of A. S. Moore, 4 February 1833.

scopecontent.p: List of sale prices for slaves, household goods.

did.unittitle: Hugh Nelson, Belvoir to John W. Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 18 February 1833.

scopecontent.p: Can't find anything about Mr. Moore's affairs.

did.unittitle: E[lizabeth] R[uffin],Philadelphia, to [Charles Campbell], 31 July [1833?].

scopecontent.p: Her visit to Philadelphia, having traveled 350 miles in two days. Leaving for New York Monday.

did.unittitle: H[enry] S[t]. G[eorge] Tucker,Woodbury, to [Charles Campbell], 29 September 1833.

scopecontent.p: Sorry Charles Campbell is giving up his profession.

did.unittitle: Otway B. Barraud, Norfolk, to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 4 November 1833.

scopecontent.p: Explains self very obscurely for a letter he wrote about Charles Campbell which seems to have offended the latter. Charles Campbell must have written about his disappointment in the Law, his failure to achieve greatness at the age of 29, his failure in the profession generally, Otway B. Barraud denies this and encourages him. Reacts to Charles Campbell's 3 ways of becoming great: 1) born 2) achieve 3) thrust upon. Spoke to Gwynn on Charles Campbell's behalf, who has offered Charles Campbell a place, hard work, rough fare, but should take it. [Civil Engineer.]

did.unittitle: H[enry] Barnard,New Haven, Connecticut to Mildred W. Campbell, Petersburg, 23 December 1833.

scopecontent.p: Is glad to have heard news of Petersburg via Messrs. May and Ruffin. Hopes to go to Virginia again soon and asks when she will again come to Connecticut. Sends her an "Essay on Slavery."

did.unittitle: L[avinia] [McPheeters],Petersburg, [Virginia] to [Charles Campbell], 26 December 1833.

scopecontent.p:
Misses him; social life.
Letter also includes a letter from Ed[mund] Ruffinto Charles Campbell. Hopes his job is going well.
Letter also includes a letter from Bet [Elizabeth Campbell] to Charles Campbell asks him to write.

did.unittitle:
Letters,
1834.
Elizabeth [Campbell],Petersburg, to Charles Campbell, Suffolk, [?] January 1834.

scopecontent.p: Cold weather; mother knitting for him. Tells him of her reading (Cowper). She sends him local newspapers regularly. Mentions of legislative. Debate on Portsmouth Bill.

did.unittitle: [Charles] Campbell, Ballard's Farm, to E[lizabeth] Campbell,Petersburg, 4 January 1834.

scopecontent.p: His stay in Suffolk, near the Blackwater River. Suffers from bad dreams. Country flat, population sparse.

did.unittitle: Lavinia [McPheeters],Petersburg, [Virginia] to Charles Campbell, Jerusalem, Southampton County, Virginia, 27 January 1834.

scopecontent.p: Glad he is enjoying engineering; Charles Campbell shouldn't expect to find a wife as smart as himself; hopes "the sable coloured gentry in Jerusalem will not rise again" but the whites there "are not much better than the blacks". Also: Note from E[lizabeth] M. C[ampbell]to Charles Campbell. Mr. Barraud in town; Charles Campbell working on railroad and "will indeed be welcomed as a traitor to your town, working on a road to destroy it".

did.unittitle: J[ohn] W[ilson] Campbell,Petersburg, [Virginia] to Charles [Campbell], 26 February 1834.
Otway B. Barraud to Charles Campbell, Norfolk, 8 March 1834.

scopecontent.p: Letter expresses concern that Campbell had not written to Barraud in considerable time. Gives advice to Campbell on how best to develop himself as Civil Engineer.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth [Campbell],Petersburg to Charles Campbell, Jerusalem, Virginia, 12 March 1834.

scopecontent.p: News of her stay in Richmond, her visit to the Capitol. Asks to go to Princeton with him. Will make and send him some shirts. Postscript: Mr. Ed[mund] Ruffinto Charles [Campbell]. His letter received; all well.

did.unittitle: Ed[mund] Ruffin,Petersburg to Charles [Campbell], 13 March 1834.

scopecontent.p: Suggests topics for him to write about, including a description of the Dismal Swampage.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Isle of Wight County, to E[lizabeth] M. Campbell,Petersburg, 30 March 1834.

scopecontent.p: Advises her to address letters to him to Suffolk, Virginia. Inquiries about brother Aleck. Remarks about Cowper.

did.unittitle: Alexander Campbell, Petersburg to Charles Campbell, Suffolk, 4 April 1834.

scopecontent.p: House full of people, preaching all week. Enjoys working in father's store. Asks news of his railroad work. Postscript: [Elizabeth M. Campbell], Petersburg to Charles [Campbell], Suffolk. Family news. They stayed at Shirley for a week.

did.unittitle: Cha[rle]s Campbell, Isle of Wight County, [Virginia], to Lavinia McPheeters, 7 April 1834.

scopecontent.p: Isle of Wight a dreary county; thinking about leaving the railroad.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Suffolk, to E[lizabeth] M. Campbell,Petersburg, 20 April 1834.

scopecontent.p:
Is in Suffolk. Has been with 2nd Division of the Road but is being transferred to the 1st Boarding near Dismal Swamp, across which railroad runs. He is writing from
P[ortsmouth] and R[oanoke] RR office. Will return shortly.

did.unittitle: [Elizabeth Campbell], Petersburg, to Charles Campbell, Suffolk, 24 April [1834].

scopecontent.p: Home has been filled with company. Speaks of their claims on the government and the possibility of their being rich shortly. Social news.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Winchester, to [Elizabeth Campbell], [May?] 1834.

scopecontent.p: Arrived in Winchester, seeking out Mr. Robinson, thinking of going west; still undecided. Does not regret leaving Portsmouth and Roanoke Railroad.

did.unittitle: [Charles] [Campbell], Mount Ephraim, to E[lizabeth] M. Campbell,Petersburg, 1 June 1834.

scopecontent.p: His trip to Winchester. He has applied for a place under Mr. Robinson with another railroad. Prefers returning to West.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell] Petersburg, Virginia to R. Smith, 28 June 1834.

scopecontent.p: Applied to Mr. Robinson at Winchester, but was not admitted; wants to go west; wants a wife.

did.unittitle: J[ames] G. McPheeters,Raleigh, North Carolina to Cha[rle]s Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 12 July 1834.

scopecontent.p: Has found a woman Charles Campbell would like; health not good; Mr. Ruffin's register popular in Raleigh; invites him to visit.

did.unittitle: Thomas W. White, Richmond to Charles Campbell, 17 July 1834.

scopecontent.p: Has had certain difficulties in getting out the first number of the Southern Literary Messenger.Will be happy to receive contributions for it from Campbell, and will pay him for any articles which are printed.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Hornet at Sea, to [Elizabeth] M. Campbell,Princeton, New Jersey, 7 August 1834.

scopecontent.p: Off Jersey Coast, will reach New York tomorrow. Describes route of future travels: New York to Albany, to Buffalo; across Lake Erie to Detroit, by stage to Chicago. Health poor: traveling the best medicine. Letter resumes from New York City: Hopes to find quiet and peace in West.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, Buffalo, New York to Elizabeth M. Campbell, Princeton, New Jersey; 15 August 1834.

scopecontent.p: After leaving New York City went to Albany and by canal to Buffalo. Leaving by steamer for Detroit tomorrow. Speaks of all past unhappiness, and thanks her for her affection.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, Detroit, Michigan to E[lizabeth] M. Campbell,Princeton, New Jersey, 17 August 1834.

scopecontent.p: Trip across Lake Erie less unpleasant than canal trip. Taking stage tomorrow for Chicago. Hopes to find some people interested in settling in Illinois.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, La Porte, Indiana to Mrs. Mildred W. Campbell, Petersburg, 22 August 1834.

scopecontent.p: News of his trip from Detroit to Chicago; description of countryside. Description of Indiana prairies. Speaks of his plans to settle in Illinois or Missouri, and his preference for settling in a fine state.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, La Porte, Indiana to E[lizabeth] M. Campbell,Princeton, New Jersey, 23 August 1834.

scopecontent.p: Countryside described. Land cheap in Illinois, he may buy a farm there. Dined with Potowotomy Indians. Leaves in 2 days for Chicago. Less depressed than formerly.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, near Springfield, Illinois to E[lizabeth] M. Campbell,Princeton, New Jersey, 1 September 1834.

scopecontent.p: Moving next to Vandalia, Illinois, and thence East Tennessee via Louisville, Kentucky. Considers it unlikely he will remain in Illinois.

did.unittitle: Ch[arle]s Campbell, Chota, Tennessee to Alexander S. Campbell, Petersburg, September 1834.

scopecontent.p: He is contented with being a schoolmaster. Tells him of eating pumpkin bread at Chota. Description of country and wild life.

did.unittitle: [Mrs. Mildred W. Campbell], Petersburg to Mr. Charles Campbell, Chota, East Tennessee, 17 September 1834.

scopecontent.p: Family news: news of letters sent to him. News of Charles' staying with his uncle and aunt in Tennessee.

did.unittitle: Charles C[ampbell], Chota, Tennessee to Mrs. M[ildred] W. Campbell,Petersburg, 20 September 1834.

scopecontent.p: His first teaching job (the children of Mr. Henley). Talks of staying with his cousins. Postscript: E[lizabeth] Henley,Chota, Tennessee to Mrs. Mildred W. Campbell, Petersburg. Expresses hope she will come to Tennessee to visit.

did.unittitle: [Mildred W. Campbell] to Charles Campbell, Chota, Tennessee, [October 1834]?

scopecontent.p: Happy to hear he has arrived safely at Chota. Postscript: Alexander S. Campbell to [Charles Campbell]. News of school. Incomplete.

did.unittitle: Jo[h]n W[ilson]Campbell, Petersburg, [Virginia] to Charles [Campbell], [Chota, Tennessee], 2 October 1834.

scopecontent.p: Advises Charles Campbell to settle in the West; hoped Charles Campbell could work for the railroad. Also a note from Charles Campbell's brother Alexander. Charles Campbell's Review of Oberlinwill appear in the next number of the register; "anti-Leigh Men Met"; Business at the store has picked up.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Campbell, Petersburg to [Charles Campbell], [Chota], 7 October 1834.

scopecontent.p: Her return home after two months. Happy to hear he is at Uncle Henley's at Chota. Her trip to Saratoga Springs, Princeton, and Philadelphia.

did.unittitle: Lavinia [McPheeters],Raleigh to [Charles Campbell], 30 October 1834.

scopecontent.p: Surprised he is at Chota; Cholera epidemic in Petersburg; has given up going to parties since she already has "enough worldliness and wickedness."

did.unittitle: Elizabeth M. Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia to Charles Campbell, Chota, Tennessee, 5 November 1834.

scopecontent.p: Social news. Informs him of her reading. Mention Mr. Maben "he is to be a near relation of yours."

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, Hard-Times, Blount County, Tennessee, to [Elizabeth Campbell], 3 November 1834.

scopecontent.p: Having grown dissatisfied with Chota, he has left it very discontented, still looking for an occupation in a quiet place.

did.unittitle: C[harles] C[ampbell], Hard-Times, Tennessee to E[lizabeth] Campbell,Petersburg, Virginia, 5 November [18]34.

scopecontent.p: Staying with Uncle Spotswood, leaving for Alabama tomorrow by stage. Again mentions going to Illinois.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, Glencoe, Alabama to E[lizabeth] M. Campbell,Petersburg, December 1834.

scopecontent.p: Arrived Tuscumbia four days ago news of relatives there. Looking for a school that suits him.

did.unittitle: E[lizabeth] M. Henley,Chota, Tennessee to Elizabeth M. Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, December 1834.

scopecontent.p: Charles has left for Tuscumbia; Margaret Keller to marry Dr. Newsom; family news.

did.unittitle: J. H. Gillespie, Somerville, [Alabama] to "brother," 12 December 1834.

scopecontent.p: Has not chosen a superintendent of the male academy; Academy has 35 students.

did.unittitle: E[lizabeth] Campbell,Petersburg to Charles Campbell, Tuscumbia, Alabama, 18 December 1834.

scopecontent.p: Inquires about Alabama cousins. Petersburg a very busy place: social news. Church news.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, Glencoe, Alabama to E[lizabeth] M. Campbell,Petersburg, 26 December 1834.

scopecontent.p: Asks her to send money. Appointed head of the Academy in Somerville, Alabama. News of cotton crop.

did.unittitle: Letters, 1835.
[Elizabeth Campbell] Petersburg to Charles Campbell, Somerville, Alabama, 3 January 1835.

scopecontent.p: Mother going to Sussex, Shirley. Rival bookstore to Father's set up. Social news. Postscript: M[ildred] W. C[ampbell]to Charles [Campbell]. News of her travel.

did.unittitle: [Elizabeth M. Campbell], Petersburg to Charles Campbell, Somerville, Alabama, 16 January 1835.

scopecontent.p: Glad to hear of his teaching job. Social news.

did.unittitle: E[lizabeth] M. Henley,Chota, Tennessee to Charles Campbell, Somerville, Alabama, 17 January 1835.

scopecontent.p: Hopes to visit relatives; family news.

did.unittitle: C[harles] C[ampbell] Glencoe, Alabama to Elizabeth M. Campbell, Petersburg, 19 January 1835.

scopecontent.p: News of school: it commences February 1. Wonders about his being able to stand the physical exertions of teaching. Family news. Inquiries into pension claims.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Glencoe, Alabama, to Lavinia MePheeters, 20 January 1835.

scopecontent.p: Enjoyed Chota; is going to Somerville to teach; his life darkened by "sombre colors" and "blue-devils."

did.unittitle: J[ohn] W[ilson] Campbell,Petersburg, [Virginia] to Charles [Campbell], 28 January 1835.

scopecontent.p: Problems with getting a note paid; family news, will send Charles Campbell periodicals and the town paper; river has been closed by ice; business is slow; thinking about moving west.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Somerville, Alabama to Henry Barnard, 7 February 1835.

scopecontent.p: He left Chota, Tennessee two months ago and is now directing a school in Somerville. He is still melancholy and afflicted with headaches.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, Somerville, Alabama to John W[ilson] Campbell,Petersburg, Virginia, 14 February 1835.

scopecontent.p: Capt. Duncan's draft; 21 students in his school supplying books for his school; asks about texts; interest in election of Virginia Senator; Easier to make money in Alabama but prices are high; describes the countryside.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, Somerville, Alabama to E[lizabeth] M. Campbell,Petersburg, 27 February 1835.

scopecontent.p: School opened: currently 16 students with prospects of having 40-50 eventually. Social news: news that H. Bernard is to be married.

did.unittitle: Jo[h]n W[ilson] Campbell,Petersburg, [Virginia] to Charles Campbell, Somerville, North Alabama, 6 March 1835.

scopecontent.p: Can supply Charles Campbell with books-lists some available books; river is frozen; has sent Charles Campbell the January number of museum and will also send February. Also a note from Charles Campbell's sister Betty. Glad that Charles not complaining about headaches; is about to get married; measles epidemic; read Mr. Adams speech on the death of LaFayette; Aleck has sent a copy of Mr. Brown's speech in the legislature; Portsmouth railroad is progressing; China missionary will speak; offers to send Charles Campbell the Missionary Herald.

did.unittitle: David Keller, Tuscumbia, Alabama to Charles Campbell, Somerville, Alabama, 8 March 1835.

scopecontent.p: Hopes school teaching is going well; severe weather; comments on national politics, Van Buren and Judge White; French treaty and possibility of war with France.

did.unittitle: 29 March 1835. Charles Campbell, Sommerville, Alabama to John W[ilson] Campbell,Petersburg, Virginia,

scopecontent.p: Will get books from Philadelphia; Lists texts he wants. Also a note to his sister Betty. Has no plans to marry; his school may increase to 40 by the end of the year; is teaching Sunday school; family news.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Sommerville, Alabama to father [John Wilson Campbell], April 1835.

scopecontent.p: Asks father to send books; may be able to sell books to the nearby Female Seminary; asks for the issue of Farmer's Register with the article on Oberlin; asks for $10; health is normal and cuts wood for exercise.

did.unittitle: J[ohn] W[ilson] Campbell, Peters[burg], [Virginia]to Charles [Campbell], 3 May 1835.
Alexander Campbell, Petersburg, to Charles Campbell, Somerville, Alabama, [16 May 1835].

scopecontent.p: Social news; town very healthy, diseases gone. Inquiries about his school.

did.unittitle: E[lizabeth] M. Campbell,Sydney Grove to Charles Campbell, Somerville, Alabama, 24 May 1835.

scopecontent.p: Informs him of her intention to marry Mr. Maben about middle of July.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, Somerville, Alabama to Alexander S. Campbell, Petersburg, 31 May/1 June 1835.

scopecontent.p: News of school. 8 published numbers so far of his Somerville Weekly Advertiser. He will spend July vacation in Tuscumbia, Alabama.

did.unittitle: Neptune Anderson, Mobile, to Mrs. Mildred W. Campbell, Petersburg, 8 June 1835.

scopecontent.p: Has been living with some gentlemen from Boston who are the best of masters hopes to obtain a situation for the summer.

did.unittitle: David Keller, Tuscumbia [Alabama] to Charles Campbell, Somerville, Alabama, 9 June 1835.

scopecontent.p: Death of James McDonald; Care of Lavinia Moore.

did.unittitle: David Keller, at Mrs. [James] McDonald's ["Glencoe", Alabama] to Charles Campbell, Somerville, [Alabama], 11 June 1835.

scopecontent.p: Death of James McDonald; Uncle William Aylett may visit Somerville.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Sommerville, Alabama to John W[ilson] Campbell,Petersburg, Virginia, 13 June 1835.

scopecontent.p: Shipment of books; emigration of people from Alabama to the west; school will end June 26 and expects to vacation at Tuscumbia; his students like him.

did.unittitle: David Keller, Tuscumbia, [Alabama] to Charles Campbell, 18 June 1835.

scopecontent.p: Problem of guardianship of Lavinia Moore.

did.unittitle: Alex[ander] M[oore] Keller,Courtland to [Charles Campbell], 26 June 1835.

scopecontent.p: Visit to Tuscumbia and Courtland; death of James McDonald.

did.unittitle: Jo[h]n W[ilson] Campbell,Petersburg, [Virginia] to Charles Campbell, Tuscumbia, Alabama, 1 July 1835.

scopecontent.p: Charles Campbell's sister Elizabeth was married at 4 AM; Describes Elizabeth Campbell's husband Mr. Maben; will try to get Charles Campbell's books sent; is closing his store.

did.unittitle: Lavinia [McPheeters],Raleigh, [North Carolina] to Elizabeth Maben, 11 July 1835.

scopecontent.p: Glad Elizabeth got married; Henry Cannon stabbed his mother's husband.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell] Glencoe, to "Mother" [Mildred Walker Campbell], 11 July 1835.

scopecontent.p: Visiting Uncle William Aylett; his school going well.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Glencoe, Alabama to Mrs. M[ildred] W. Campbell,Petersburg, 11 July 1835.

scopecontent.p: Spending his vacation with Aunt Eliza. Prospects for new school session beginning August 10. Family news.

did.unittitle: Ar[thur] H[azelrigg] Henley,Chota, [Tennessee] to Jo[hn] W[ilson] Campbell,Petersburg, Virginia, 12 July 1835.

scopecontent.p: Money for Charles Campbell; Charles Campbell in good health and happy with his situation; hopes that John Wilson Campbell's daughter Elizabeth is happily married; does not recommend moving west; if he could leave Tennessee, would move to Texas.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Tuscumbia, Alabama to Mr. [Arthur H.] Henley,14 July 1835.

scopecontent.p: Asks Arthur H. Henley to forward the balance of his money; health is not good; sister Elizabeth to be married to Mr. Maben and journey north; cousin Lavinia McPheeters to be married; Mr. Keller in town to see Parsons, the gubernatorial candidate.

did.unittitle: [Mrs. Mildred W. Campbell], Petersburg, to Charles Campbell, Somerville, Alabama, 27 July 1835.

scopecontent.p: Informs him of marriage of his sister, "Bet", to Mr. Maben. Her trip to Princeton. List of books sent to him.

did.unittitle: Jo[hn] W[ilson] Campbell,Petersburg, [Virginia] to Charles [Campbell], 8 August 1835.

scopecontent.p: Money for Charles Campbell; Charles Campbell's books sent to him; John Wilson Campbell will get out of debt this year; Mr. Ruffin offered to lend his register to Charles Campbell; John Wilson Campbell has sent the intelligencer to Charles Campbell; family news.

did.unittitle: David Keller, Tuscumbia, [Alabama] to Charles [Campbell], 14 August 1835.

scopecontent.p: Guardianship of Lavinia Moore.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth M. Henley, Chota, Tennessee to Charles Campbell, Sommerville, Alabama, 1 September 1835.

scopecontent.p: Hopes he will visit; family news.

did.unittitle: M[ary] K. Henley,Chota [Tennessee] to Charles Campbell, Sommerville, Alabama, 20 September 1835.

scopecontent.p: Hopes he will visit; family news. "Minna" [Elizabeth M. Henley] to Charles Campbell. Family news.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Sommerville, Alabama to John W[ilson] Campbell,Petersburg, Virginia, 20 September 1835.

scopecontent.p: Books have arrived, lists them; if brother Aleck wants to join Charles Campbell and teach he should prepare himself; has received the periodicals, Intelligencer, Museum, Ruffin's Register; Charles Campbell sent Ruffin an article for the Register.

did.unittitle: D[avid] Keller,Tuscumbia, [Alabama] to Charles [Campbell], 22 September 1835.

scopecontent.p: Charles Campbell has visited Virginia; Charles Campbell's books have been sent.

did.unittitle: [William Aylett?], Rose Hill, Tuscaloosa City to Charles, 25 September 1835.

scopecontent.p: Did not move to town; Elizabeth at the Female Academy.

did.unittitle: David Keller, Tuscumbia [Alabama] to Mary K. Henley, Chota, Monroe, E. Tennessee, 2 October 1835.

scopecontent.p: Cannot visit Chota; family news.

did.unittitle: David Keller, Tuscumbia [Alabama] to Charles [Campbell], 7 October 1835.

scopecontent.p: Items sent to Lavinia Moore.

did.unittitle: Jo[h]n W[ilson] Campbell,Petersburg, [Virginia] to Charles Campbell, Sommerville, Alabama, 8 October 1835.

scopecontent.p:
Is settling his business books and opening new books for his partnership with Mr. Ruffin; has given up plans to move West; family news.
Letter also includes a note from Mother [?].
Letter also includes a note from brother A. S. Campbell; father's business with Mr. Ruffin will be called Campbell & Ruffin and will be a large establishment.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, Somerville, Alabama to D[avid] Keller,15 October 1835.

scopecontent.p: Acknowledges receipt of items for Lavinia Moore; father in partnership with Edmund Ruffin.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, Somerville, Alabama to [Elizabeth Campbell Maben], 24 October 1835.

scopecontent.p: Family news: 1835 an important year for Campbell family with her marriage and his trip west. School attendance falling off: he will not stay beyond current session.

did.unittitle: [Lavinia McPheeters], Raleigh, [North Carolina] to [Aunt Mildred W. Campbell?], 26 October 1835.

scopecontent.p: Father thought of going to a temperance convention; expects to be married next week to Mr. Brown; invites Aunt to wedding.

did.unittitle: [Elizabeth Campbell Maben], Petersburg to Charles Campbell, Sommerville, Alabama, 11 November 1835.

scopecontent.p: Father in New York. Various other family news. Several lines of the letter are written and initialed by Alexander Spotswood Campbell.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Sommerville, Alabama to Mrs. M[ildred] W. Campbell,Petersburg, 9 December 1835.

scopecontent.p: Informs her he has given up the school and intends to move on. Includes a recipe for making beer.

did.unittitle: M[ary] K. Henley,Chota, Tennessee to Charles Campbell, Sommerville, Alabama, 11 December 1835.

scopecontent.p: Family news.

did.unittitle: Mrs. M[ildred] W. Campbell,[Petersburg] to Charles Campbell, Tuscumbia, Alabama, Christmas 1835.

scopecontent.p: Suggests he come home and open a school there. Family news.

did.unittitle: Letters, 1836.
Alexander S. Campbell [Petersburg] to Charles [Campbell], [Chota], [1836].

scopecontent.p: He is spending vacation in Petersburg. Betty going to Richmond tomorrow. Intends to come west when he has finished school.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Glencoe, to [Mildred Campbell], 13 February 1836.

scopecontent.p: Left Sommerville, 8th January; plans not to return to Virginia. Keller has sold plantation, thinks Petersburg good place for Lavinia, mention of Texas, Seminoles in Florida, fire at New York. [Edmund] Ruffinhas migrated to Bowden's Corner, please tell him infomation concerning Bland's manuscripts at John Meade's near City Point which he ought to publish.

did.unittitle: Char[les] Campbell, Glencoe, Alabama to father [John Wilson Campbell], 14 March 1836.

scopecontent.p: Regrets imposing on his relatives hospitality for so long; worries about being able to support himself; has no plans to return to Virginia.

did.unittitle: Alexander S. Campbell to Charles [Campbell], [May 1836-1837?].

scopecontent.p: Has read his article in Farmer's Register.Social and family news; father has new store.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Glencoe, Alabama to John W[ilson] Campbell,Petersburg, Virginia; 21 May 1836.

scopecontent.p: Received John Wilson Campbell's check for $215.76; expects to stay at Glencoe until August; regards teaching as a "dernier resort which I wish to abandon as soon as possible as being very unfavorable to my health"; Tuscumbia held an illumination in honor of Houston's victory over St. Anna; sent articles to Ruffin and the Messenger, but has gotten no acknowledgement; is never without a headache.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, [Tuscumbia] to [Alexander S. Campbell], [8 June 1836-1837?].

scopecontent.p: News of Texas wars. Received money sent from home.

did.unittitle: J[ohn] W[ilson] Campbell,Petersburg, [Virginia] to Charles [Campbell], 17 June 1836.

scopecontent.p: Charles Campbell mentioned that he had written several hundred pages and John Wilson Campbell urges him to publish, fiction is most profitable, and Carruthers and French have done well even though they are "ordinary writers"; advises Charles Campbell against putting out a newspaper or literary paper; Elizabeth Maben has a baby girl; three new railroads building locally; Edmund Ruffin, Jr., is working for a railroad; expects few Virginians to go to Texas until things are settled with the Mexicans; development of local interest in silk culture; local prices very high.

did.unittitle: Cha[rle]s Campbell, Glencoe, Alabama to [Elizabeth Campbell Maben], 17 June 1836.

scopecontent.p: He has been sick and confined to bed. News of crops. Cousin Alfred Aglett dies. Speaks of incompatibility of his headaches with teaching profession.

did.unittitle: E[lizabeth] M. Henley,Chota, Tennessee to Charles Campbell, Tuscumbia, Alabama, 25 June 1836.

scopecontent.p: Family news.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. Carter,Shirley to Mrs. M[ildred] W. Campbell,Petersburg, 25 June 1836.

scopecontent.p: Inquires after her family. Trouble with her eyes. Weather poor, wheat crop failing.

did.unittitle: C[harles] C[ampbell], Chota, Tennessee to [Elizabeth Campbell Maben], 20 August 1836.

scopecontent.p: Informs her of his intention to marry Elvira N. Callaway of Toqua before end of September. His intention to return to Virginia then. Inquires after health of her child.

did.unittitle: C[harles] [Campbell], Chota, [Tennessee] to E[lvira Callaway],23 August 1836.

scopecontent.p: Looking forward to their wedding, September 13.

did.unittitle: C[harles] [Campbell], Chota, [Tennessee] to E[lvira Callaway],25 August 1836.

scopecontent.p: Looking forward to their marriage.

did.unittitle: E[lizabeth] M. [Maben],Petersburg to Charles Campbell, Tuscumbia, Alabama, [? September 1836].

scopecontent.p: Social news. Spring arriving. Mother has left but she sees father every day.

did.unittitle: E[lizabeth] M. Maben,Petersburg, to Charles Campbell, Chota, Tennessee, September 1836.

scopecontent.p:
She has been sick in bed. She is pleased to hear of his marriage. She is very busy taking care of her child [Jane], husband, and house. Mr. Maben has also been ill. Aleck goes to College in November.
Postscript: 2 pages. ALS.
A[lexander] S[potswood] Campbell,to Charles [Campbell]. Hopes Charles will return before he goes to College.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, Chota, Tennessee to Mrs. M[ildred] W. Campbell,Petersburg, 4 September 1836.

scopecontent.p: Informs her of his impending marriage and trip to Virginia. Description of his bride.

did.unittitle: M[ary] K. Henley,Chota, [Tennessee] to Mildred W. Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 11 September 1836.

scopecontent.p: Charles Campbell will be leaving for Virginia in two days to bring his wife home; would like to visit Virginia. Elizabeth J. Henley to Mildred W. Campbell. Best wishes.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to H[enry] Barnard,26 September 1836.

scopecontent.p: Summarizes his travels in the West for the last 2 years. Tells of his marriage. He is still not very well, but has done some writing and may attempt to publish some of it.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg, Virginia to A[rthur] H[azelrigg] Henley,25 October 1836.

scopecontent.p: Difficult seven day journey from Knoxville to Petersburg; Petersburg vastly improved since last visit and $200,000 subscribed for a railroad to E. Tennessee; wife Elvira happy and attends church more; Synod will meet in Petersburg next week; has found some Revolutionary War papers and six George Washington letters.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia to Arthur Henley, Chota, E. Tennessee, 28 October 1836.

scopecontent.p: Took seven days to travel from Knoxville to Petersburg and was a difficult journey; Petersburg is vastly improved and is planning to build a railroad to E. Tennessee for which they have a $200,000 subscription; Betty lives in a fine house and her husband is worth $100,000 but is a tobacco speculator so may go broke; brother Aleck going to Princeton; wife Elvira happy; synod meets in Petersburg next week; child abandoned on a doorstep in town and Charles Campbell's mother subpoenaed as a witness in the case; thinks of moving west to Illinois or Missouri when the estate settled.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to [Henry] Barnard,2 November 1836.

scopecontent.p: Has decided not to go to New York and so will not be able to meet him. Has abandoned plan of publishing some of his work.

did.unittitle: Henry Barnard, Hartford, Connecticut to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 12 November 1836.

scopecontent.p: Expresses interest in his research in Revolutionary documents and letters. Reports the death of a friend, and other social news. Says that Van Buren was almost defeated in Connecticut.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Norfolk, [Virginia] to Elvira [Campbell],[Petersburg, Virginia], 18 November 1836.

scopecontent.p: Describes his trip to Norfolk; went with Mr. Ruffin to Suffolk; will go by boat to Philadelphia; will return in 10 days; spent an evening with Barraud.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Henley, Chota, Tennessee to Elvira A. Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 25 November 1836.

scopecontent.p: Misses her company. Also, a note from Mary Henley. Misses her.

did.unittitle: [Rev. W. S. Plumer] (penciled in), Richmond, to [Charles Campbell], 12 December 1836.

scopecontent.p: Charles Campbell's letter received, has attended to matter. Suggests not to send any piece on which have not done his best.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell to O. B. Barraud, Petersburg, 19 December 1836.

scopecontent.p: Letter explains a possible business speculation in a cotton seed oil business (Smith & Follett, owners).

did.unittitle:
Letters,
1837.
Charles Campbell to Aunt, [c. 1837].

scopecontent.p: Elvira needs assistance, asks for Mrs. Paisley to come immediately.

did.unittitle: Alexander S. Campbell to Charles [Campbell], [1837?].

scopecontent.p: Studies going well except for mathematics. Gave first College speech on "Love of Country." Glad to have sister Betty write to him.

did.unittitle: Account of Mr. Campbell with Boswell Jefferson, 3 January 1837.
Charles Campbell, Petersburg, to Mr. Anderson, Yorktown, 18 January 1837.

scopecontent.p: Campbell about to publish short work on Virginia history in Southern Literary Messenger.Requests information from Anderson on James City and Gloucester Counties, Yorktown and siege.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Aylett Keller, Tuscumbia, [Alabama] to Charles Campbell, Chota, Tennessee, 13 February 1837.

scopecontent.p: News of the Female Academy she is attending; family gossip.

did.unittitle: E[lizabeth] M. M[aben]to Charles Campbell, Chota, East Tennessee, [27] February [1837].

scopecontent.p:
News of Father's business and her reading. Mr. Maben thinking of going to Texas, but may put it off. He is going to England next year. News of Aleck in College.
Postscript: 2 pages. ALS. [Mildred W. Campbell] to [Charles Campbell]. Social news.

did.unittitle: W[illia]m M. Campbell,St. Charles, Missouri to Charles Campbell, Chota, Monroe County, Tennessee, 5 March 1837.

scopecontent.p: Has been in Missouri 7 years; Is a member of the general assembly; Lists Missouri resources.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Toqua, Monroe County, Tennessee to [Elizabeth Aylett Keller?] [Tuscumbia, Alabama], 7 March 1837.
Tho[ma]s C. Batte,Charles County Missouri, to Charles Campbell, Monroe County, Chota P.O., East Tennessee, 10 March 1837.

scopecontent.p: Suggests Charles Campbell move to his state but visit before he decides doing so. Cost of government priced land is increasing. Discussion of the climate.

did.unittitle: Elvira N. Campbell, Toqua, Tennessee to [Mrs. Mildred W. Campbell], [Petersburg], 16 March 1837.

scopecontent.p: Speaks of possibility of building a house; Mr. Campbell's (Charles?) like of farming.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, Chota, Tennessee to Mrs. M[ildred] W. Campbell,Petersburg, Virginia, 18 March [1837].

scopecontent.p: Informs her of land he has bought and his intentions to build on it.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Keller, Tuscumbia [Alabama] to Charles Campbell, Chota, Tennessee, 31 March 1837.
Mrs. M[ildred] W. Campbell,Petersburg to Charles Campbell, Chota, Tennessee, 7 April 1837.

scopecontent.p: Family news. Effects of worsening economic conditions on various neighbors.

did.unittitle: E[lizabeth] M. Maben,Petersburg to Charles Campbell, Chota, Tennessee, [19 April 1837].

scopecontent.p: Were visited by Aleck. Going to Richmond shortly. News of Aleck in college.

did.unittitle: A[lexander] M[oore] Keller,Tuscumbia [Alabama] to Aunt, 8 May 1837.
Charles Campbell, Toqua Creek to Elizabeth Aylett Keller, Tuscumbia, Alabama, 15 May 1837.

scopecontent.p: Family news; is living in a log house; corn scarce; has heard report of low cotton prices.

did.unittitle: J[ohn] W[ilson] Campbell,Petersburg, [Virginia] to Charles [Campbell], 8 June 1837.

scopecontent.p: John Wilson Campbell has been unwell; businesses are all doing badly banks, railroads, etc., and therefore will be unable to help Charles Campbell out; fever to move west has died out; Mabens spoke of traveling north, but currency troubles make travel difficult.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Toqua, Tennessee to [Thomas W.] White,12 June 1837.

scopecontent.p: Was happy to see recent article of his appear in the Southern Literary Messenger. Points out that some of his sentences were made to stand alone as paragraphs. Encloses an order in which he wants future articles published.

did.unittitle: Mrs. M[ildred] W. Campbell,Petersburg to Charles Campbell, Chota, Tennessee, 4 July 1837.

scopecontent.p: Her recovery from influenza. Mention of a recent religious convention.

did.unittitle: [Elvira C. Campbell] Toqua to [Mildred W. Campbell], [Petersburg], 6 July 1837.

scopecontent.p: They have moved and have built two cabins and a stable. Hard times, everything scarce. Charles sick from exertion of building.

did.unittitle: Alexander S. Campbell, Princeton, New Jersey to Charles Campbell, Chota, Tennessee, 12 July [1837].

scopecontent.p: Has sent him college catalogue. Describes 4th of July festivities. Requests suggestions for senior speech topics.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Toqua to [Alexander S. Campbell]. 29 July 1837.

scopecontent.p: Announces birth of his son, named Callaway. Farming going well. Suggestions for Aleck's "senior speech": the lights and shadows of a student's life, description of Princeton, on the death of Major Andre, defense of U.S. policy toward Indians.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Toqua, Tennessee to [Mrs. Mildred W. Campbell], [Petersburg], 1 August 1837.

scopecontent.p: Announces death of his wife, Elvira, of child-bed fever; leaving him and his child. He has given the child to Elvira's sister.

did.unittitle: Alexander S. Campbell, Na[s]sau Hall,to [John W. Campbell], [Petersburg], [September 1837].

scopecontent.p: Received and is saddened by news of Elvira Callaway Campbell's death. Session over at end of month; he will return home then.

did.unittitle: E[lizabeth] M. Maben,Fauquier, to Mrs. [Mildred W.] Campbell,Petersburg, 1 September [1837].

scopecontent.p: Received news of Elvira Campbell's death. Her family all well, going to Winchester next week and returning ca. first of October.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg, Virginia to [Callaway], 8 September 1837.

scopecontent.p: Wants her to bring his child to Petersburg.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg, Virginia to cousin, 12 September 1837.

scopecontent.p: Mourns death of his wife; regrets leaving his child.

did.unittitle: William M. Campbell, St. Charles, Missouri, to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 27 September 1837.

scopecontent.p: Sympathy at death of Charles Campbell's wife; uncertain about Charles Campbell starting a literary paper; his section of the country lacks money.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell] to [Mary K. Henley?], October 1837.

scopecontent.p: Misses his child; suffers from headache and depression; family news.

did.unittitle: Betty [Elizabeth M. Henley], Chota, Tennessee to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 8 October 1837.
Charles Campbell, Petersburg, [Virginia]. to Lavinia M[cPheeters] Brown,Raleigh, North Carolina, 16 October 1837.

scopecontent.p: Sad she is in ill health; his wife dead of "fever and derangement;" expects his headache will never end; his wife's family trying to keep his son.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia to Elizabeth Keller, Tuscumbia, Alabama, 30 October 1837.

scopecontent.p: Sympathy on death of her father; reports death of his wife and birth of his son; his son taken from him; brother Aleck going to Princeton; his headache continues; melancholy continues.

did.unittitle: Lavinia M[cPheeters] Brown,Raleigh, [North Carolina] to Charles Campbell, November 1837.

scopecontent.p: Has been sick; thinks Charles Campbell should continue with engineering; would like Betty to visit when the railroad is done; does not appear to be sick because she has a nervous disease.

did.unittitle: [?], Mobile to Charles Cam[pbe]ll, Petersburg, Virginia, 30 November 1837.
Alexander Moore Keller, Tuscumbia [Alabama] to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 2 December 1837.

scopecontent.p: Has visited relatives at Chota.

did.unittitle: R. M. Anderson to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 8 December 1837.

scopecontent.p: On guardianship of Charles Campbell's son Callaway; legal advice on the guardianship; Mr. Callaway has not filed a legal motion to take over the guardianship; advises Charles Campbell to file a motion on it in Federal Court.

did.unittitle: [A. M. Keller], Tuscumbia, [Alabama] to Charles Campbell; Petersburg, Virginia, 27 December 1837.

scopecontent.p: Courtship; Family news.

did.unittitle:
Letters,
1838.
Lavinia Moore, Petersburg, [Virginia] to "Mother" [A. J. Dickson], [c. 1838].

scopecontent.p: Is going to Mrs. Gray's school; brother William has grown a lot.

did.unittitle: [Alexander S. Campbell], Princeton, to [John W. Campbell], Petersburg, [1838?].

scopecontent.p: Stopped in Washington and went to House and Senate. Describes burning of Abolitionists Hall in Philadelphia. Has read piece in New Yorkerby Charles.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia to [Thomas H.] Williamson,6 January 1838.

scopecontent.p: Would like to work on railroad for health reasons.

did.unittitle: A[nne] E[velina] H[enley],Chota, [Tennessee] to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 6 January 1838.

scopecontent.p: News of his son; is teaching her younger children; Uncle Spotswood has rheumatism.

did.unittitle: Henry Barnard Hartford, Connecticut to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 7 January 1838.

scopecontent.p: Difficulty in settling his father's estate prevents him from coming to Virginia. He greatly enjoyed spending New Years Day in New York. Tells him of books he has been reading.

did.unittitle: [Otway B. Barraud], Norfolk, to Charles Campbell, 13 January 1838.

scopecontent.p: Extends his condolences. Encourages him to go into editing newspaper or magazine, particularly perhaps the Messenger, believing Campbell would do a better job than White. At same time, Barraud excuses himself from joining in the venture.

did.unittitle: [Thomas Williamson], Westham to [Charles] Campbell, 17 January 1838.

scopecontent.p: Can use him for a reference; Job opening for a surveyor for a canal.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. C[arter],Shirley to Mrs. M[ildred] W. Campbell,Petersburg, 20 January 1838.

scopecontent.p: Has not yet received package sent. Will send $30 next week. Invites her for visit.

did.unittitle: [Illegible], Petersburg, to Samuel Houston, President of Texas, 22 January 1838.

scopecontent.p: Letter of recommendation for Frederick Robbins.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg, to [Alexander S. Campbell], 23 January 1838.

scopecontent.p: Father has been nominated for office of Collector; will soon control patronage involved. He is about to undertake engineering job on James River. Mentions other political matters: Canada, Texas bill.

did.unittitle: [William M. Campbell], St. Charles, Missouri to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 15 April 1838.

scopecontent.p: "Bitter effects of the bank veto" which "deranged Commerce"; asks for Petersburg information for Hannah Rochester.

did.unittitle: A[lexander] S. Campbell,Princeton, to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, June 1838.

scopecontent.p: Has seen subsequent articles in New Yorkerby Charles. News of Princeton. Has been reading newspapers, etc.

did.unittitle: A. J. Dickson, to "daughter" [Maria Lavinia Moore], Petersburg, Virginia, 8 June 1838.
Charles Campbell, Petersburg, to [Alexander Campbell], [Princeton], 1 July 1838.

scopecontent.p: Family and social news. Politics: Speaks of struggles in House over subtreasury and banks. Talk of split in Whig Party.

did.unittitle: Alexander S. Campbell, Princeton, New Jersey, to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 9 July 1838.

scopecontent.p: Describes 4th of July celebration mentions opinions of Literary Messengerand New Yorker. Will write to father.

did.unittitle: [A. M. Keller], Buzzard Roost, Alabama to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 4 September 1838.

scopecontent.p: Announces his engagement and lists fiancee's accomplishments; she is Irish and named Jane E. Sheegog.

did.unittitle: Cha[rle]s Campbell, Chota, to [Alexander S. Campbell], 10 September 1838.

scopecontent.p: His visit to Cherokee Camp described. Speaks of legal difficulties in obtaining possession of his son. Headaches very bad.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. Carter,Shirley to Mrs. Mildred Campbell, Petersburg, 20 October 1838.

scopecontent.p: Inquires for news of her trip. Intends to visit her, at time of fair and church meeting. Describes sad condition of her own parish.

did.unittitle: Joseph B. Gravely, Breckenridge, to Ch[arles] Campbell, 23 October 1838.

scopecontent.p: A subscription letter for 1st ed. of History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: Betty [Elizabeth M. Henley], Chota, Tennessee to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 9 November 1838.

scopecontent.p: News of Charles Campbell's son; soldiers pursuing Indians; family news.

did.unittitle: [?] W. Fisher, East Netel [?] to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 26 November 1838.

scopecontent.p: Thinks Upshur manuscript still exists.

did.unittitle: Ed[mund] Ruffinand Jos[eph] A. White, Petersburg to [Charles Campbell], 29 December 1838.

scopecontent.p: They ask him to give one or more lectures before the Petersburg Lyceum.

did.unittitle:
Letters,
1839.
[Charles Campbell?] to T. T. Campbell, [c. 1839].

scopecontent.p: Discusses taking of depositions in his case to gain guardianship of his son.

did.unittitle:
R. Baird, Richmond, [Virginia] to
Mr. and Mrs. John W[ilson] Campbell,Petersburg, Virginia, 16 February 1839.

scopecontent.p: Will preach in the Presbyterian Church about France; will preach in Petersburg Monday and asks John Wilson Campbell to announce it; will lecture on Evangelical religion in France.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg, to Mrs. McGuire, 8 March 1839.

scopecontent.p: Thanks her for a letter.

did.unittitle: M[ary] K. Henley,Chota, [Tennessee] to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 13 April [C. 1839].

scopecontent.p: News of Charles Campbell's son; family news. Betty [Elizabeth M. Henley] to Charles Campbell. News of his son.

did.unittitle: Ar[thur] H[azelrigg] Henley,Chota, [Tennessee] to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 22 June 1839.

scopecontent.p: Describes legal maneuvers over guardianship of Charles Campbell's son; only ground Charles Campbell could lose the case on would be his insanity, but Arthur Hazelrigg Henley Does not expect that tactic to succeed; Charles Campbell's son is well; Family news. M[ary] K. Henleyto Charles Campbell. Gossip has ruined Mrs. Russell's reputation; Uncle Spotswood happy with his new home at Aunt Eliza's; Charles Campbell's son is learning to talk.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia to Mr. Tarver, 28 June 1839.

scopecontent.p: Has not written to Lavinia Moore's mother because some of her views are "indiscreet and improper"; thinks Mr. Tarver will do all that is proper for Lavinia; Lavinia is well.

did.unittitle: Henry Barnard, Hartford, Connecticut to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 3 July 1839.

scopecontent.p: He has been kept extremely busy with his activities of establishing the Board of Education in Connecticut. Gives news of mutual friends. He is active in founding of Connecticut Historical Society.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg, to Mr. [Thomas] White,19 July 1839.

scopecontent.p: Has some historic letters he would like published in the Messenger.

did.unittitle: Ar[thur] H[azelrigg] Henley,Chota, Tennessee, to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 20 July 1839.

scopecontent.p: Reports on progress of Charles Campbell's legal attempts to gain guardianship of his son, all testimony has been in Charles Campbell's favor; Charles Campbell's son healthy; Arthur Hazelrigg Henley. Has a "nervous affection" in his right hand which prevents him from writing well; N. Byers swore in court that he saw Charles Campbell "in a passion" once.

did.unittitle: Th[omas] W. White,Richmond to Charles Campbell, 20 July 1839.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for Col. Bland's letter, which will be published in the September issue of the Messenger. He is flooded with contributions to the Messenger: he has more than he can publish. Apologizes for not being able to publish more of Campbell's material, but hopes to do better in the future.

did.unittitle: Mr. [?] Cocke, to Alex[ander] S. Campbell,Petersburg, 21 July 1839.

scopecontent.p: Invitation to dinner at Evergreen on 24 July.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg, Virginia to T. J. Campbell, 1 August 1839.

scopecontent.p: Legal difficulties with regard to guardianship of Charles Campbell's son.

did.unittitle: Charles F. Osborne, Petersburg, to Charles Campbell, August 183[?]9.

scopecontent.p: Pertains to publication arrangements.

did.unittitle: Charles F. Osborne, Petersburg, to Ch[arles] Campbell, 21 August 1839.

scopecontent.p: Publications arrangements and offer of editorship of Democratic paper.

did.unittitle: J[ames] E. Heath,Richmond to [Charles Campbell], 27 August 1839.

scopecontent.p: Informs him of Thomas White's intention not to publish large selections of the Bland manuscripts in the Messenger, and the reasons for this. Decries the "vassalage" of Virginia to the standards of New York literature."

did.unittitle: John Alexander, Rock Castle, Lexington, Virginia to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 9 September 1839.
Jared Sparks, Cambridge, Massachusetts to Charles Campbell, [Petersburg], 10 September 1839.

scopecontent.p: Is glad to learn he intends to publish the Bland Papers. Suggests he write to Carey and Lea of Philadelphia or Harper and Brothers of New York, to see if either will publish it. Will be happy to aid the project in any way if he can.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to [Jared Sparks, Cambridge, Massachusetts]. 23 September 1839.

scopecontent.p: Forwards him a catalogue of the Bland Papers. He will attempt to have them published in Virginia rather than in Boston.

did.unittitle: Arthur Hazelrigg Henley Chota, [Tennessee] to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 27 September 1839.

scopecontent.p:
The court has decided to give Charles Campbell custody of his son; importance of a father's influence on his son.
Letter also includes a note from
Betty [Elizabeth M.] Henleyto Charles Campbell with her best wishes.

did.unittitle: H. D. Gilpin, Washington, to Ch[arles] Campbell, Petersburg, 30 September 1839.

scopecontent.p: Gilpin encouraged Campbell to examine and publish the Colonel Bland papers which Campbell possessed.

did.unittitle: Ar[thur] H[azelrigg] Henley,Chota, [Tennessee] to John W[ilson] Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 15 October 1839.

scopecontent.p: Has settled accounts as administrator of the A. Schoore Estate; account of testimony in Charles Campbell's guardianship case for custody of his son. Includes a copy of the court clerk's record on the Alexander Schoore Estate.

did.unittitle: Jared Sparks, Cambridge, Massachusetts to Charles Campbell, [Petersburg], 12 November 1839.

scopecontent.p: Having examined the Bland Paperscatalogue, he thinks they will be very important. Thinks it best to have them published in Virginia. Advises him to place all financial risk on publishers, if possible.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. C[arter],Shirley to Mrs. Mildred Campbell, Petersburg, 15 November 1839.

scopecontent.p: She has not been well. Death of Dr. Berkeley, other local news. Charles [Campbell]'s health precarious, also.

did.unittitle: Th[omas] W. WhitesRichmond to Charles Campbell, 27 December 1839.

scopecontent.p: Encloses a proof sheet of Campbell's forthcoming article in the Messengerand asks him to read it over. The Lynchburg Virginianof last Monday paid a compliment to Campbell's last item in the Messenger.

did.unittitle:
Letters,
1840.
[Charles Campbell] to [Callaway Campbell], [September ] [c. 1840's].

scopecontent.p: Health advice;-will get him a puppy; Mabens are at Sweet Spring; Uncle Tom moved from Cleveland to Toqua.

did.unittitle: Miss E. H. Taylor to [Charles Campbell], 1 February 1840.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for examining the proofs sent her by Thomas White. She returns them. She encloses another article and asks him to convey it to Mr. White.

did.unittitle: Miss E. H. Taylor to [Charles Campbell], 10 February 1840.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for sending proofs to her, and asks him now to return them to Thomas White.

did.unittitle: Tho[mas] W. White,Richmond to Charles Campbell, 13 February 1840.

scopecontent.p: Explains why Campbell has not been paid for his services to the Southern Literary Messenger. Will now pay him $1.50 per printed page, for future articles. Asks Campbell to "make some sport" for readers in future articles, although he has no objection to tragedy or melodrama.

did.unittitle: H. Meade, Amelia, to [Charles Campbell], 20 February 1840.

scopecontent.p: Details the mss. which he has that Campbell might be interested in. Mss. pertaining to Revolutionary War (Southern Campaign), letters of Major Eggleston, etc.

did.unittitle: Ar[thur] H[azelrigg] Henley,Chota, [Tennessee] to Charles [Campbell], 20 March 1840.

scopecontent.p: Charles Campbell won custody of his son, but the case is being appealed, therefore the boy will not be delivered; William G. Lear is becoming editor of the Hamilton Gazette; Lavinia Moore returned to Tuscumbia with several suitors; expects to see Charles Campbell in the summer.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, Petersburg, to Henry S[t.] George Tucker,Richmond, 24 March 1840.

scopecontent.p: Asks for data on Bland family.

did.unittitle: George Bancroft, Boston to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 25 March 1840.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for his offer to use the Bland Papers in his History of the U.S.

did.unittitle: P. D. Erigg and Elton, Philadelphia, to John W. Campbell, 30 March 1840.

scopecontent.p: Pertains to sale of work John W. Campbell wrote, not in their line, suggests other publisher and binders.

did.unittitle: H[enry] S[t.] G[eorge] Tucker,Rich[mon]d,to [Charles Campbell], 31 March 1840.

scopecontent.p: Data on Bland family.

did.unittitle: H. A. Garland, Washington, to [Charles Campbell?], 31 [March?] 1840.

scopecontent.p: Will attend to the papers; hopes he will make the paper a success.

did.unittitle: Ch[arles] Campbell, Petersburg, to Mr. H. McFarland, 7 April 1840.

scopecontent.p: Campbell requested McFarland's assistance in obtaining publication of the Bland Papers. Outlines his desired mode of publication.

did.unittitle: H[enry] S[t.] G[eorge] Tucker,Richmond, to [Charles Campbell], 9 April 1840.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for dedicating his book to him.

did.unittitle: Jo. Gaus Jr., Washington to Charles Campbell, 10 April 1840.

scopecontent.p: Note on family genealogy.

did.unittitle: H. S. G. Pucket[?] to [Charles] Campbell, 18 April 1840.
M[ary] B. Carter,Shirley to Charles [Campbell], 21 April 1840.

scopecontent.p: Invites him for visit to see his uncle Bernard [Carter]and her sister Mrs. Mason. Expresses her interest in his "antiquarian researches."

did.unittitle: Kate Beckwith, Raleigh, North Carolina to Anna Burdsall, Trenton, New Jersey, 22 April 1840.

scopecontent.p: Invites her to visit; visited relatives in New Bern.

did.unittitle: Miss E. H. Taylor [Charles Campbell], 6 May 1840.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for sending proofs to her, and asks him now to return them to Thomas White. Acknowledges receipt of his letters of February 10 and 22, which have just reached her.

did.unittitle: J. T. Bison[?], Petersburg to [Charles Campbell?], 15 June 1840.

scopecontent.p: Announces lecture to be given on June 17; invites him.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to B[enjamin] B. Minor,Richmond, 24 July 1840.

scopecontent.p: Congratulates him on his becoming editor and proprietor of the Messenger. Sends him some articles for inclusion in the Messenger.

did.unittitle: George Bancroft, Boston to Charles Campbell, [Petersburg], 27 July 1840.

scopecontent.p: Thinks the Bland Paperswill be valuable, but as he has no connection with the "North American Review" he cannot tell about publishing them in it. Asks him to forward a copy of the Bland Papersto the Attorney General in Washington, where he can pick them up.

did.unittitle: Ch[arles] Campbell, Petersburg, to H. D. Gilpin, 1 August 1840.

scopecontent.p: Campbell sending 2 copies of 1st vol. of Bland Papersto Gilpin.

did.unittitle: Jo[h]n E. Meade,Cawsons to Charles Campbell, 18 August 1840.

scopecontent.p: Is willing to help Mr. Banister, with the City Point RR Co., but doesn't think he would be useful.

did.unittitle: H. D. Gilpin, Washington, to Ch[arles] Campbell, Petersburg, 25 August 1840.

scopecontent.p: Thanks Campbell for the copies of the Bland Papers. Praises the effort of making available primary sources.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell] to [Mary K. Henley], 2 October 1840.

scopecontent.p: Son has been sick; brother Alek going to Missouri, has been invited to a Whig convention in Richmond.

did.unittitle: C[harles] C[ampbell], Petersburg, to "P. P.", Scottsville, Powhatan County, Virginia, 16 November 1840.

scopecontent.p: Historical and philosophical discussion of boots and politics.

did.unittitle: "P. P. Clerk of our Parish," Powhatan, to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 30 November 1840.

scopecontent.p: Historical and philosophical discussion of boots and of liberty.

did.unittitle: A[lexander] S. Campbell,Jefferson City, [Missouri] to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 16 November 1840.

scopecontent.p: His trip from St. Louis to St. Charles, described his stay with cousins there. After lengthy stay, went on to Jefferson City. Asks him to forward a copy of Messengerwith his piece about Virginia in it.

did.unittitle: E. A. Southwick, Pokeepsie, to Anna Burdsall, Mobile, Alabama, 6 December 1840.

scopecontent.p: Weather cold; Jane Burdsall married; is making doughnuts.

did.unittitle: Benjamin B. Minor, Kenmore to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 8 December 1840.

scopecontent.p: He plans to leave for Petersburg day after tomorrow. While in Richmond, he will try to get support for the publication of the Bland book, from Governor Gilmer. Social news of Fredericksburg.

did.unittitle:
Letters,
1841.
E[lizabeth] M. Henley,Chota, Tennessee to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 26 January [1841].

scopecontent.p: Whig and Harrison celebration in Knoxville; Family news.

did.unittitle: Ro. Caushon, Lynchburg, to [Charles Campbell], 12 February 1841.

scopecontent.p: Has in employ a hard working young man seeking printing work in Petersburg, and wishes Charles Campbell to employ him.

did.unittitle: Ar[thur] H[azelrigg] Henley,Chota [Tennessee], to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 12 February 1841.

scopecontent.p: Charles Campbell must go to Tennessee to assume custody of his son; Charles Campbell has become an "Editor, Democratic"; Arthur Hazelrigg Henley is a Whig and "a moderate party man"; Charles Campbell has sent Arthur Hazelrigg Henley copies of The Statesman.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. Carter,Shirley to Mrs. Mildred Campbell, Petersburg, 22 February [1841].

scopecontent.p: Sorry to hear of Charles' illness; invites him to Shirley. Invites her for visit. Local news; news of her flowers, her reading. Regrets loss of her last child, born three months before.

did.unittitle: John H. Rice, Princeton, to Alexander S. Campbell, Petersburg, 1 April 1841.

scopecontent.p: Describes Mr. Green's law school. Social news.

did.unittitle: L[ewis] J. Cist,Cincinnati to [?], 19 April 1841.

scopecontent.p: Letter concerns autograph collecting.

did.unittitle: Theodore Foster, Agent for George Hunt, New York, to Charles Campbell, 6 May 1841.

scopecontent.p: With regard to periodicals Charles Campbell did not receive.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, Petersburg to [?], 12 May 1841.

scopecontent.p: The "Athenaeum" has received no books since March 24. Asks that those arrears be sent.

did.unittitle: W[illiam] A. Caruthers,Savannah to [Charles Campbell], 25 May 1841.

scopecontent.p: Asks him for details of colonial Virginia law: he is at a critical juncture in his novel and needs the information promptly. Asks for other details, in order to make his novel accurate.

did.unittitle: E[lizabeth] M. Henley,Chota, Tennessee to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 17 June [1841].

scopecontent.p: Family news. Mary [Henley]to Charles Campbell. Family news.

did.unittitle: Lewis J. Cist, Cincinnati to C[harles] Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 30 July 1841.

scopecontent.p: Letter concerns autograph collecting.

did.unittitle: Cha[rle]s Campbell, Petersburg, to Lewis J. Cist, Esq., 14 August 1841.

scopecontent.p: Discussion of autographs he owns, including Washington, Harrison, Jefferson, etc. Found a number in the Bland Papers.

did.unittitle: George B. Cary, Washington, to Charles Campbell, 8 September 1841.

scopecontent.p: Goode and Jones will present the resolutions from Sussex and Surry Counties, saw the President riding-he seems well.

did.unittitle: A[lexander] M[oore] Keller,Buzzard Roost [Alabama] to Charles [Campbell], 16 September 1841.
M[ary] K. Henley,Chota, E. Tennessee to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 9 November [1841].

scopecontent.p: Family news.

did.unittitle: N. G. Taylor, Elizabethton, Tennessee to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 11 November 1841.
Ch. Campbell, Petersburg, to Col. Wm. Gooch. Col. Gooch's son , editor of the New York Evening Mail, had to abandon paper because of lack of subscriptions, 11 November 1841.

scopecontent.p: Campbell proposed that the son and he co-edit the Statesman.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. Carter,Shirley to Mrs. M[ildred] W. Campbell,Petersburg, 11 November 1841.

scopecontent.p: She is ill: perhaps inflammation of kidneys. Will send Spanish Chestnuts soon.

did.unittitle: Sam[ue]l O. Campbell,Natural Bridge, Virginia to [Charles Campbell], 17 November 1841.
A[lexander] S. Campbell,Fredericksburg to Mrs. [Mildred W.] Campbell,Petersburg, 18 November 1841.

scopecontent.p: News of his boarding accommodations. Description of his room, removed from those of other law students.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg, to Thomas May, 3 December 1841.

scopecontent.p: Letter pertains to sale of The Statesman: Lists briefly debts and assets of the paper.

did.unittitle: Alex[ander] S. Campbell,Fredericksburg, to Charles Campbell, 22 December 1841.

scopecontent.p: Asks Charles' advice on a matter he must argue before moot court.

did.unittitle: W. O. Goode, Washington City, To [?], 31 December 1841.
