scopecontent.p: Confidential letter; parties are at a "Stand Still"; fears that movements of Presidential aspirants may destroy his hopes.

did.unittitle:
Letters,
1842.
Abby J. Champion, St. Croix to Anna Burdsall, Montgomery, Alabama, 1 January 1842.

scopecontent.p: Her Brother died; life in St. Croix.

did.unittitle: W[illiam] A. Caruthers,Savannah to Charles Campbell, [Petersburg], 8 January 1842.

scopecontent.p: He has been encouraged to write a sequel to his Knights of the Horse-Shoe, and asks for anecdotes concerning characters in it.

did.unittitle: M[ary] Carter,Shirley to Mildred W. Campbell, Petersburg, 25 January 1842.

scopecontent.p: Asks her to visit and help her with her faith. Church news. Has had visitors and has been ill with nervous headaches.

did.unittitle: Mary Carter, Shirley to Mildred W. Campbell, Petersburg, 29 January 1842.

scopecontent.p:
Shocked at news of death of
[Pres. William Henry] Harrison. Has visited his family at Berkeley. Local news: attack of measles.

did.unittitle: George B. Cary, House of Representatives, to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 2 February 1842.

scopecontent.p: Discussion of newspapers, "House now engaged in this miserable affair of John Q. Adams."

did.unittitle: [Alexander S. Campbell] Fredericksburg, to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 8 February 1842.

scopecontent.p:
Has discovered a number of lectures written by Governor Spottswood. Reads
Statesmenregularly; thinks Charles was right in enlarging it. Has been debating question of Texas into Union.

did.unittitle: George B. Cary, Washington, to Charles Campbell, 12 February 1842.

scopecontent.p: Discussion of the currency House "diligently at work," reference to House as "noisy" and "disorderly" Hall.

did.unittitle: George B. Cary, Washington, to Charles Campbell, 24 February 1842.

scopecontent.p: Campbell's recommendation of Banister as Postmaster in Petersburg; death of Lewis Williams of North Carolina; Cary has no influence with "Heads of the departments" or the President.

did.unittitle: W. McPheeters, Raleigh, to James E. McPheeters, Petersburg, Virginia, 24 February 1842.

scopecontent.p: Asks for data on Moore and Aylett families.

did.unittitle: W[illiam] A. Carruthers,Savannah to [Charles Campbell, Petersburg], 26 February 1842.

scopecontent.p: Inquires into how Campbell is descended from Gov. Alexander Spotswood. Asks for genealogical tree and personal recollections.

did.unittitle: George B. Cary, House of Representatives, to Charles Campbell, 28 February 1842.

scopecontent.p: House now voting upon petition "to dissolve this Union," mention of John Quincy Adams.

did.unittitle: Abby J. Champion, New York to Anna Burdsall, Mobile, Alabama, 24 March 1842.

scopecontent.p: Her brother and his two children died in St. Croix; Describes people she knew in St. Croix.

did.unittitle: A[lexander] S. Campbell,[Fredericksburg] to [John W. Campbell, Petersburg], 26 March 1842.

scopecontent.p: He has enjoyed his study of law greatly. Will return home within one week.

did.unittitle: Arthur H[azelrigg] Henley,Chota, [Tennessee] to Charles Campbell, 29 April 1842.

scopecontent.p: Custody of Charles Campbell's son; family news.

did.unittitle: John W. Syme, A. S. Smith, and K. B. Parker, [Petersburg], 21 June 1842.

scopecontent.p: Invitation to celebration of first anniversary picnic of the Petersburg Guards.

did.unittitle: A[lexander] Campbell,Warrenton, to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, July 1842.

scopecontent.p: Made temperance speech on July 4. Authored a humorous poem under name of "Spikes," soon to be printed. Employment prospects not very good.

did.unittitle: Thomas W. Gilmer, Washington, to C[harles] Campbell, Petersburg, 14 July 1842.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for copy of the "Bland Papers"; hopes they will soon be published.

did.unittitle: George B. Cary, Washington, to Charles Campbell, 21 July 1842.

scopecontent.p: Letter in praise of Edmund Burke of New Hampshire and is enclosing speech.

did.unittitle: Jacob Nollner, Washington City, to Charles Campbell, 22 July 1842.

scopecontent.p: Must follow strictest economy. Therefore is ending the subscription to Charles Campbell's paper.

did.unittitle: W[illiam] A. Caruthers,Savannah, to Charles Campbell, [Petersburg], 22 July 1842.

scopecontent.p: Asks for a copy of the Westover Manuscripts. Also asks there he can obtain a copy of the Statutes at Large.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg, to Thomas Ritchie, Jr., Richmond, 14 August 1842.

scopecontent.p: Received Thomas Ritchie, Jr.'s letter as was leaving for Appomattox coal pits. Published manuscript of George Mason which was in Bland Papers. Quotes Thomas Jefferson on George Mason. Would like Thomas Ritchie, Jr.' aid in completing publication of Bland Papers. Needs $100-200. Would like Thomas Ritchie, Jr. to read manuscript. Important events: [Webster]-Ashburton Treaty [settling the northeastern boundary], the veto, and elections.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg, to Mr. [?] Smith, Washington, D.C., 14 August 1842.

scopecontent.p: Received Smith's request that Charles Campbell write The Statesman. Charles Campbell would be glad to comply if times were better, but the poor patronage and pressures of time forbid it. At work for the benefit of the printer with no profit himself, pleased if can keep out of debt. Fond of editorial business, but at present "unpropitious" and if continues many papers will fold.

did.unittitle: [Alexander Campbell], Warrenton, to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 2 September 1842.

scopecontent.p: Describes his involvement in slander suit. Prospects for a job as good there as anywhere in the state. Asks him to send newspapers containing his article on Virginia.

did.unittitle: Ar[thur] H[azelrigg] Henley,Chota, [Tennessee], to Charles Campbell, Petersburg., Virginia, 25 September 1842.

scopecontent.p:
Encloses an account of Charles Campbell's son's estate; Mr. Williams making temperance speeches "which seems to be the fashion."
Letter also includes the Callaway's account of Charles Campbell's son's estate.

did.unittitle: [Alexander S. Campbell], Warrenton, to [John W. Campbell], [Petersburg], 18 November 1842.

scopecontent.p: Social news. Has got all the law books he wants. News that Whigs are defeated and that next congress will be Democratic.

did.unittitle: W. W. Poole, Charleston, South Carolina, to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 5 December 1842.

scopecontent.p: Saw Charles Campbell's offer to sell The Statesman. Poole was editor and proprietor of the City Gazetteof Charleston until 1833 when retired. Joined the military, until recently ordered to remote station in the Southwest-resigned. Would best get on in Democratic Virginia. Wishes to know conditions of office. Name lowest terms. What do people of Petersburg think of Calhoun's bid for Presidency?

did.unittitle: D. Howard, Washington, to C[harles] Campbell, 6 December 1842.

scopecontent.p: Thanks for the numbers of The Statesman, one containing notice of sale of establishment. Disappointed in the income of the paper. Heard of a daily establishment in the Northwest.

did.unittitle: Scott Burdsall, Owego, New York to Anna Burdsall, Rahway, New Jersey, 22 December 1842.

scopecontent.p: Goes sleigh riding.

did.unittitle: C[harles] [Campbell], Petersburg to Ge[orge] B. Carey [Cary],Washington, 30 December 1842.

scopecontent.p: Wishes to recommend the post of collector to Hugh Nelson. He himself would like the position of clerkship.

did.unittitle:
Letters,
1843.
[Charles Campbell], to "Cousin," [c. 1843].

scopecontent.p: Aleck plans to marry; sister Betty had another child; his mother teaching; he is working at the custom house.

did.unittitle: Alexander S. Campbell to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 26 January 1843.

scopecontent.p: Has left check for public money with Mr. Maben. Postscript: E[lizabeth] M. M[aben]to Charles [Campbell] and to [Mildred Campbell]. All well and enjoying good weather.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell to Alex[ander] A. Campbell,28 January 1843.

scopecontent.p: Mr. Nelson has written Secretary of Treasury concerning his checques. Awaiting instruction.

did.unittitle: John Maben, Richmond to [?], 30 January 1843.

scopecontent.p: Brother left recently; letter arrived after he was gone.

did.unittitle: A[lexander] M[oore] Keller,Tuscumbia, [Louisiana] to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 1 February 1843.

scopecontent.p: Sympathy on death of Charles' father; family planning to move west; asks about Mr. Sutton and the revolutionary claims. Mary F[airfax] Kellerto sister [Mildred Campbell]. Sympathy note; family news of other brothers and sisters.

did.unittitle: Ar[thur] H[azelrigg] Henley,Chota, [Tennessee] to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 3 February 1843.

scopecontent.p: Sympathy at death of Charles Campbell's father; Charles Campbell's son's estate; family news.

did.unittitle: [Alexander S. Campbell], Warrenton to Charles [Campbell], 11 February 1843.

scopecontent.p: Asks information on settling accounts as soon as possible. Job prospects soon.

did.unittitle: Kate [Beckwith],Raleigh, [North Carolina], to Anna Burdsall, Rahway, New Jersey, 12 February 1843.

scopecontent.p: Is spring; has gone to 16 parties; John Manly is courting her, but her parents against it.

did.unittitle: [Alexander S. Campbell], Warrenton, to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 20 February 1843.

scopecontent.p: Legal matters relating to Parker's estate. Although job prospects remain poor, he has given up thought of sailing with Captain Cocke as clerk.

did.unittitle: Ar[thur] H[azelrigg] Henley,Chota, [Tennessee], to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 28 February 1843.

scopecontent.p: Charles Campbell's son's estate; Great scarcity of money; Family news.

did.unittitle: Alex[ander] S. Campbell,Warrenton, to Charles [Campbell], 21 March 1843.

scopecontent.p: Sends note, giving his attorney to Charles, in matters relating to the estate of John W. Campbell.

did.unittitle: A[lexander] S. Campbell,Warrenton, to Charles [Campbell], [Petersburg], 25 March 1843.

scopecontent.p: It would be very inconvenient for him to go to Petersburg: court session about to begin.

did.unittitle: Jared Sparks, Cambridge, Massachusetts to Charles Campbell, 18 April 1843.

scopecontent.p: Asks him to send a copy of the Bland Paperswhich he has been unable to find in Boston. Also request a copy of the Westover Manuscripts,edited by Edmund Ruffin.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to Mary B. Carter, Shirley, 23 April 1843.

scopecontent.p: Sends her son "antiquarian collections." Enjoyed his visit to Shirley.

did.unittitle: Ar[thur] H[azelrigg] Henley,Madisonville, to Charles Campbell, 8 May 1843.

scopecontent.p: Difficult to get money, therefore slow in remittances.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. C[arter],Shirley, to M[ildred] W. Campbell,Petersburg, 19 May 1843.

scopecontent.p: Her china arrived, and she will send money for it soon. She is feeling better, although she still suffers occasionally from headaches. Family news.

did.unittitle: M[ary B.] C[arter]to M[ildred W.] Campbell,Petersburg, [After 19 May 1843].

scopecontent.p: Encloses list of her china, including worth of pieces. Other miscellaneous items. Asks her for accounting of other expenses made on her behalf. Encloses check for $31.50, which she hopes settles everything.

did.unittitle: [Jared Sparks], Cambridge, Massachusetts to Charles Campbell, 20 May 1843.

scopecontent.p: Acknowledges receipt of first volume of the Bland Papers. Declares them to be more valuable than he had anticipated. Also expresses thanks to Edmund Ruffin for the Westover Manuscripts.

did.unittitle: Betty [Elizabeth M. Henley], Chota, Tennessee to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 29 May 1843.

scopecontent.p: Has called off her wedding; Lavina Moore has not yet gotten a divorce; Mr. Barclay McGhee has been committed to a lunatic asylum; Family news.

did.unittitle: Henry Barnard, Hartford, Connecticut to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 30 May 1843.

scopecontent.p: Offers his assistance in binding his book, and gives advice on how to set a price for it. Gives news of friends.

did.unittitle: L. Wallazz Philadelphia, to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 31 May 1843.

scopecontent.p: Amusing description of presenting Charles Campbell's letter to Mr. Grigg who said he would act on the matter at a "convenient season." Would promote sale of Bland Papers. Humiliating confession of poverty is fashionable. Will begin printing shop on credit. Mesmerism and Millerism growing Mormonism stationary. Theatres.

did.unittitle: Announcement for Henry Howe's Historical Collections of Virginia,10 June 1843.
Charles Campbell Petersburg, Virginia to Cha[rle]s Hosmer, Connecticut Historical Society, 12 June 1843.

scopecontent.p: Accepts honorary membership in Connecticut Historical Society.

did.unittitle: J. M. Randolph, Richmond to C[harles] Campbell, 19 June 1843.

scopecontent.p: Letter of introduction for Henry How.

did.unittitle: W. C. Banister, Petersburg to Charles Campbell, 24 June 1843.

scopecontent.p: Will not recommend Charles Campbell as his successor.

did.unittitle: [Henry Howe?], Midlothian to Cha[rle]s Campbell, Petersburg, 14 July 1843.

scopecontent.p: Will be traveling in eastern and western Virginia; hopes to meet him in the winter. Sends him some drawings, including a sketch of Bacon's Castle.

did.unittitle: L. Wallazz, Philadelphia, to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 30 July 1843.

scopecontent.p: Actions of Connecticut Historical Society pleasing. Regret that ignorance of Charles Campbell's deserts deprives him of similar favor in Virginia. Little acquaintance with booksellers, now in type and steroetype establishment, but will try to promote Bland Papers. Have met John F. Watson, antiquarian and author of Annals of Philadelphia, much like Charles Campbell. Will bring out 3rd ed. of Annals. Financial matters of Mr. Ruffin. Unable to dispose of type. Confused paper money Penn. Politicians emphasize "principle," "patriotism," etc., but none in actions.

did.unittitle: John Tyler, Washington to Ch[arle]s Campbell, 27 August 1843.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for the Bland Papers. Comments about historical materials of the Revolution.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to "my dear cousin," 28 August 1843.

scopecontent.p: Received letter from President Tyler marking Charles Campbell for book. Family news, engaged to be married to a young lady at school with a decent fortune. Social news.

did.unittitle: A. P. Upshur, Washington to Charles Campbell, Petersburg. 8 September 1843.

scopecontent.p: Acknowledges receipt of the Bland Papers, one copy for himself, one for the Library of Congress.

did.unittitle: Lucy D. Henry, Cub Creek, Charlotte, Virginia to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 11 September 1843.

scopecontent.p: Enjoyed reading his articles; poem, Lines in Honor of a ____ Patriot.

did.unittitle: [Jared Sparkes], Cambridge, Massachusetts to Charles Campbell, 12 September 1843.

scopecontent.p: Acknowledges receipt of the Bland Papersand praises their usefulness. Expresses regret that they have not sold as many copies as expected.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg, to B[enjamin] B. Minor,Richmond, 13 September 1843.

scopecontent.p: Points out several typographical errors in the September 1843 edition of the Southern Literary Messenger.Is sending some "scraps" for inclusion in the Messenger, under the title of "Virginia Antiquities." Suggests changing title of that column to "Old Mortalities." Asks for reprints of articles of his that have appeared in the Messengerso he will not have to cut them out himself.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia to Dolly [Lucy] D. Henry,26 September 1843.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, Petersburg to J. K. Tefft, Savannah, 23 March 1844.

did.unittitle: J. K. Tefft, Savannah to Cha[rle]s Campbell, Petersburg, 30 March 1844.

scopecontent.p: Lists those letters and autographs he would appreciate having.

did.unittitle: Charles [Campbell], Petersburg, Virginia to Mary K. Henley, Chota, Tennessee, 2 April 1844.

did.unittitle: L. Wallazz, Philadelphia, to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 2 May 1844.

scopecontent.p: Can't sell printing material, so is setting up shop, but poor until gets work. Now needs what sold, and didn't get the money. Hopes can get material back for non-payment, will Charles Campbell inquire? E. C. Biddle preparing to resign as director, will see him about how Bland is selling. Friends at Malbourne well, enjoying beautiful new home, but Charles Campbell must philosophize with friend not to overwork. Democrats would carry an election because Whigs all at Baltimore convention. Financially strapped, but doesn't want the people of Petersburg to know it.

did.unittitle: Ar[thur] H[azelrigg] [Henley],Chota, [Tennessee] to Charles Campbell, 4 May 1844.

scopecontent.p: Apologizes for delay in remittances.

scopecontent.p: Thanks her for her information.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia to Preston Trotter, Brownsburg, Virginia, 18 June 1844.

scopecontent.p: Sends notes on Campbell family genealogy.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. Carter,Shirley to M[ildred] W. Campbell,Petersburg, 9 July 1844.

scopecontent.p: Invites her down; There is little sickness there. Religious, church news.

did.unittitle: A[lexander] S. Campbell,Warrenton, to Charles Campbell, Richmond, 15 July [1844].

scopecontent.p: Surprised to hear he was in Richmond, but thinks he will do well at the Customs House. Happily married now. Gave political speech. Postscript: Morly [Homer Campbell]to [Charles Campbell]. Has found a widow for Charles Campbell to marry. Invites him for a visit.

did.unittitle: [Mrs. Mildred W. Campbell], Petersburg to Charles [Campbell], 20 July 1844.

scopecontent.p: Informing him of her sending him a trunk. Postscript: Callaway Campbell, Petersburg to [Charles Campbell] his father. News of his hen.

did.unittitle: Thomas C. Reynolds, Petersburg, to [Charles Campbell], 22 July 1844.

scopecontent.p: Excuses delay in answering Charles Campbell's letter of the 12th. Hopes for help from Charles Campbell-articles. Thanks for back issues of the Statesman. Agrees with Charles Campbell's wish for less asperity in political dissensions. Reynolds has been unsparing in his editorials. Would like to be milder if policy and opponents would allow.
Haunted room at Ampthill; Describes tobacco warehouse.

did.unittitle: [Mrs. Mildred W. Campbell], Shirley to Charles [Campbell], 8 August 1844.

scopecontent.p: News of her trip to Shirley with Callaway Campbell and cousin Philip Aglett.

did.unittitle: Thomas C. Reynolds, Petersburg to Charles Campbell, Richmond, 13 August 1844.

scopecontent.p: Received Charles Campbell's letter of the 10th. Undisposed to get into a contest with the Richmond Whig which has the advantage of wider circulation. Reynolds' first attack, abolition proceeding which might have placed disunionist Whig on defensive, were given no notice by democratic papers. Whig said no word on the proceedings. Will issue weekly paper at low price for Virginia and North Carolina to force respect from "big" papers. Requests written communication for the Republican. Should see several men about establishing Antiquarian Society.

did.unittitle: A[lexander] S. Campbell,Warrenton to Charles Campbell, Richmond, 9 September 1844.

scopecontent.p: He and Molly were disappointed at not seeing him this summer. He attended tournament at the Springs, heard address by Judge B[everly] Tucker. Losing interest in politics.

did.unittitle: Anna Bland Dudley, [Tennessee] to [Charles Campbell], 14 September 1844.

scopecontent.p: Is sending manuscript of the war in the Carolinas for publication; is moving to Louisiana.

did.unittitle: Henry Howe, New Haven, Connecticut to Cha[rle]s Campbell, Petersburg, 14 September 1844.
[Charles Campbell], Petersburg to Henry Howe, [New Haven, Connecticut], 29 September 1844.

scopecontent.p: Makes corrections in his memoir of John Randolph.

did.unittitle: Cha[rle]s Campbell, Richmond, [Virginia] to Anna B. Dudley, 14 October 1844.

scopecontent.p: Has received her manuscript and part is missing; suggests publication in Southern Literary Messenger.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. [Carter],Shirley to Mildred W. Campbell, Petersburg, 15 October 1844.

scopecontent.p: Hopes [her son] Charles [Carter]is doing well with his studies. Will send money for him. Charles Campbell has given her a copy of his book.

did.unittitle: Alex[ander] S. Campbell,Warrenton to Charles [Campbell], November 1844.

scopecontent.p: Business matters still referring to settling of father's estate. Will pay Charles all he owes him.

did.unittitle: Henry Howe, New Haven to Cha[rle]s Campbell, Richmond, Virginia, 6 November 1844.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for Randolph portrait; experts to get his work published soon.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Richmond to Henry Howe, [New Haven, Connecticut], 15 November 1844.

scopecontent.p: Will endeavor to send the information on recent political history he asked for. He is glad James K. Polk has been elected, even though he feels sorry for Henry Clay, and his Whig friends.

did.unittitle: Henry Howe, New Haven, Connecticut to Cha[rle]s Campbell, Richmond, 20 November 1844.

scopecontent.p: He has already received the requested information on recent Virginia political history from another source. As a Whig, he is sorry that Polk has defeated Clay, but is not discouraged.

did.unittitle: Edmund Ruffin, Marlbourne, to [Charles Campbell][?], 20 November 1844.

scopecontent.p: Pertains to an intended visit of Campbell to Ruffin. Mentions defeat of Henry Clay.

did.unittitle: W[illia]m Spotswood Fontaine,to Charles Campbell [Richmond, Virginia], 21 November 1844.

scopecontent.p: Asks for papers to read before their trip to Gloucester.

did.unittitle: Thomas C. Reynolds, Richmond, to [Charles Campbell], 24 November 1844.

scopecontent.p: Reynolds no longer edits the Republican. Returned to Richmond and attends to practice. No time for paper which Charles Campbell suggests, doubts would be successful alongside The Messenger. Would be willing to cultivate Charles Campbell's acquaintance.

did.unittitle: Edmund Ruffin, Marlbourne, to [Charles Campbell], 16 December 1844.

scopecontent.p: Travel arrangements for Campbell to join the Ruffins for Christmas.

did.unittitle: H. A. Garland, by S. Garland, Jr., Petersburg, [Virginia] to Charles Campbell, Richmond, [Virginia], 21 December 1844.

did.unittitle: M[ildred] W. C[ampbell]to Charles [Campbell], [1845].

scopecontent.p: News of Callaway; he will not go to Tennessee. Journey to Warrenton upcoming: herself, Betty, and Callaway. Spoke with someone who tried but failed to get a copy of his Historyin Richmond.

did.unittitle: Alex[ander] S. Campbell,Warrenton to Charles [Campbell], 6 January 1845.

scopecontent.p: Has been busy settling small farm. Asks him to inquire into the estate of Col. William Aylett for anything which might be due them.

scopecontent.p: Sympathy letter on death of Arthur Hazelrigg Henley 's daughter Elizabeth; news of Charles Campbell's son; family news.

did.unittitle: Cha[rle]s Campbell, Richmond, Virginia to Henry Howe, 11 February 1845.

did.unittitle: M[ildred] W. Campbell,Petersburg to Charles [Campbell], 13 February 1845.

scopecontent.p: Asking him to come home. Financial difficulties. Postscript: C[allaway] Campbellto [Charles Campbell]. News of his hen and his school work.

did.unittitle: J[ohn] Minor,Fredericksburg, to CH. Campbell, 23 March 1845.

scopecontent.p: Minor vividly evaluates the works on Virginia history already done. Burr's history treated in very lively fashion. Argues that Americans are thoughtless, vapid, and follow bad examples. Critical of American misuse of language. Argued for an objective style of history. Very colorful letter.

did.unittitle: W[illia]m Plumer,Richmond to [Charles Campbell, Petersburg], 2 April 1845.

scopecontent.p: He will approach Drinker and Morris for him but is not optimistic about their publishing the History of Virginia.Thinks the proposed appendix on the Indian wars a good idea.

did.unittitle: E. A. Dalrymple, Farmington, Virginia, to [Charles Campbell], 4 April 1845.

did.unittitle: [Alexander S. Campbell] to Charles [Campbell], 15 April 1845.

did.unittitle: Henry Howe, Richmond to Cha[rle]s Campbell, Richmond, 20 April 1845.

scopecontent.p: His book Historical Collections of Virginiahas been published; he describes his references to Campbell's work in it. Sends him a copy of it; hopes he will point out errors in it. Will leave soon for trip to either Ohio or South Carolina.

did.unittitle: Henry Howe, New Haven, Connecticut to Cha[rle]s Campbell, Richmond, 3 May 1845.

scopecontent.p: His publisher has decided to postpone a book on South Carolina, so he will not be traveling there. Plans to go to Ohio for about two years in order to assemble historical, collections there, even though he does not enjoy traveling.

did.unittitle: H. A. G[arland],Washington, to [Charles Campbell?], 10 May 1845.

scopecontent.p: The president told H. A. Garland that the commission would be issued that day.

did.unittitle: H. A. G[arland],Washington to [Charles Campbell ?], 10 May 1845.

scopecontent.p: Urging the recipient to put in his claim.

did.unittitle: Kate [Beckwith],Petersburg, Virginia to Anna Burdsall, Rahway, New Jersey, 22 May [c. 1845-1848].

scopecontent.p: Asks Alexander to inquire of reputable New York publisher if any of them are interested in publishing his History of Virginia(Tales from the History of Virginia): 600 pages in manuscript.

scopecontent.p: Discussion of forthcoming publication of History of Virginia. Maybe publish in Virginia instead of New York? Publish anonymously to promote sales?

W[illia]m[s]bu[r]gto Charles Campbell, 9 July 1845.

scopecontent.p: Sends tombstone inscription of Elizabeth Bacon.

did.unittitle:
C[harles Campbell], Petersburg, [Virginia] to
W[illia]m S[potswood] Fontaine,21 July 1845.

scopecontent.p: Would like to have his daguerreotype; is working in the Custom House; has done little with The History of Virginia; asks about diggings in the Indian mounds.

did.unittitle: Charles Yancey, Wetumpka, Alabama, to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 27 July 1845.

Heard Charles Campbell worked with Bland Papers, on the antiquities of Virginia. Would like to have the publication of them in serial or book form. Has established bindery and printing office. Knows Charles Campbell would like to publish tales of Virginia; Charles Yancey would do that also. Charles Yancy is son of Francis G. Yancey, editor of the Intelligencies, a native of Petersburg.

did.unittitle: [William A. Caruthers], Savannah to Charles Campbell, 27 July 1845.

scopecontent.p: Has arranged to have The Knights of the Horse-Shoepublished in book form. Is sorry to see that Edgar Allan Poe is again working for the Southern Literary Messenger. Has proposed him as an honorary member of the Georgia Historical Society; tells him of its activities.

did.unittitle: James W. Alexander, New York to [Charles Campbell, Petersburg], 30 July 1845.

scopecontent.p: Is leaving town until September 1 and therefore will not be able to approach publishing houses for him until then. Thinks Harpers would be more likely to publish the History of Virginiathan Wiley and Putnam.

did.unittitle: [?], Richmond, to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 2 August 1845.

scopecontent.p: Invites him to Richmond.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell; Petersburg, to Charles Yancey, Wetumpka, Alabama, 4 August 1845.

scopecontent.p: If finds anything suitable, will send it for Charles Yamcey's meditated magazine. Northern advantages in book-making and selling, down to a science. No literary periodical can sustain itself without paying contributors.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to P[eter] V. Daniel,Jr., [Richmond], 4 August 1845.

scopecontent.p: Asks to be excused from a social engagement, because he is working full-time as a collector of customs at Petersburg. Hopes to come to Richmond soon to talk with him.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to W. F. Watson, 19 August 1845.

scopecontent.p: W. F. Watson's letter so unreadable that Charles Campbell believes he has adopted Gliddon's hieroglyphics, only use of handwriting is to obscure meaning. Does excite the curiosity and imagination.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell][?], Petersburg to [Mildred W. Campbell] [?], [Warrenton, Virginia][?], 25 August 1845.

scopecontent.p: Alexander's disillusionment with farming. News of Petersburg.

did.unittitle: James W. Alexander, [New York] to [Charles Campbell], [Petersburg], 16 September 1845.

scopecontent.p: Alexander explained terms by which Wiley and Putnam would examine and perhaps publish Campbell's books.

did.unittitle: Kate [Beckwith],Petersburg, [Virginia] to Anna Burdsall, Rahway, New Jersey, 24 September 1845.

scopecontent.p: Has moved to Virginia; her former fiance, Robert Moore, is dead; thinks she will not marry.

did.unittitle: Ar[thur] H[azelrigg] Henley,Maryville to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 6 October 1845.

scopecontent.p: Encloses $85 for care of his land.

did.unittitle: Certificate of honorary membership for Charles Campbell in the Georgia Historical Society, 13 October 1845.

scopecontent.p: Acknowledges and accepts his honorary membership in the Georgia Historical Society.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell] Petersburg to [Alexander S. Campbell], [Warrenton], 1 November 1845.

scopecontent.p: Has been leading very monotonous life. Farming news.

did.unittitle: John R. Thompson, Richmond to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 3 November 1845.

He gives Campbell a list (including Richard Bland, Patrick Henry, George Wythe and others), asking if he has any of these that he could have.

did.unittitle: A[lexander] S[potswood] Moore,Glencoe, Alabama to Mildred W[alker] Campbell,Petersburg, Virginia, 4 November 1845.

scopecontent.p: Hired Francis V. Sutton to try to get Alexander Moore's Revolutionary War pension, but Sutton has apparently done nothing, asks Charles Campbell to help; family news.

did.unittitle: John Lyon, Petersburg to Cha[rle]s Campbell, [Petersburg], 4 November 1845.

scopecontent.p: Asks that he not resign as a member and as President of the Young Men's Literary Society of Petersburg. Conveys resolutions of the society to this effect.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. C[arter],Shirley to Mildred W. Campbell, Petersburg, 7 November 1845.

scopecontent.p: Family news. She is in good spirits. Her son Will has bought Berkeley plantation.

did.unittitle: [Alexander S. Campbell], Warrenton, to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 8 November 1845.

scopecontent.p: Asks a little longer before repayment of debt. Social and family news.

did.unittitle: P[eter] V. Daniel, Jr.,Richmond to [Charles] Campbell, Petersburg, 15 November 1845.

scopecontent.p: Has just returned from King William, and speaks of many of Campbell's friends there. Hopes to see him there at the end of next week.

did.unittitle: Henry Howe, New Haven, Connecticut to Cha[rle]s Campbell, Petersburg, 19 November 1845.

scopecontent.p: Letter of introduction of George Durin, a portrait painter. Will leave very shortly for Ohio, where he hopes to assemble a book of historical collections, even though the Virginia Historical Collectionsvolume is not selling well.

did.unittitle: Sally R. Campbell, Ann Smith Academy, to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 12 December 1845.
[Charles Campbell], Petersburg, [Virginia] to [Sall]y Campbell,Lexington, Virginia, 17 December 1845.

scopecontent.p: Sorry she is moving away; his mother has a house; has an office in the Custom House which "gives me ample leisure for my literary projects"; brother Aleck married.

did.unittitle: Rev. William S. Plumer, Richmond to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 29 December 1845.

scopecontent.p: Received Charles Campbell's letter of the 26th. 1. Doesn't know address of Rev. J. W. Alexander. 2. Doesn't think war panic will have any effect, that it is dying away. 3. Almost any wholesale merchant, could send on Charles Campbell's manuscript to New York. 4. Doesn't know whether Charles Campbell should go to New York or send his manuscript. Do best work yourself, sell manuscript if can. If will write about a kingdom that can't be moved, will answer.

did.unittitle:
Letters,
1846.

scopecontent.p: Hopes to be in Richmond soon. Says his life is "as monotonous as a canal-boat."

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. Carter,Shirley to Mrs. [Mildred W.] Campbell,Petersburg, 20 January 1846.

scopecontent.p: She is still ill and in low spirits. Wishes to see her.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to Jared Sparks, [Cambridge, Massachusetts], 2 February 1846.

scopecontent.p: Glad to know he has enjoyed the Bland Papers. Sends some autographs. Has finished his work on the history of Virginia and looks to have it published.

scopecontent.p: Asks if there was an Historical Society in Virginia

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg,[Virginia] to Sam[ue]l D. Campbell,20 February 1846.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for a copy of the Bland Papers. His publisher is asking for stories, and so he asks Campbell for some anecdotes of Virginia's past. Has heard that his History of Virginiais being published.

did.unittitle: Sam[ue]l D. Campbell,Natural Bridge, Virginia to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 4 March 1846.

scopecontent.p: Sent copies of fathers manuscripts; family genealogy information; brother William is editing a newspaper; William is member of the state convention in Missouri; Sally moving to Missouri.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. Carter,Richmond to Mildred Campbell, Petersburg, 4 March [1846].

scopecontent.p: Is visiting in Richmond but did not see "little Wellwood," because he had scarlet fever. Fear of transmitting it to Shirley. Asks her to come at Easter and to bring Charles, his wife and Callaway.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to William A. Caruthers, Savannah, 11 March 1846.

scopecontent.p: Suggests an anecdote about the dealings between Blackbeard the pirate and the Governor of North Carolina as material for a story. Tells of his difficulties in finding a publisher for the History of Virginia.Gives news of his family.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. C[arter],Shirley, to Mildred W. Campbell, Petersburg, 12 March 1846.

scopecontent.p: Family news. Expresses strong religious sentiments; disappointment over lack of spiritual interest in her husband's son.

did.unittitle: [Elliot] M.[Braxton],Rich[mon]dto Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 13 March 1846.

scopecontent.p: Has been saved from suicide but is still depressed.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg, to E. [Elliot] M. Braxton,16 March 1846.

scopecontent.p: Tries to cheer him up.

did.unittitle: W[illiam] B. Sprague,Albany to [Charles Campbell], 26 March 1846.

scopecontent.p: Letter concerns autograph collecting.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. Carter,Shirley to Mildred W. Campbell, Petersburg, 30 March 1846.

scopecontent.p: Has been to Richmond; has met Betty [Campbell Mabin]. Will write for manuscript Charles [Campbell] wants if he will come and explain the matter to her.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to James E. Heath, [Richmond], 31 March 1846.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for reading his manuscript [ History of Virginia] which has now been submitted to Drinker and Morris. He is thinking of adding to it a history of the Indian wars written by an uncle, which manuscript he send Heath for review. Expresses hope for founding a new historical society for Virginia since even Rhode Island has one.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg, Virginia to [?], 2 April 1846.

scopecontent.p: Letter concerns autograph collecting.

did.unittitle: R. R. Howison, Richmond to Charles Campbell, [Petersburg], 2 April 1846.

scopecontent.p: Introduces himself. He is researching in the history of Virginia and would appreciate the chance to look at his [Campbell's] manuscript. Encourages him to have the work published.

did.unittitle: Sam[ue]l D. Campbell,Natural Bridge, Virginia to [Charles Campbell], 3 April 1846.

scopecontent.p: May use his father's manuscripts.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to R. R. Howison, Richmond, 3 April 1846.

scopecontent.p: Offers to help him with information on Virginia history.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to Alex[ander] S. Campbell,Warrenton, 5 April 1846.

scopecontent.p: Work at Custom House has been slow but is picking up. Has been attending temperance meetings. Cousin Sam Campbell has sent him a manuscript history of the Indian wars in Western Virginia, which he will use as appendix to his own history.

did.unittitle: Lyman C. Draper, Baltimore to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 7 April 1846.

scopecontent.p: Requests information on descendants of Revolutionary figures he is researching. Has not yet acquired a copy of the Bland Papers. Is glad to hear of Campbell's work on Virginia, hopes himself to do some on Western Virginia.

did.unittitle: W[illiam] B. Sprague,Albany, [New York] to Charles Campbell, 9 April 1846.

scopecontent.p: Letter concerns autograph collecting.

did.unittitle: Kate B[eckwith],Petersburg, [Virginia] to Anna Burdsall, Poughkeepsie, New York, 9 April 1846.
Ja[me]s E. Heath,Richmond to [Charles Campbell],[Petersburg], 9 April 1846.

scopecontent.p: Has talked with Drinker and Morris, who will, he is certain, publish Campbell's manuscript [ History of Virginia]. Hopes Campbell has not changed it for "adaptation to schools." Is not hopeful for the founding of an Historical Society in Richmond: thinks it would soon languish for want of money, interest, and material.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to Lyman C. Draper, 10 April 1846.

scopecontent.p: Regrets he is unable to provide requested information on certain historical figures, but suggests names of those who might be of assistance. Sends him a copy of the Bland Papers. Tells him of his work on the history of Virginia, and encourages him to investigate Western Virginia.

did.unittitle: J. K. Tefft, Savannah to Cha[rle]s Campbell, Petersburg, 10 April 1846.

scopecontent.p: Hopes that his membership certificate and books have not been lost en-route to him. Asks if he can acquire some manuscripts for him.

did.unittitle: A[lexander] S. Campbell,Warrenton, to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 11 April 1846.

scopecontent.p: Today was his militia's master day. Assembly election campaign hard-fought.

did.unittitle: R. R. Howison, Richmond to Charles Campbell, 14 April 1846.

scopecontent.p: Confident Charles Campbell's volume will be published in time for use before R. R. Howison's book is ready. Controversial issues in history of Virginia, Harvey, Protectorate, Bacon. Finds Charles Campbell's father's volume on Virginia helpful (as did Bancroft) but disagrees with his view of Bacon. Would like use of Histories of Virginiaby Stitch and Keith; only in City Library; knows Charles Campbell owns them; could he borrow these rare books?

did.unittitle: H[enry] Barnard,Hartford, Connecticut to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 14 April 1846.

scopecontent.p: Tells him of the disposition of the Bland Papers. Looks forward to meeting him in New York. News of mutual friends.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia to Rev. [William B.] Sprague,Albany, New York, 15 April 1846.

scopecontent.p: Letter concerns autograph collecting.

did.unittitle: J. K. Tefft, Savannah to C[harles] Campbell, [Petersburg], 17 April 1846.

scopecontent.p: Acknowledges receipt of autographs. William A. Caruthers says anecdote Campbell sent him is not appropriate. Offers a Walter Scott autograph in exchange for a Robert Burns manuscript.

did.unittitle: [Rev. Dr. Sprague], Albany, to C[harle]s Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 21 April 1846.

scopecontent.p: Letter concerns autograph collecting.

did.unittitle: [A. Alexander Little], Richmond to [Charles] Campbell, Petersburg, 23 April 1846.

scopecontent.p: Richmond election. Won by Mayo by majority votes. Saw Tom Ritchie. Patrick Henry Society decided notice should be given; Congress seems undecided [subject not given].

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], to [A. Alexander Little], 30 April [1846].

scopecontent.p: Petersburg discussing the ship canal; other local news. Taking elocution lessons.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia to Rev. W[illia]m B. Sprague,[Albany], 4 May 1846.

scopecontent.p: Letter concerns autograph collecting.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell, Petersburg] to [George Bancroft], [Before: 5 May 1846].

scopecontent.p: Asks how to obtain manuscript of Gov. Alexander Spotswood mentioned in his History of U.S.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to George Bancroft, [Washington], 5 May 1846.

scopecontent.p: Asks him to write to a Mr. Featherstonehaugh, British consul at Le Havre, requesting some manuscripts of Gov. Alexander Spotswood in his possession.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell to Mary B. Carter, 5 May 1846.

scopecontent.p: Returns book she lent him. He has obtained an autograph of Gov. Spotswood, whom he calls "the ablest and best of our colonial governors."

did.unittitle: W[illiam] A. Caruthers,Savannah to Charles Campbell, [Petersburg], 5 May 1846.

scopecontent.p: Inquires into the connections of the Spotswood, Washington, and Dandridge families. Intends to write a sequel to the Knights of the Horse-Shoe. Asks what the reaction to it has been in Virginia.

did.unittitle: Lyman C. Draper, Baltimore to Ch[arle]s Campbell, Petersburg, 5 May 1846.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for copy of Bland Papersand praises their importance. Is glad to hear of forthcoming History.

did.unittitle: George Bancroft, Washington to Ch[arle]s Campbell, Petersburg, 8 May 1846.

scopecontent.p: He has tried before to get certain manuscripts of Gov. Spotswood from Mr. Featherstonehaugh, and says it is impossible.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. Carter,Shirley to Mildred W. Campbell, Petersburg, 9 May 1846.

scopecontent.p: Betty Campbell Maben]is at Shirley for a visit. Invites her for a visit. Longs for death.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to W[illia]m A. Caruthers,Savannah, 10 May 1846.

scopecontent.p: Refers him books which contain a genealogy of the Washington family. Gives outline sketch of his own connection with the Moore, Dandridge, and Spotswood families.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to Drinker and Morris, 11 May 1846.

scopecontent.p: Sends account of Pt. Pleasant campaign written by uncle. Dr. Samuel Campbell. Proposes to incorporate it with own manuscript, giving due credit.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg, [Virginia] to John D. Munford, Richmond, [Virginia], 21 May 1846.

scopecontent.p: Notes on Bland family and Munford family.

did.unittitle: [Rev.] William S. Plumer,Richmond to [Charles Campbell], 22 May 1846.

scopecontent.p: Seems fair that author and publisher should share risks of profit, if not less, but would prefer a net sum. Prime purpose is to place work before the public. Now is the time to collect and note occurrences with correct chronology. (refers to war of U.S. and Mexico penciled in Charles Campbell's hand). Check facts with Departments in Washington.

did.unittitle: L[ucy] D. Henry,Windston[?] to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 27 May 1846.
Drinker and Morrish, Richmond to [Charles Campbell], 4 June [18]46.

scopecontent.p: Declines publishing proposition, proposes that when it is fully prepared, will make an offer. Par of manuscript was elsewhere, so not immediately returned.

did.unittitle: Jared Sparks, Salem, Massachusetts to Charles Campbell, [Petersburg], 10 June 1846.

scopecontent.p: Advises him on how to make best possible financial arrangement with publishers. Says that Virginia should attempt to procure its colonial papers from England as Georgia and New York have done.

did.unittitle: Elliot M. Braxton, Richmond to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 12 June 1846.

scopecontent.p: Wishes Charles Campbell were there.

did.unittitle: Henry Barnard, Hartford, Connecticut to [Charles Campbell], [Petersburg], 14 June 1846.

scopecontent.p: Will be able to meet him in New York any time after the 4th of July. Recommends that Harpers publish his History of Virginia.

did.unittitle:
Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia to
Dolly [Lucy] D. Henry,Charlotte County, Virginia, 17 June 1846.

scopecontent.p: Would like to visit; visited Gloucester; "'Cupid's' arrows have so completely riddled my heart that there is hardly anything left to shoot at."

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to W[illia]m A. Caruthers,Savannah, 21 June 1846.

scopecontent.p: Gives further details of the genealogy of the Dandridge and Spotswood families. Sends a facsimile of an autograph of Gov. Alexander Spotswood.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to Henry Barnard, 26 June 1846.

scopecontent.p: Has presented his manuscript Historyto a Richmond publishing house but doesn't know if they will print it. If not, he will got to New York and try to have it published there. Briefly describes the work and his exertions in writing. Plans to go to New York about 18 July to discuss the matter with Harpers.

did.unittitle: J. K. Tefft, Savannah to C[harles] Campbell, Petersburg, 28 June 1846.

scopecontent.p: Acknowledges receipt of autographs. Informs him that William A. Caruthers has been quite sick; his recovery is doubtful.

did.unittitle: Lucy D. Henry, Windston, to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 29 June 1846.

scopecontent.p: Is anxious to meet him.

did.unittitle: P. R. Page, Richmond to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 29 June 1846.

scopecontent.p: Sends tomb inscriptions.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to Elliot M. Braxton, Richmond, 14 July 1846.

scopecontent.p: Has been unwell; is waiting for the "ship canal" to be finished; has been reading about the West; asks about his mental state.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. Carter,Shirley to Mildred Campbell, Petersburg, 15 July 1846.

scopecontent.p: Invites her for a visit when her school is finished. Longs for death. Family news.

did.unittitle: George Bancroft, Washington to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 16 July 1846.

scopecontent.p: Inquires as to when and where Richard Bland's Inquiry into the Rights of the British Colonieswas first published.

did.unittitle: John Howland and Thomas C. Hartshorn, Providence, Rhode Island to Charles Campbell, 22 July 1846.

scopecontent.p: Acknowledges gift of the Bland Papers.

did.unittitle: A[lexander] S. Campbell,Warrenton to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 22 July 1846.

scopecontent.p: Speaks of Callaway's proposed trip to Tennessee. He is tired of Warrenton and will move at first opportunity.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia to Mrs. Lucinda F. Lea, 25 July 1846.

scopecontent.p: Charles Campbell's son will visit Mrs. Lea in the summer.

did.unittitle: Lyman C. Draper, Baltimore to Ch[arle]s Campbell, [Petersburg], 29 July 1846.

scopecontent.p: Asks for the original of a letter in the Bland Papers.Inquires into content of Col. William Byrd's papers. He will leave in a few weeks for the West to gather more information and evidence.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to Lyman C. Draper, [Baltimore], 3 August 1846.

scopecontent.p: Encloses the requested document from the Bland Papers. Refers him to William B. Harrison of Brandon for information concerning Col. William Byrd. He is having difficulty finding a publisher for his History.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg, [Virginia] to Rev. Mr. Childs, 4 August 1846.

scopecontent.p: Would like to have account of Rhode Island Historical Society.

did.unittitle: Jas. E. Heath, Richmond to [?], 4 August 1846.

scopecontent.p: Unable to find a Bland pamphlet; fears the university plan for an historical society will fail because "the dry records of the past possess few attractions" for Virginians; Mr. Maxwell trying to revive the Virginia Historical Society.

did.unittitle: H[enry] Barnard,Hartford, Connecticut to [Charles Campbell], 5 August 1846.

scopecontent.p: Has spoken with the Harper Brothers about their publishing the History of Virginia. Asks him to let him know in advance when he will be coming. Has met John Moncure Daniel.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, [Petersburg] to Henry Barnard, [Hartford], 9 August 1846.

scopecontent.p: Now plans to go to New York in early October. Proposes to send the manuscript to him and let him negotiate with Harpers or any other house which will publish it.

did.unittitle: A[lexander] S. Campbell,Warrenton to Charles [Campbell], 16 August 1846.

scopecontent.p: Announces death of his young daughter Mary. Wife has been sick but is bearing loss well.

did.unittitle: Lyman C. Draper, Baltimore to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 25 August 1846.

scopecontent.p: Returns the original copy of a letter of Col. Andrew Lewis, of which he has made a copy. Leaves for the West on the 27th; is to spend six to eight weeks there. Offers to help him find a publisher.

did.unittitle: J[ohn] M. Daniel,Richmond to Cha[rle]s Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia. 28 August 1846.

scopecontent.p: Asks to borrow a book; is anxious to read Charles Campbell's History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to Harper Brothers, New York, 31 August 1846.

scopecontent.p: Letters from Mr. Barnard of Hartford suggest Charles Campbell send History of Virginiato Harper Brothers after speaking with them about it. Sends manuscript by private hand. Would like to personally correct proofs.

did.unittitle: M[ildred] W. Campbell,Warrenton to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 1 September 1846.

scopecontent.p: News of her stay with Alexander and his wife.

did.unittitle: Alexander S[pottswood] Campbell,Warrenton to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 1 September 1846.

scopecontent.p: News of his illness and planned trip to Fauquier Springs. Dinner given for Vice-President George Mifflin Dallas.

did.unittitle: E[lliott] M. Braxton,Rich[mon]d to [Charles] Campbell, 16 September 1846.

scopecontent.p: Writes to Charles Campbell when he is depressed, "Troubles seem to thicken"; worries about "the dark vail of mystery and distress that has ever hung around."

did.unittitle: Ar[thur] H[azelrigg] Henley,Chota, [Tennessee] to Charles C[ampbell], 20 September 1846.

scopecontent.p: Charles Campbell's son is visiting Arthur Hazelrigg Henley; volunteer companies are drilling for "Mr. Polk's army"; will send $115 for his ward's expenses; has read Charles Campbell's novel and thinks the Knights of the Horse-Shoe"inferior" to Horse-Shoe Robinson; family news.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to [?], 22 September 1846.

scopecontent.p: Has sent Introduction to the History of Virginiato Harpers. Small volume, covers first settlement to siege of York. Main attention to colonial period. Difficulty of being unknown to publishers. Requests a friendly word with publishers so Charles Campbell will get fair hearing.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to [?], 22 September 1846.

scopecontent.p: Wishes to have manuscript published in [New York?], has sent it to Harpers. Has received from cousin Rev. Samuel Campbell an account of the Point Pleasant campaign written by Dr. Campbell(Samuel Campbell's father). Though you don't know Harpers, Charles Campbell would appreciate kind word in his behalf.

did.unittitle: C[harles] C[ampbell], Petersburg to [?], 23 September 1846.

scopecontent.p: Received letter and manuscript by Col. Lewis. Appreciates offer of assistance in publication, though don't know him personally. Has sent manuscript to Harpers for examination.

did.unittitle: C. Campbell, Petersburg to James W. Alexander, New York, 22 September 1846.

scopecontent.p: Campbell tells Alexander that he has send his ms. to the Harpers for evaluation. Refers to a new addition on Point Pleasant campaign.

did.unittitle: Henry Barnard, Providence, Rhode Island to Charles Campbell, 24 September 1846.

scopecontent.p: Will be in New York again soon and will discuss the History of Virginiawith the Harper Brothers. Suggests that Campbell begin making contributions to Jared Sparks's American Biography.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to [Henry] Barnard,26 September 1846.

scopecontent.p: Inquires how long he will be in New York and of the prospects of Harpers' publishing his History. Asks if he could revise the proofs himself through the mail if Harpers did the work. Responds favorably to his suggestion that he contribute to Sparks' Biography.

did.unittitle: Tho[ma]s H. Callaway,Monroe Country, Tennessee to Charles Campbell, 1 October 1846.

scopecontent.p: Has been sick; Cally will visit after seeing the Henleys; will send Cally home with Mr. Jackson.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to John M. Daniel, Richmond, 1 October 1846.

scopecontent.p: Has seen his article on Virginia history and thanks him for reference to his manuscript. Has forwarded his manuscript to Harpers and hopes they will publish it. Work on the Historyhas not been taxing to his physical condition, even though he writes slowly and with difficulty.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg, Virginia to Arthur H[azelrigg] Henley,Chota, [Tennessee], 7 October 1846.

scopecontent.p: Happy that Arthur Hazelrigg Henley like Charles Campbell's son Cally; family news; price of "bread-stuffs" is up and will benefit farmers; prospects good for all produce except tobacco; free traders argue that free trade will help even tobacco prices.

did.unittitle: Ch[arle]s Botts,Richmond to [Charles] Campbell, [Petersburg], 12 October 1846.

scopecontent.p: Wants Campbell to become the Petersburg correspondent for the Richmond Standard. Is unable to make a firm monetary offer at present, but hopes to eventually.

did.unittitle: Chas. Campbell, to Charles T. Botts, ed. of The Standard, Richmond, 16 October, 1846.

scopecontent.p: Campbell has submitted 1st of proposed series of articles to Richmond Standard. Urges Botts as editor to take a more supportive attitude toward Polk administration. Critical of Gen. Taylor's armistice with Mexicans.

did.unittitle: E[lliott] M. Braxton,Rich[mon]dto Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 20 October 1846.

scopecontent.p: His fiancee broke their engagement.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg, to "Sir" [editor of the Democratic Review?], 20 October 1846.

scopecontent.p: Letter concerns Charles Campbell's subscription to the Democratic Review.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Richmond to E[lizabeth] M. Maben,[November 1846].

scopecontent.p: Health poor. Does not agree with her that preachers remain fixed for life; suggests a move about every 5 years. Callaway very well. One publisher has rejected his History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: W[illia]m B. Allegne,Richmond to [Charles Campbell, Petersburg], 4 November 1846.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for the book he sent. Hopes to visit Petersburg this winter.

did.unittitle: P[eter] V. Daniel, Jr.,Richmond to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 9 November 1846.

scopecontent.p: Will marry Miss Mary Robertson of Philadelphia on December 1, and invites him to the wedding.

did.unittitle: E[lizabeth] M. M[aben],Richmond to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 16 November 1846.

scopecontent.p: Letter received from Mother; she has been ill. She will visit Petersburg before Christmas. Church news. Asks how his History of Virginiais progressing.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell] to [?], 24 November 1846.

scopecontent.p: Charles Campbell says he would be willing to publish his manuscript in the periodical; is pleased that he is thinking of starting an historical society.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, [Petersburg] to W[illia]m Pannill,[Petersburg], 28 November 1846.

scopecontent.p: Resigns from "The Society" [Young Men's Literary Society of Petersburg?].

did.unittitle: Campbell Wallace, Knoxville, [Tennessee] to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 30 November 1846.

scopecontent.p: Encloses check for $115.

did.unittitle: 3 poems, December 1846.
Charles Campbell, Petersburg to Benjamin B. Minor, Richmond, 10 December 1846.

scopecontent.p: Inquires into arrangement for printing his History of Virginiain the Messenger. He wants printing completed in 1847 volume of Messenger. He intends to secure a copyright and also wants to examine all the proofs.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to [Benjamin B. Minor, Richmond], 10 December 1846.

scopecontent.p: Draft duplicate of letter of 10 December 1846.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell to A[rthur] H[azelrigg] Henley,11 December 1846.

scopecontent.p: Family news; Charles Campbell's son arrived home safely but the man who traveled with him borrowed $20 from Charles Campbell and has not paid it hack.

did.unittitle: A[lexander] S. Campbell,Warrenton to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 18 December 1846.

scopecontent.p: Business matters in Washington discussed: He will go there shortly after New Year's Day. He has sent daguerreotype of himself to Sister Betty.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, Petersburg to [Alexander] S. Campbell,Warrenton, 21 December 1846.

scopecontent.p: Business matters, touching on trip to Washington. Family news; announces death of Santa Anna. Asks him to look for a book in Washington.

did.unittitle: [Rev.] William S. Plumer,Richmond to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 26 December 1846.

scopecontent.p: Cannot comply with Charles Campbell's request as has disposed of things (Charles Campbell had lent a very rare Indian relic, stone cooking utensil; Rev. William S. Plumer disposed of it with a cabinet, penciled in Charles Campbell's hand). As ages, less pleased with earth, but loves friends more and more.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to B[enjamin] B. Minor,Richmond, 29 December 1846.

scopecontent.p: Explains the delay in his sending the manuscript of his History of Virginiaand hopes it is not too late to include part of it in the January issue of the Messenger. Asks again to see the proofs.

did.unittitle:
Letters,
1847.
Joseph B. Boyd, Maysville, Kentucky to Charles Campbell, 4 January 1847.

scopecontent.p: Letter concerns autograph collecting.

did.unittitle: [Benjamin B.] Minor,to C[harles] Campbell, 11 January 1847.

scopecontent.p: Proposes to buy new type for the printing of the History of Virginia, and asks Campbell to contribute $50 to this project. Tries to persuade Campbell that the additional expense will be worthwhile.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, Petersburg, [Virginia] to Rev. Sam[ue]l D. Campbell,18 January 1847.

scopecontent.p: Southern Literary Messengerwould publish his manuscript; Samuel D. Campbell's father's manuscript will appear in Charles Campbell's publication; will have 500 copies published.

did.unittitle: Sally Moore Braxton, Mantnor[?], to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 21 January 1847.

scopecontent.p: Read Dr. Caruthers book; family news.

did.unittitle: [Benjamin B.] Minorto [Charles] Campbell, 22 January 1847.

scopecontent.p: Asks him to send Dedication and Preface to his History of Virginia (if he has any) so that the History may be published in full in the Southern Literary MessengerWill send some proofs tomorrow. Asks Campbell if he would object to the addition of notes and addenda to the Messenger's addition of the History.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell, Petersburg, [Virginia] to [Sally Moore Braxton], 24 January 1847.

scopecontent.p: Dr. Caruthers was preparing a sequel to Knights of the Golden Horse-Shoe.

did.unittitle: P. C. Pendleton, Savannah, Georgie to Charles Campbell, 26 January 1847[?].

scopecontent.p: Soliciting writings and subscriptions for his magazine "Magnolia." Will pay $2 to agents for each cash-paying subscriber.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to William F. Watson, Richmond, 31 January 1847.

scopecontent.p: Enclosed is title page of book. Please deposit it at Federal Court for articate of copyright. Letter from Mantua, tell Braxton.

did.unittitle: W[illiam] Maxwell,Richmond, [Virginia] to Charles Campbell, 22 February 1847.

scopecontent.p: Chosen a corresponding member of Virginia Historical and Philosophical Society.

did.unittitle: A. B. Guijon, Washington to [Charles] Campbell, Petersburg, 22 February 1847.

scopecontent.p: Letter concerns Force's Historical Tracts. Discussion of Bacon's Rebellion. Is sending "An Account of Bacon's Rebellion in the Year 1776"[sic]. Has decided to enter college.

did.unittitle: [Elizabeth Campbell Maben], Richmond to Mrs. Mildred W. Campbell, Petersburg, 26 February 1847.

scopecontent.p:
$3000 collected for "the Irish." Social news.
Postscript: Campbell Maben to [Callaway Campbell]. His mother (Elizabeth Maben) has been reading Charles Campbell's History of Virginia. 1 page.
Postscript: Jennie Maben to [Mildred W. Campbell]. Hopes she is successful with her school. 1 page.

did.unittitle: E. Lorraine, Richmond, [Virginia] to Cha[rle]s Campbell, 28 February 1847.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for $15; asks him to recommend the family boarding house to others.

did.unittitle: Ar[thur] H[azelrigg] Henley,Chota, [Tennessee] to Charles [Campbell], 1 March 1847.

scopecontent.p: Sends $85 for his ward; has been sick; family news.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to Alex[ande]r Guijon,Washington, 1 March 1847.

scopecontent.p: Asks him to bring a copy of Peter Forces' Historical Tractswith him to Richmond.

did.unittitle: K. B. Townley, Lynchburg, Virginia to "friend" [Charles Campbell], 2 March 1847.

scopecontent.p: Wants to know what ship Richard Townley arrived in during the 17th century.

did.unittitle: A. B. Guiion, Washington to [Charles] Campbell, 4 March 1847.

scopecontent.p: Discussion of the Senate meeting. Debts of the Senators. Social life in Washington.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg, [Virginia] to [K. B.] Townley,Lynchburg, [Virginia], 6 March 1847.

scopecontent.p: Does not know the name of the vessel Richard Townley arrived in; suggests ways of finding the information.

did.unittitle: W[illiam] Henry Foote,Romney to [Benjamin B.] Minor,12 March 1847.

scopecontent.p: Has read Campbell's Historyas published in Southern Literary Messenger. Inquires as to whether 1619 or 1620 is the correct date for the introduction of slaves in Virginia. Asks Campbell to settle the matter, over which there has been some dispute.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to B[enjamin] B. Minor,[Richmond], 24 March 1847.

scopecontent.p: Explains his view of certain financial aspects of the publication of his History. Will attend the next meeting of the historical society if he can, but will be unable to write anything for it.

did.unittitle: Sam[ue]l D. Campbell,Natural Bridge, Virginia to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 25 March 1847.

scopecontent.p: Gilmore family history; Campbell family history; Revolutionary war; glad Virginia Historical Society was revived.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to Benj[amin] B. Minor,30 March 1847.

scopecontent.p:
Has read, corrected, and returned proof sheet. Sends references and a note on an aspect of the Historyfor inclusion.
Draft duplicate of this letter listed below.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to [Benjamin B. Minor, Richmond]. ALS. 1 page. 30 March 1847.

scopecontent.p:
Draft duplicate of letter of 30 March 1847.
See above for the final copy of this letter with the same date.

did.unittitle: E. Lorraine, Richmond, [Virginia] to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 31 March 1847.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell] to [?], Timber Neck, Gloucester County,[Virginia], 15 May 1847.

scopecontent.p: Thinks everyone should be involved in the Presidential campaign; is satisfied with the nominees, Cass and Butler, and expects them to win.

did.unittitle: A[lexander] S. C[ampbell],Warrenton to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 29 June 1847.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for books sent him. Has been reading about farming and is becoming more enthusiastic about it. Looking forward to visit from Mother and Callaway. Has not yet read his History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: John N. Rose, Memphis, Tennessee to Charles C. Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 30 June 1847.

scopecontent.p: Character reference for Michael D. Deadrick.

did.unittitle: Elliot M. Braxton, Mantua to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 1 July 1847.

scopecontent.p: Acknowledges receipt of $200. Local news: choosing of a new Presbyterian pastor.

did.unittitle: B[enjamin] Silliman,New Haven, Connecticut to Rev. Stephen Taylor, 10 August 1847.

did.unittitle: M[ildred] W. Campbell,Warrenton to Charles [Campbell], 16 August 1847.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth M. M[aben],White Sulphur to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 19 August [1847].

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to Mrs. E[lizabeth] M. Maben,27 August 1847.

scopecontent.p: Glad to hear news of her journey to the White Sulphur springs. News received from Mother about Callaway, Aleck, and his wife.

scopecontent.p: Account of family, particularly of his father.

scopecontent.p:
News of home. Reference to his writing a book.
Letter also includes the letter of C[harles] C[ampbell], Petersburg, to Cally [Campbell]. Encourages him to practice writing. ALS. 2 pages.

did.unittitle: [?], Norborne to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, [Virginia], 4 September 1847.

scopecontent.p: Returns a book.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, Petersburg, [Virginia] to Mr. Macfarlane, 6 September 1847.

scopecontent.p: Complains about paying too much postage on his proof sheets; the Messengeris for sale.

did.unittitle: W[illiam] B. Harrison,Sweet Springs, Virginia to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, [Virginia], 14 September 1847.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for data on Harrison family; Harrison family data.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to B[enjamin] B. Minor,[Richmond], 15 September 1847.

scopecontent.p: Sends more of manuscript of his History, leaving it to printer of Messengerto be divided up between now and the end of the year. Understands Minor is interested in selling the Messenger, but he prefers to remain in editing rather than publishing it.

did.unittitle: J[ohn] M[oncure] Daniel,Richmond to [Charles] Campbell, 24 September 1847.

scopecontent.p: "Little John" Thompson purchased Southern Literary Messenger yesterday from [Benjamin B.] Minorfor about $2000. Financial situation of Messenger uncertain; Daniel had offered $1500 for it; Thompson knows nothing of this. Their friend [Charles Tyler] Bottsis starting out for California.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to Mrs. M[ary] B. Carter,Shirley, 25 September 1847.

scopecontent.p: Sorry to have missed her while she was in Petersburg. Speaks of his nervous condition and the necessity of his retirement to the country.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to John M. Daniel, Richmond, 27 September 1847.

scopecontent.p: The Messenger's subscription list is declining; doesn't think literary periodical would ever flourish in the South.

did.unittitle: J[ohn] R. Thompson,Richmond to [Charles Campbell], 2 October 1847.

scopecontent.p: Mr. Macfarlane has no copies of his History of Virginiaand would like some. Greets Campbell, hopes he will continue to aid Southern Literary Messengerof which he, Thompson has just become editor.

did.unittitle: John R. Thompson, Richmond to C[harles Campbell], [Petersburg], 6 October 1847.

scopecontent.p: Asks him whether the conclusion of his Historyshould be published in the December or the January issue of the Messenger. When he comes to Richmond, Thompson will show him some interesting autograph letters.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, Petersburg to John R. Thompson, [Richmond], 8 October 1847.

scopecontent.p: Informs Thompson of the agreement with Benjamin B. Minor to have the History of Virginiacomplete in the 1847 volume of the Messenger, even if this meant devoting the entire December issue to it.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to Alex[ander] S. Campbell,26 October 1847.

scopecontent.p: Will visit him early next week. Relates news of a fire in house and stable of John and Betty Maben: fires were deliberately set.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Richmond to Mildred Ruffin, Marlbourn, Hanover, 29 October 1847.

scopecontent.p: Will visit Marlbourn.

did.unittitle: S. S. Braxton, Fredericksburg to Charles [Campbell], 5 November 1847.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for his gift.

did.unittitle: Kate [Beckwith],Petersburg, [Virginia] to Anna Burdsall, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, 8 November 1847.

scopecontent.p: Hopes her brother will be well.

did.unittitle: Arthur H[azelrigg] Henley,Chota, [Tennessee] to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 11 November 1847.

did.unittitle: Scott [Burdsall]and J. M. N., Augusta to Anna Burdsall, Petersburg, Virginia, 23 November 1847.

scopecontent.p: Took a steam boat to Charleston and will go to Montgomery. J. M. N. to Anna Burdsall. Invites her to visit.

did.unittitle: A. E. Peticolas[?], Richmond, [Virginia] to Charles Campbell, 25 November 1847.

scopecontent.p: Asks for a friend's manuscript.

did.unittitle: E[lliott] M. Braxton,King and Queen C[our]t Houseto Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 30 November 1847.

scopecontent.p: His fiancee rejected him and he is depressed.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell] to Alex[ander] S. Campbell,Warrenton, December 1847.

scopecontent.p: His trip from Warrenton to Richmond where he stayed with [Edmund] Ruffinfor a week. Will have his Historybound shortly and still uncertain if he will profit by it.

did.unittitle: Henry T. Oates, Charleston to Cha[rle]s Campbell, 7 December 1847.

scopecontent.p: Letter concerns autograph collecting.

did.unittitle: W[illia]m Maxwell,Richmond to Cha[rle]s Campbell, [Petersburg], 8 December 1847.

scopecontent.p: Sends him a prospectus of his work, hoping Campbell will be able to obtain subscribers for it. Asks if he will attend the Annual Meeting of the Virginia Historical Society on December 16th.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg, [Virginia] to Henry T. Oates, 11 December 1847.

scopecontent.p: Letter concerns autograph collecting.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, Petersburg to R. R. Howison, Richmond, 11 December 1847.

scopecontent.p: His History of Virginiais currently in press at the office of the Southern Literary Messenger. He will send him the proof sheet when they become available.

did.unittitle: J[ohn] M. Daniel,Richmond to [Charles Campbell, Petersburg], [Late 1847].

scopecontent.p: Asks for unbound sheets of the Historywhich has been appearing in the Messenger; he would like to bind them himself.

did.unittitle:
Letters,
