Charles Campbell to Thomas H. Williamson, [1848].

scopecontent.p: Comment on Cavaliers and Puritansarticle; does not know the Bacon coat of arms.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. C[arter],[Shirley] to [Mildred W. Campbell], [Petersburg], [1848].

scopecontent.p: Sends son Charley back to school today. Encloses $50; asks her to buy various articles of clothing.

did.unittitle: Mary B. Carter, [Shirley] to Mildred W. Campbell, Petersburg, 1 January 1848.

scopecontent.p: Sends a barrel of food. Will get several copies of Charles' new Historyshortly. Family news.

did.unittitle: Lyman C. Draper, Baltimore to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 13 January 1848.

scopecontent.p: His 1846 journey to the West was very successful. Was in Richmond last July, but ill-health prevented him from going to Petersburg. Is working on a volume The Life and Times of George Rogers Clark.Congratulates him on appearance of History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: William Maxwell, Richmond to Charles Campbell, 17 January 1848.

scopecontent.p: Received Charles Campbell's letter with $6 enclosed, six subscriptions to William Maxwell's Historical Register. Lists names. Thanks for copies of Charles Campbell's History. Will try to help sell and circulate Charles Campbell's book.

did.unittitle: John M. Mason, Washington to C[harles] C[ampbell], 21 January 1848.

scopecontent.p: Letter concerns history of Bacon's Rebellion, printed in the Southern Literary Messenger; no means of franking book Charles Campbell wishes to send to Library of Congress or to Smithsonian.

did.unittitle: J[ames] W. Alexander,New York to Charles Campbell, [Petersburg], 24 January 1848.

scopecontent.p: Has received his letter, but his book has yet to arrive. Regret that he will not have time to review it.

did.unittitle: Jared Sparks, Cambridge, Massachusetts to Charles Campbell, [Petersburg], 25 January 1848.

scopecontent.p: Is glad to hear the History of Virginiahas been published. Asks for a copy for himself and one for Francis Bowen, editor of the North American Review.

did.unittitle: A[lexander] S. Campbell,Warrenton to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, February 1848.

scopecontent.p: Encloses partial payment of debts. Announces birth of second son, named William Horner. Has seen advertisements for his Historybut has yet to see the book itself.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to Jared Sparks, Cambridge, Massachusetts, [2] February 1848.

scopecontent.p: Sends him two copies of the History of Virginia. Asks how he can send copies to George Bancroft in London. Tells him of the revival of the Virginia Historical Society and its intention to publish a quarterly.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to [Jared Sparks, Cambridge, Massachusetts], 2 February 1848.

scopecontent.p: Sends him two copies of the History of Virginia Says he would like to send some copies to George Bancroft in London but he does not know how to reach him.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to Rev. J. W. Alexander, New York, 7 February 1848.

scopecontent.p: Believes would be interested in information of the Davies family. Sent copy of Charles Campbell's book. Questions using extensive quotes in original obsolete form, vs. modernized shorter quotes. If book sells well, may put out "handsome" edition. Sends copy to Tribune, Horace Greeley, editor, for whom he wrote some time ago; also a copy to the Literary World.

did.unittitle: A[lexander] S. Campbell,Warrenton to Charles [Campbell], 18 February 1848.

scopecontent.p: Letter of introduction of Dr. Helms, who is investigating their claims upon government.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], [Petersburg] to [Alexander S. Campbell], [Warrenton], [March [?] 1848].

scopecontent.p: Callaway may be going to Tennessee shortly. Met soldiers returning from Mexico. Family news.

did.unittitle: Ar[thur] H[azelrigg] Henley,Madisonville to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 5 March 1848.

scopecontent.p: Encloses $160 for his ward's expenses; 40 cases of measles on his plantation.

did.unittitle: Lyman C. Draper, Baltimore to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 6 March 1848.

scopecontent.p: Has written a favorable review of the History of Virginiafor the Literary World. He is writing only fitfully. Asks further information on Col. Alexander Spotswood Dandridge, mentioned in the History.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. Carter,Shirley to M[ildred] W. Campbell,Petersburg, 8 March 1848.

scopecontent.p: She has read Charles's book and is delighted with it. Family news.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to [Lyman C. Draper, Baltimore], 8 March 1848.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for favorable reviews in Literary World, an extract of which his bookseller will use as advertisement. Suggests name of someone to write to for information on Col. Alexander Spotswood Dandridge.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to Lyman C. Draper, Philadelphia, 9 March 1848.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for favorable review in Literary World. He once had a letter of Col. A. S. Dandridge, which is now at Virginia Historical Society. He has received a letter from Jared Sparks, favorably commenting on the History.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell, Petersburg] to Jared Sparks,[Cambridge, Massachusetts], 9 March 1848.

scopecontent.p: Is glad to hear that Sparks approves of his Historyand hopes it will be noted in the North American Review.

did.unittitle: R. C. Mason, near Alexandria to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, [Virginia], 10 March 1848.

scopecontent.p: Found error in History of Virginia. Jefferson not the author of the Bill of Rights, George Mason wrote it; cites evidence for this.

did.unittitle: Marion R. Booth, Hawthorne Hall to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 15 March 1848.

scopecontent.p: Will read his History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: A[lexander] S. C[ampbell],Warrenton to Charles [Campbell], 16 March 1848.

scopecontent.p: Has read favorable review of his History. More about Dr. Helms. Molley's health improving.

did.unittitle: Jared Sparks, Cambridge, Massachusetts to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 21 March 1848.

scopecontent.p: He does not object to the use of his comments on the Historybeing made public. Discusses a factual question raised by Lyman C. Draper, and compares some historians to sheep. Says a note of the book will be made in a future issue of the North American Review.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to J. K. Tefft, Savannah, 24 March 1848.

scopecontent.p: Read with interest the proceedings of the Georgia Historical Society. Will send the Society a copy of his History of Virginiaat the first opportunity. Says most Virginians are currently too "engrossed in president making" to notice his book.

did.unittitle: R. K. Meade, Wash[ington]to C[harles] Campbell, 26 March 1848.

scopecontent.p: Has met with the Secretary of the Treasury and Charles Campbell has been appointed a clerk.

did.unittitle: R. C. Mason, near Alexandria to [Charles Campbell], 29 March 1848.

scopecontent.p: Thanks Charles Campbell for attention to George Mason case.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to [John R. Thompson, Richmond], 11 April 1848.

scopecontent.p: Sends correction of an item in last issue of Messenger. Encourages him to continue publishing even though these are bad times for "belles lettres".

did.unittitle: J. K. Tefft, Savannah to Cha[rle]s Campbell,[Petersburg], 15 April 1848.

scopecontent.p: Has just returned from Europe. Suggests ways of sending the History of Virginiato the Georgia Historical Society.

did.unittitle: John F. Randolph, Yazoo City, Mississippi to Cha[rle]s Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 16 April 1848.

scopecontent.p: Read Charles Campbell's works; recounts his life story.

did.unittitle: Henry Barnard, Charleston, South Carolina to Charles Campbell, 18 April 1848.

scopecontent.p: He is traveling with Mrs. Barnard, and they expect to spend time in the Norfolk-York-Richmond area. Hopes to meet Campbell and to introduce his wife to him.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to Henry Barnard, 20 April 1848.

scopecontent.p: Is glad to hear that he and Mrs. Barnard will visit Virginia. Suggests places for them to visit. Hopes to join them.

did.unittitle: Sam[ue]l D. Campbell,Natural Bridge, Virginia to [Charles Campbell], 29 April 1848.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for copies of his History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: M. K. McGhee, Toquaville to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, May [1848] [?].

scopecontent.p: Family news; remembers happy days at Chota.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to Jared Sparks, Cambridge, Massachusetts, 2 May 1848.

scopecontent.p: Sends him the requested copy of Kercheval's History. Encloses a list of more of the Bland manuscripts.

did.unittitle: F[rancis] Waylandand R. A. Guild, Providence, Rhode Island to Charles Campbell, 3 May 1848.

scopecontent.p: Acknowledges gift of History of Virginiato Brown University Library.

did.unittitle: N. Gammell[?], [Providence, Rhode Island] to Charles Campbell, 4 May 1848.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for the gift of his Historyto Brown University Library.

did.unittitle: Henry Barnard. [Murfreesboro] to C[harles] Campbell, [Petersburg], 5 May 1848.

scopecontent.p: He and his wife arrived this morning and would be happy to see him, even though he [Barnard] is ill.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to [Dr. Helm, Warrenton, Virginia (penciled in)], 17 May 1848.

scopecontent.p: Giving reference for quote from the Bland Paperson Colonel James Monroe.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. Carter,Shirley to [Mildred W.] Campbell,Petersburg, 10 June 1848.

scopecontent.p: Family news: her children have joined the church, which is a great comfort to her. Her son, Will, is at Whig convention in Philadelphia.

did.unittitle: A[lexander] S. Campbell,Warrenton, to Charles [Campbell], 16 June 1848.

scopecontent.p: Spending time with farming; good crop of wheat expected. Although originally he thought little of [Lewis] Cass,now prefers him to [Zachary] Taylorin the upcoming campaign.

did.unittitle: Henry Barnard, Providence, Rhode Island to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 20 June 1848.

scopecontent.p: Jared Sparks has asked to borrow a book of Virginia documents which Campbell had given him. He has been very busy since his return from the South, delaying some writing he had intended to do. A woman of his acquaintance wants autographs and letters of some Virginia Revolutionary leaders.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to Henry Barnard, 26 June 1848.

scopecontent.p: Has quickly forwarded the book requested by Jared Sparks. Would like to see his proposed article if he finds time to finish it. Regrets that he cannot furnish any of the requested autographs.

did.unittitle: Charles [Campbell], Petersburg, Virginia to Mary McGhee, 26 June 1848.
[Charles Campbell] to Arthur H[azelrigg] Henley,Chota, Tennessee, 13 July 1848.

scopecontent.p: Charles Campbell's son Cally plans to visit Tennessee Family news.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. C[arter],Shirley to M[ildred] W. Campbell,Petersburg, 14 July [1848].

scopecontent.p: Glad to hear when will come for a visit next month. Family news.

did.unittitle: H. H. Cocke, Norfolk to [Charles Campbell], 21 July 1848.

scopecontent.p: Encloses information on Harrison family.

did.unittitle: Jared Sparks, Cambridge, Massachusetts to Charles Campbell, [Petersburg], 28 July 1848.

scopecontent.p: Acknowledges receipt of Kercheval's History. Will be happy to receive the new Bland Manuscripts. Encloses the outline of an upcoming work.

did.unittitle: J. I. Shaw, North-Middletown, Bourbon County, Kentucky, to Charles Campbell Petersburg, 28 July 1848.

scopecontent.p: Inquires whether he can obtain copy of Col. John Stuart's history of the Indian wars, published by the Virginia Historical Society in 1833.

did.unittitle: Lyman C. Draper, Philadelphia to Ch[arle]s Campbell, Petersburg, 29 July 1848.

scopecontent.p: Inquires into information concerning early exploration of Shenandoah Valley. Asks for further information on sources of account of Battle of Point Pleasant contained in the History. Has learned of the break-up and sale of the William Byrd library.

did.unittitle: C[harles] C[ampbell], Petersburg, [Virginia] to Anna [Burdsall],31 July 1848.

scopecontent.p: Thanks her for the present to Callaway; went to old point, "a watering place"; was present at return of Virginia volunteers from Mexico with "long hair and squalid beards, and shabby uniforms, and slouched hats and rusty guns" and with several curiosities.

did.unittitle: Th[oma]s H. Williamson,Lexington, Virginia to Cha[rle]s Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, August [1848].

scopecontent.p:
Read Charles Campbell's History of Virginia; sends description of Bacon crest.
Encloses copy of his article Cavaliers and Puritans.13 pages.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell, Petersburg] to [Jared Sparks], August [1848].

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for his favorable remarks on the History.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell, Petersburg] to [Jared Sparks], 15 May 1848.

scopecontent.p: Forwards a copy of Kercheval's History. Discusses factual questions raised by Lyman Draper.

did.unittitle: J. K. McGhee, Montvale to [Charles Campbell], August [1848][?].

scopecontent.p: Family news; Thomas Humes of Knoxville is anxious to see the Bland Papers; question of Calie's guardianship.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, Petersburg to W[illia]m Nelson,Yorktown, 4 August 1848.

scopecontent.p: Asks to borrow old letterbook.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to William Maxwell, 4 August 1848.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to Lyman C. Draper, [Philadelphia], 7 August 1848.

scopecontent.p: Answers his queries of July 29, correcting printers' errors in the History. Gives information on his own descent from Gov. Alexander Spotswood.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, Petersburg to [Mildred W. Campbell], 7 August 1848.

scopecontent.p: Cally's need to visit dentist. Asks that Callaway return to Petersburg.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg, [Virginia] to Mrs. Lucinda F. Lea, 14 August 1848.

scopecontent.p: Charles Campbell is sending son Cally to Mrs. Lea's for the summer; asks her to treat Cally firmly.

did.unittitle: William Maxwell, Richmond to Charles Campbell, 16 August 1848.

scopecontent.p: Received Charles Campbell's letter of the 5th. Sends pamphlet for Charles Campbell to forward to Mr. Shaw. Mr. [Hugh Blair] Grigsbyapprised William Maxwell of what Charles Campbell said about Col. Byrd's Library. William Maxwell would be glad to get some books and a catalogue. Trip to Eastern Shore, saw Mr. Joynes.

did.unittitle:
C[harles] C[ampbell], Petersburg to
Mrs. Henry [Josephine D.] Barnard,23 August 1848.

scopecontent.p: Gives her the promised description of their trip on the York River. Witty remarks concerning crabs and young ladies.

did.unittitle: A[lexander] S. Campbell,Warrenton to Charles [Campbell], 25 August 1848.

scopecontent.p: Mother, Betty, Callaway, and children arrived last Friday. All enjoyed their stay. Takes little excitement in election campaign, but refers to Wilmot Proviso as "humbug."

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to [Alexander S. Campbell], [Warrenton], 3 September 1848.

scopecontent.p: Happy to receive news of family's visit to Warrenton.

did.unittitle: Kate [Beckwith],Petersburg, [Virginia] to Anna Burdsall, Rahway, New Jersey, 11 October 1848.

scopecontent.p: "C.C. was here" and was sad that there was no message for him from Anna Burdsall.

did.unittitle: Henry Barnard, New York to Charles Campbell, 11 October 1848.

scopecontent.p: Is sending him a copy of his book, School Architecture.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], [Petersburg] to Alex[ander] S. Campbell,[November 1848].

scopecontent.p: Made trip north a month ago; met William Homes on board a steam boat out of Baltimore. Visited Franklin Institution in Philadelphia. In New York for funeral of Sen. [ ] Lewis.

did.unittitle: John R. Thompson, Richmond to C[harles] Campbell, 15 November 1848.

scopecontent.p: Inquires about the author of a recent article. Asks him to contribute an article for the January issue of the Messenger.

did.unittitle: William Bolling, Whig Hall to Charles Campbell, 9 December 1848.

scopecontent.p: Tenders official thanks for copy of History of Virginiasent to "American Whig Society."

did.unittitle: Ar[thur] H[azelrigg] Henley,Chota, Tennessee to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 31 December 1848.

scopecontent.p: Encloses $100 for his ward (Charles Campbell's son); his health is poor.

did.unittitle:
Letters,
1849.
M[ary] B. Carter,Shirley to M[ildred] W. Campbell,Petersburg, 25 January 1849.

scopecontent.p: Family news: son Charlie's work as an overseer. Asks her to buy him a chair to use in his work.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell] to [?], [March c. 1849].

scopecontent.p: Cally arrived safely at Mr. Callaway's; death of Arthur Henley.

did.unittitle: Callaway Campbell,Candys Creek to Grandma [Mildred Walker Campbell], March 1849.
E[lliott] M. Braxton,King and Queen to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 6 March 1849.

scopecontent.p: Is running for office; campaigned against Taylor in 1848.

did.unittitle: A[lexander] S. Campbell,Warrenton to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 9 March 1849.

scopecontent.p: Although he was for Zachary Taylor originally, he voted for [Lewis] Cass; fears the Whigs coming to power. A bad season for farm operations. Family news.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. C[arter],Shirley to Mildred W. Campbell, Petersburg, 10 March 1849.

scopecontent.p: Acknowledges receipt of chair. Expresses her anti-slavery sentiments: calls it a "great sin." Asks her to bring two copies of Charles' Historywhen she comes. Encloses $10.

did.unittitle: C[harles] Campbell, Petersburg, [Virginia] to [?], 21 March 1849.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for news of death of Arthur H. Henly.

did.unittitle: C[harles] C[ampbell], Petersburg to [John R. Thompson, Richmond], 9 April 1849.

scopecontent.p: Compliments him for his direction of the Messenger. Expresses belief that as the "political excitement" abate, the magazine will prosper.

did.unittitle: James D. Tatum, Aberdeen, Mississippi to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 13 April 1849.
Folder 79 currently does not exist in this collection.
Charles Campbell, Petersburg to John R. Thompson, 20 April 1849.

scopecontent.p: He has written very little lately, but will try to contribute something soon to the Messenger, perhaps revisions of some articles published a few years ago in The New Yorker, a short-lived magazine edited by Horace Greeley.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg, [Virginia] to [James D. Tatum, Aberdeen, Mississippi], 27 April 1849.

scopecontent.p: Did not see James D. Tatum's brothers' paintings since he saw James D. Tatum, he has married and received $10,000 in property from his wife's estate; returned to Virginia and became Customs Collector which gives "a tolerable income"; his nervous maladies continue.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg, [Virginia] to [James D.] Tatum,[Aberdeen, Mississippi], 30 April 1849.

scopecontent.p: Did not see James D. Tatum's Brother's painting.

did.unittitle: Josephine D. Barnard, Hartford, Connecticut to Charles Campbell, 8 May 1849.

scopecontent.p: She pleasantly recalls their visit of last year to Virginia. They were recently in Baltimore visiting a daughter of Charles Carroll of Carrollton. She is now going to Detroit but her husband, Henry, must remain in the East.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to [Josephine D. Barnard], 16 May 1849.

scopecontent.p: Wishes they could again be together and traveling, but for a longer period of time than last year.

did.unittitle: John M. Galt, Williamsburg to [Charles Campbell, Petersburg], 21 May 1849.

scopecontent.p: Inquires into some specific information regarding Pocahontas.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to Susan Braxton, 5 June 1849.

scopecontent.p: Planning to visit Richmond; Cholera has driven the legislature to Fauquier Springs.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to Lyman C. Draper, Philadelphia, 15 June 1849.

scopecontent.p: Is sorry to hear of his illness. Gives information on daughters of Gov. Alexander Spotswood and their descendants. Speaks of difficulty of obtaining a daguerreotype or engraving of Gov. Spotswood.

scopecontent.p: Is glad to hear of his "Herculeen" work with the manuscripts he has collected. Asks for a list of some of the books in the Byrd library.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to [John R. Thompson], 16 March 1851.

scopecontent.p: He has found an old letter of John Adams', which he thinks bears republication. Proposes being paid a constant rate of $1.50 for all of his work published in the Messenger.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell] to [Anna Campbell], 7 July [1851].

scopecontent.p: Hopes she is enjoying her trip; 4th of July quiet except Mr. Pryor, who delivered the "Horation". Deliver "a regular disunion blowout" and a "fierce denunciation of the radicalism of the age"; Charles Campbell is editing Mr. Pryor's paper for a week, but Charles Campbell differs from Pryor's "ultra disunion course".

did.unittitle: Anna [Campbell],Philadelphia, [Pennsylvania] to Charles [Campbell], 8 July 1851.

scopecontent.p: Visited Reading; brother in poor health; arrived in Rahway; misses him.

scopecontent.p: Hopes her trip is going well; July 4th speech by Mr. Pryor was "in part disunion, in part anti-radical"; Charles Campbell will edit Pryor's "fire eating paper" for a week; Charles Campbell describes himself as a moderate; political parties "jumbled up and confounded"; hopes AC will gain 5 pounds.

did.unittitle: Anna [Campbell],Rahway, [New Jersey] to [Charles Campbell], 14 July [1851].

scopecontent.p: Saw brother Edward and his children; will go to Trenton; Charles Campbell is editing for Mr. Pryor.

did.unittitle: C[harles] C[ampbell], Petersburg, [Virginia] to Anna Campbell, 17 July 1851.

scopecontent.p: Hopes her brother will get well; news of his school; is still editing Pryor's paper and is trying "to make it savor less of disunion" and has written on disunion spirit in South Carolina; black children have whooping cough; article he sent to Thompson for his July issue did not appear.

did.unittitle: Anna [Campbell],[New Jersey] to Charles [Campbell], 22 July 1851.

scopecontent.p: Misses him; has been berry-picking; enjoying living in the country; expected his article to appear in the Messenger; one of her Quaker friends has converted to the Presbyterian church; asks him to bring some things with him.

did.unittitle: C[harles] C[ampbell], Petersburg, [Virginia] to Anna Campbell, 23 July 1851.

scopecontent.p: May be joining her at Rahway; Pryor pleased with Charles Campbell's editing of the paper even though Charles Campbell tried to repress Pryor's "extravagant reckless sort of ultraism"; John Tyler wrote Charles Campbell thanking him for a book.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to N. A. Sturdivant, Ed. of Southern Era, 3 September 1851.

scopecontent.p: On return from trip to North, found N. A. Sturdivant's letter, asking that Charles Campbell contribute something to his magazine. Obliged for compliment, but feels he has written enough "enamateur", and will write no longer in that way.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to William Maxwell, 6 September 1851.

scopecontent.p: Has returned proof-sheet of the Register. Sends letter of Earl of Essex to Lord Southampton. Mr. Conway Robinson has wanted Charles Campbell to publish it. If William Maxwell wishes any of Charles Campbell's articles to republish, Charles Campbell will be glad to revise. Richard Batte, of the post office, wishes to subscribe to the Register.

scopecontent.p: Has looked over Chalmer's Introduction, seems accurate and able, but the theory that a civilized America would be dependent on Great Britain is absurd. Doesn't attach importance that many do to the political discoveries of America, may possess British prejudices. Best eulogy to British administration of America is the contest which appear to be growing between the different sections of the country.

scopecontent.p: Plans to pick her up and bring her home well before the baby is due; domestic news.

did.unittitle: Anna C[ampbell],[New Jersey] to Charles [Campbell], 22 July 1856.

scopecontent.p: Charles Campbell might like the Trenton dentist better than the New York dentist; unsure when the baby is due but would like to be home for the delivery.

did.unittitle: C[harles] C[ampbell], Petersburg, Virginia to Anna [Campbell],25 July 1856.

scopecontent.p: Has gotten Miss Eliza Wilson to help Anna Campbell through her confinement; his school year-is over.

did.unittitle: Callaway Campbell, Cleveland, [Tennessee] to "Pa" [Charles Campbell], 29 July 1856.

scopecontent.p: Mary McGhee has not recovered from Barkley's death [suicide]; news of the Henley family; Henley boys in California are making $10-15 a day each.

did.unittitle: C[harles] C[ampbell], Petersburg, Virginia to Anna [Campbell],30 July 1856.

scopecontent.p: Plans for Anna Campbell's trip back to Virginia.

did.unittitle: Mildred W[alker] Campbell, Petersburg to Anna [Campbell],31 July 1856.

scopecontent.p: Mildred Walker Campbell planning to start a school; Miss Eliza Wilson will arrive to nurse Anna Campbell.

did.unittitle: C[harles] C[ampbell], Petersburg, [Virginia] to Anna [Campbell],1 August 1856.

scopecontent.p: Will leave Virginia to pick her up; domestic news.

did.unittitle: A[nna] C[ampbell]to Charles [Campbell], 5 August 1856.

scopecontent.p: Has written to Eliza Wilson; children have been sick; looking forward to seeing him.

did.unittitle: Hugh B. Grigsby, Charlotte, Virginia to Charles Campbell, 3 September 1856.

scopecontent.p: Discusses Richard Henry Lee's participation in the convention of 1776. He is currently working on his history of the convention of 1788.

did.unittitle: W[illia]m T. Joynes[?], Petersburg, [Virginia] to C[harles] Campbell, 1 October 1856.

scopecontent.p: His son Thomas is Charles Campbell's pupil, against him starting Latin, does not want him working too hard.

did.unittitle: Anna Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia to "cousin" [Charles], 13 November 1856.

scopecontent.p: Sympathy on death of Louisa; has a baby boy.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to H[ugh] B. Grigsby,[Norfolk], 17 November 1856.

scopecontent.p: Sends him information on an ancestor of the Randolph family.

did.unittitle:
Callaway Campbell, Petersburg, [Virginia] to
Mildred W[alker] Campbell,24 November 1856.

scopecontent.p: Arrived safely in Petersburg; Falconer sentenced to two years in prison for stealing railroad money; Jenny getting married.

did.unittitle: William V. Wells, Boston to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 26 November 1856.

scopecontent.p: Looking for information on Samuel Adams.

did.unittitle: William V. Wells, Boston to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 6 December 1856.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for his help on Virginia history.

did.unittitle: Hugh B. Grigsby, Norfolk to [Charles Campbell], 15 December 1856.

scopecontent.p: Offers to make suggestions and corrections of a future edition of the History of Virginia. Encourages production of a new edition.

did.unittitle:
Letters,
1857.
Anna Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia to "cousin," 22 February 1857.

scopecontent.p: Has been sick and cures sore throat with lager beer; Charles Campbell's school is very small; is tired of living in a slave state; Charles Campbell not making much money.

did.unittitle: David Winge, Marengo, Alabama, to Charles Campbell, 4 April 1857.

scopecontent.p: Subscription business.

did.unittitle: C. Benjamin Richardson, Boston to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 21 May 1857.

scopecontent.p: Received Charles Campbell's of the 18th. Send back issues of the Historical Magazine. Hopes Charles Campbell will show magazine to interested people. Started by member of local historical societies to aid members and students.

did.unittitle: Anna C[ampbell],Petersburg, Virginia to "cousin," 11 August 1857.

scopecontent.p: She is well; Charles Campbell gave up his school.

did.unittitle: Bishop William Meade, Millwood to Charles Campbell, 14 August [18]57.

scopecontent.p: Sends two almanacs.

did.unittitle: Cal[laway] Campbell,Hampden Sydney to "Grandma" [Mildred Walker Campbell], 27 September [1857].

scopecontent.p: Has a blister from exercising too hard on the bars in the gym; is studying Latin and chemistry; rooms at the college and eats at Capt. John Smith's; have about 100 students; has joined the Phip Society; Charles Martin is head of the college.

did.unittitle: John R. Kilby, Suffolk, to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 22 October 1857.

scopecontent.p: Subscribed to History of Virginia.

did.unittitle:
C al[laway] Campbell,Cohuttah Springs, Murray County, Georgia to
G[randmother][Mildred Walker Campbell], 30 October 1857.

scopecontent.p: Does not know when he will get to Virginia; went to a fair at Cleveland; expects to sell his Toqua farm; advises Uncle Aleck to go west since "the West is filling up rapidly"; Father is teaching at Anderson Seminary, but Charles Campbell "never was calculated for a teacher- he will have to abandon his system of corporal punishment before he can succeed"; has read about the Harper's Ferry riot and it may be the beginning of civil war.

did.unittitle: John R[andolph] Tucker,Richmond to [Charles Campbell, Petersburg], 30 October 1857.

scopecontent.p: Will be unable to deliver a lecture.

did.unittitle: Callaway Campbell, Hampden Sydney to M[ildred] W[alker] Campbell,3 November 1857.

scopecontent.p: Religious revival in progress at the college and has had good preaching from D. Smith, Hoge, and Dabney; has not been studying hard; went hunting.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to Hugh B. Grigsby, [Norfolk], 9 November 1857.

scopecontent.p: Encloses information on Patrick Henry and his opinions of the Alien and Sedition laws. Sends him copies of letters of delegates to Convention of 1788.

did.unittitle: W[illia]m S. Plumer,Alleghany [Allegheny], Pennsylvania to [Charles Campbell, Petersburg], 17 November 1857.

scopecontent.p: Will be happy to deliver a lecture to the Petersburg Library Association in December.

did.unittitle: Hugh B. Grigsby, Norfolk to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 8 December 1857.

scopecontent.p: Is working on a history of the Virginia ratification Convention of 1788, and thanks him for the offer of some manuscripts. Criticizes the writings against him of "R.R.".

did.unittitle: W[illia]m H[olmes]McGuffey to Charles Campbell, 26 December 1857.

scopecontent.p: He is unable to recommend anyone to direct a school which Campbell had proposed.

did.unittitle:
Letters,
1858.
[Anna Campbell] to [Charles Campbell], 1858.

scopecontent.p: Plans for her school.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell's membership certificate of the Maryland Historical Society, 7 January 1858.
A[lexander] S. Campbellto Charles [Campbell], 21 January 1858.

scopecontent.p: Has been building an office, besides working farm. Suggests he give up teaching and exert efforts to get a job from President Buchanan.

did.unittitle: E. A. Dalrymple, Baltimore, [Maryland] to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 10 February 1858.

scopecontent.p: Charles Campbell elected a corresponding member of the Maryland Historical Society.

did.unittitle: Mildred W. Campbell, Marlbourn[e]to Charles [Campbell], 27 February 1858.

scopecontent.p: Sends copy of Martha Washington letter in Mr. Ruffin's book of old letters. Also: copy of Martha Washington Letter.

did.unittitle: Edward Everett, Washington to Charles Campbell, 7 March 1858.

scopecontent.p: Printed regret for not accepting Charles Campbell's invitation to speak.

did.unittitle: W[illia]m G. Palmer,Richmond, [Virginia] to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, [Virginia], 19 March 1858.

scopecontent.p: Asks Charles Campbell to help recruit members for Virginia Historical Society to revive its "now drooping energies".

did.unittitle: Mildred W. Campbell, Marlbourne to Charles [Campbell], 20 March 1858.

scopecontent.p: Deliberate fire set in neighbor's barn. Inquiring if he wants any old magazines she has acquired.

did.unittitle: Benson J. Lossing, New York to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 27 March 1858.

scopecontent.p: Traveling and remarriage has delayed responding to Campbell's letter of 30 January. Is glad to hear of a revised and enlarged History of Virginiaforthcoming, and is confident some of the illustrations in his own Field Book of the Revolutioncould be used in it.

did.unittitle: Benson J. Lossing, Poughkeepsie, New York to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 1 April 1858.

scopecontent.p: Now is not a favorable time to publish a new book, but he thinks the times will be better by September. Harper and Brothers Publishers have some illustrations which might be used in it.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to B[enson] J. Lossing,[Poughkeepsie, New York], 24 April 1858.

scopecontent.p: Sends him some original manuscripts to aid him in his research. Makes suggestions on other things he might examine. Asks that they be returned, as he wishes to give them to the Virginia Historical Society.

did.unittitle: C. Benjamin Richardson. Prospectus of the second volume of the Historical Magazine, and opinions of the press on it, 1 May 1858.

scopecontent.p: Charles Campbell listed as a contributor to the first volume.

did.unittitle: Callaway Campbell, Hampden Sydney to M[ildred] W[alker] Campbell,5 May 1858.

scopecontent.p: Will go to Petersburg June 15, and then to Tennessee; considering UVA for law studies; Charles Campbell a candidate for history professor at William and Mary, wants a new coat for a party.

did.unittitle: Callaway Campbell, Hampden Sydney to M[ildred] W[alker] Campbell,17 May 1858.

scopecontent.p: Received her letter via Mr. McIlvaine; wants new clothes; only two students graduating from the seminary; Charles Campbell did not get William and Mary professorship.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg, [Virginia] to Anna [Campbell],[Shirley], 21 May 1858.

scopecontent.p: Misses Anna Campbell; Charles Campbell's influenza is better.

did.unittitle: George Ripley, New York to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 22 May 1858.

scopecontent.p: Prom office of N. A. Cyclopedia pertaining to Campbell's intent to write articles for the Cyclopedia.

did.unittitle: Anna C[ampbell],Shirley to Charles [Campbell], 30 May 1858.

scopecontent.p: Asks him to come take her home; is reading a life of Aaron Burr.

did.unittitle: Hugh B. Grigsby, Charlotte, Virginia to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, [Before June 1858].

scopecontent.p: Is very glad to hear of the forthcoming new edition of the History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. Carter,Shirley to M[ildred] W. Campbell,Petersburg, 21 June [1858][?].

scopecontent.p: Introduces Mr. Murdaugh, a friend of son Robert, to her. He is traveling to Petersburg with two other Navy officers.

did.unittitle: Hugh B. Grigsby, Norfolk to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 27 June 1858.

scopecontent.p: Regrets that illness prevents him from reading over his manuscript. Suggests he inquire about having it published by a Northern publishing house. He will be in Williamsburg soon; asks to meet him there.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to [Alexander S. Campbell], 28 June 1858.

scopecontent.p: Will leave for his house on July 3rd. Callaway going to Tennessee next month, and will take possession of his estate. Predicts that trans-Atlantic cable will bust.

did.unittitle: W. Winston Fontaine, Fontaine Bleau to Charles Campbell, 28 June 1858.

scopecontent.p: Is collecting Indian relics; asks for Spotswood genealogy and the Macons.

did.unittitle: Callaway Campbell, Cleveland, Tennessee to M[ildred] W[alker] Campbell,12 July 1858.
Judney and Russell, New York publishers to Charles Campbell, Warrenton, 14 July 1858.

scopecontent.p: Received Charles Campbell's of 9th. Are taking Irving's Life of Washingtonin octavo for guide. Would be pleased to do the work, 100 copies will cost $836, not including small type for notes.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. C[arter],Shirley to Mildred [W. Campbell],17 July 1858.

scopecontent.p: Invites her to spend Fall with her. Her husband not well, and will not be at home much. Family news.

did.unittitle: J. K. Tefft, Savannah to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 20 July 1858.

scopecontent.p: Acknowledges receipt of letter and enclosures; apologized for not having written sooner. Is glad to learn of new edition of the History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Warrenton to H[ugh] B. Grigsby,[Charlotte, Court House?], 25 July 1858.

scopecontent.p: Has made arrangements with a New York publisher. Would appreciate his review of his manuscripts, and will send it when done.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Warrenton to J. G. Ghislelin, Jr., [Norfolk], 26 July 1858.

scopecontent.p: Campbell seeking a publisher for 2nd edition of History of Virginia. Ghislelin to be an agent if a publisher secured.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Warrenton to Hugh B. Grigsby, [Charlotte Court House], 26 July 1858.

scopecontent.p: Has received estimates on the cost of publishing the new edition of the History. Intends to have it finished by the Fall but is uncertain as to whether he will find a publisher. Would appreciate his review of his manuscript.

did.unittitle: Hugh B. Grigsby, Charlotte, Virginia to Charles Campbell, [Petersburg], 27 July 1858.

scopecontent.p: Makes suggestions and corrections on the manuscript of the History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Warrenton, Virginia to [?], 2 August 1858.

scopecontent.p: Received letter of the 27th; glad for corrections and suggestions. Would like to see his manuscript. Would like to visit to discuss history. No claim to being a "Virginia historian," only wrote Introduction to the History of the Colony of Virginia. Discussion of Randolph genealogy. Few Virginia families descended from titled or landed gentry.

did.unittitle: Hugh B. Grigsby, Charlotte, Virginia to [Charles Campbell], 12 August 1858.

scopecontent.p: Makes a correction and clarification of something in the History. Is having difficulty with his publisher, but is busy with his work on the Convention of 1788.

did.unittitle: D. Appleton & Co., [publisher], New York to [Charles Campbell], 16 August 1858.

scopecontent.p: Terms of publication of History of Virginia. Not a lucrative offer.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Warrenton to Hugh B. Grigsby, Charlotte Court House, 22 August 1858.

scopecontent.p: Gives information of the Bullett family, in-laws of his brother. Two Northern publishers have declined to publish the second edition of his History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Warrenton to [?], 23 August 1858.

scopecontent.p: Discussion of Mecklenburg Resolutions. May not have power for corrections; two New York publishers have refused a second edition; subscriptions possible, but not desirable. Thanks for copy of The Dead of the Chapel of William and Mary, is valuable and will make reference to it. Questions on Randolph's and Bacon's Castle.

did.unittitle: Hugh B. Grigsby, Charlotte, Virginia to Charles Campbell, [Petersburg], 30 August 1858.

scopecontent.p: Gives information of his arrangements with his publisher. Speaks of various historical figures.

did.unittitle: C[harles] C[ampbell],Petersburg, [Virginia] to Anna [Campbell],6 September 1858.
Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia to Anna [Campbell],10 September 1858.

scopecontent.p: Plans to resign from the Anderson Seminary; local news.

did.unittitle: Anna C[ampbell],Fauquier County, Virginia to "cousin", 13 September 1858.

scopecontent.p: Has been in Fauquier since July; has been teaching; Charles Campbell unemployed; brother William very weak.

did.unittitle: Cal[laway] Campbell,Cleveland, [Tennessee] to Pennsylvania [Charles Campbell], 16 September 1858.

scopecontent.p: Sends a check for $200; expects to visit Virginia in October.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg, [Virginia] to Anna [Campbell],20 September 1858.

scopecontent.p: Will see her soon.

did.unittitle: C[harles] C[ampbell], Petersburg, [Virginia] to Anna [Campbell],20 September 1858.

scopecontent.p: Will meet her in Richmond.

did.unittitle: Mildred W. Campbell, Petersburg to Anna Campbell, Warrenton, 20 September 1858.

scopecontent.p: Encloses $25 as means of her returning to Petersburg.

did.unittitle: Hugh B. Grigsby, Charlotte Court House to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 22 September 1858.

scopecontent.p: Discusses a Nathaniel Bacon, who he thinks was not the rebel. Discusses Patrick Henry and says he was definitely not a demagogue. Gives information on Henry's family.

did.unittitle: Con[way] Robinson,Washington to Ch[arle]s Campbell, [Petersburg], 29 September 1858.

scopecontent.p: Is glad to hear of forth-coming new edition of the History of Virginiabut doubts that it will be a financial success. Advises him to seek advice from Hugh Grigsby on publishing.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, 30 September 1858.

scopecontent.p: A subscription list for a new edition of A History of the Colony and Ancient Dominion of Virginia.

did.unittitle: List of subscribers to Charles Campbell's History of Virginia, 30 September 1858.
Charles Campbell, Petersburg to J. D. Ghiselin, Jr., [Norfolk], 5 October 1858.

scopecontent.p: Subscription business about 2nd edition of History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: P[eter] V. Daniel,Washington to Charles Campbell, 7 October 1858.

scopecontent.p: Although inexperienced, he will be glad to help in gathering subscriptions for his book. Decries Yankee control of the printed media. Compares the Southern Literary Messengerfavorably to the "vapid inanity" of Harper's Magazine.

did.unittitle: W. S. Rohr, Harrisonburg, Virginia to Charles Campbell, [Petersburg], 8 October 1858.

scopecontent.p: Subscribed to History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to [Hugh B. Grigsby], 8 October 1858.

scopecontent.p: The new edition of the History of Virginiawill be sold by subscription; asks if he will help in getting subscribers. Suggests their combining to publish a paper "divested of party politics."

did.unittitle: William J. Bolling, Louisville, Mississippi, to Charles Campbell, 12 October 1858.

scopecontent.p: Another subscriber to list for Campbell's History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: A. Alexander Little, Fredericksburg to Charles Campbell. 13 October 1858.

scopecontent.p:
Subscription business. Discussion of editing the
Intelligencer.

did.unittitle: N. F. Cabell, Warminster, Nelson County to Charles Campbell, 14 October 1858.

scopecontent.p: Since Charles Campbell is issuing a 2nd edition of his History of Virginia. He tells him of possible source materials; Lee Papers in poor condition, and are about 900 pieces.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to [Hugh B. Grigsby], 15 October 1858.

scopecontent.p: Sends a prospectus of the new edition of the History. Speaks of financial arrangements for his work on it.

did.unittitle: Tho[mas] H. Wynne,Richmond to Charles Campbell, [Petersburg], 15 October 1858.

scopecontent.p: Is glad to learn of forthcoming new edition of the History of Virginia. Suggests having it published by a northern publishing house, rather than having it sold only by subscription.

did.unittitle: A. W. Weddell, Hampden Sydney College to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, [Virginia], 16 October 1858.

scopecontent.p: Sends list of subscribers to Charles Campbell's History; asks him to write an article for Hampden Sydney literary magazine.

did.unittitle: D[avid] Keller,Rose Hill, Fayette County, Kentucky to Charles [Campbell], [Petersburg], 17 October 1858.

scopecontent.p: Long time since they have corresponded; asks about Grandfather's service in the Revolution; try to get service claim allowed; is practicing medicine; has six children.

did.unittitle: Wm. Fischer Cocke, Richmond to Charles Campbell, [Petersburg], 18 October 1858.

scopecontent.p: Subscribed to History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: Townsend Ward, Philadelphia to Charles Campbell, 18 October 1858.

scopecontent.p: Sends copy of Contributions to American History1858 for Charles Campbell's perusal.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to Hugh B. Grigsby, 18 October 1858.

scopecontent.p: Asks for brief prospectus of what he is currently working on.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to Hugh B. Grigsby, 18 October 1858.

scopecontent.p: Asks for a brief prospectus of what he is currently working on. Asks his help with regard to the subscription list of the History. Asks his opinion on current historical questions about Patrick Henry and others.

did.unittitle: Inman Homer, Warrenton to Charles Campbell, [Petersburg], 21 October 1858.

scopecontent.p: Subscribed for 2 copies of History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: John Wickham to Mildred [Campbell],21 October 1858.

scopecontent.p: Indirect subscription to History of Virginiavia Campbell's mother.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg, to [William J. Bolling], 23 October 1858.

scopecontent.p: Discussed a marriage of "Seigniora Bolling" to a Mr. Kemp.

did.unittitle: John Esten Cooke, Richmond to Cha[rle]s Campbell, [Petersburg], 23 October 1858.

scopecontent.p: Is happy to have written an article for him. Answers a query about some relatives of his.

did.unittitle: N. F. Cabell, Warminster, Nelson County to C[harles] Campbell, Petersburg, 26 October 1858.

scopecontent.p: Hopes Charles Campbell will get to see the Lee Papers; hopes Charles Campbell will use the Lee Papers to set the record straight.

did.unittitle: R. Montgomery Walker, Boston, [Massachusetts] to Charles Campbell, 30 October 1858.

scopecontent.p: Letter concerns a Washington autograph.

did.unittitle: [N. F. Cabell], Warminster, Nelson County to [Charles Campbell], 2 November 1858.

scopecontent.p: Is sending him copies of Lee Papers.

did.unittitle: Hugh B. Grigsby, Charlotte Court House to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 4 November 1858.

scopecontent.p: Discusses some financial and political matters brought before the House of Burgesses in 1765 and after.

did.unittitle: Geo[rge] Henry Moore,New York to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 6 November 1858.

scopecontent.p: Wants Charles Campbell to help distribute copies of the proceedings of the Virginia Assembly of 1619.

did.unittitle: E[lizabeth] M. Maben,Richmond to Charles [Campbell], 8 November 1858.

scopecontent.p: Happy to hear he is adding to his list of subscribers: she is trying to help.

did.unittitle: George W. Munford, Richmond, [Virginia] to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 13 November 1858.

scopecontent.p: Governor received copies of journal of 1619 Virginia Assembly; lists some of contents of Virginia Archives; asks for latest edition of Charles Campbell's History.

did.unittitle: M. R. Bohannan, Lynchburg to Charles Campbell, 16 November 1858.

scopecontent.p: Added his name to subscribers for Campbell's History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: William J. Bolling, Louisville, to Charles Campbell, 19 November 1858.

scopecontent.p: Arrangement by one of Campbell's literary agents for [ History of Virginia].

did.unittitle: N. F. Cabell, Warminster, Nelson County to Charles Campbell, 22 November 1858.

scopecontent.p: Has sent Charles Campbell copies of the Lee Papers.

did.unittitle: A. W. Weddell, Hampden Sydney College to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 24 November 1858.

scopecontent.p: Asks for manuscripts of article for literary magazine.

did.unittitle: Judney and Russell, New York publishers to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 24 November 1858.

scopecontent.p: Received Charles Campbell's of 22nd. Understood that Mr. Lossing would write Charles Campbell. Would like to do work, take pay from subscriptions, but 600 subscribers will not pay for 1000 copies, $1400 without the engravings. Will cost more if they must use agents, etc.

did.unittitle: William B. Harrison, Brandon to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 24 November 1858.

scopecontent.p: Subscribed for 2 copies of History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: S. Moore Lenfree to Charles Campbell, 25 November 1858.

scopecontent.p: A letter from Campbell's cousin about subscription list for History of Virginia. An account of the health and doings of various relatives.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell] to William B. Harrison, 27 November 1858.

scopecontent.p: Thanked Harrison for his subscription.

did.unittitle: Judney and Russell, New York publishers to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 29 November 1858.

scopecontent.p: Received Charles Campbell's of 27th. Had forgotten Charles Campbell's last letter, and now can say that book will cost no more than first estimate.

did.unittitle: Thurston Enyhih [?], Fort Lee, New Jersey, to Charles Campbell, 5 December 1858.

scopecontent.p: Subscription to History of Virginia, and offer of assistance in discovering data for same.

did.unittitle: Derby and Jackson, publishers, New York to Charles Campbell, 6 December 1858.

scopecontent.p: Received Charles Campbell's of 4th. Charles Campbell doesn't provide enough data for definite publishing costs for History of Virginia. To stenotype 600 pages similar to Randall's Jefferson: $1100 to $1200. Print and bind 1000 copies, $600-800. Would receive mark down [?] for small commission provided pay cash or good security for short time.

did.unittitle: J. B. Lippincott, Philadelphia to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 6 December 1858.

scopecontent.p: Gives him information on the costs of publishing the new edition of the History of Virginia. He does not want to take the full financial risk himself, but will perform the work of printing and binding, etc., if paid in the process.

did.unittitle: Jo[h]n Minge,Cha[rle]s Cityto Cha[rle]s Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 7 December [18]58.

scopecontent.p: Suggestion for correction regarding Harrison descendants in Charles Campbell's History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: Geo[rge] P. Scarburgh,Washington to Charles Campbell, Petersburg., Virginia, 8 December 1858.

scopecontent.p: Thinks he can get a copy of Upshur.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to C. Benj. Richardson, [Boston], 9 December 1858.

scopecontent.p: Encloses circulars for proposed 2nd edition of History of Virginia. If book appears soon, will send some copies. Glad Historical Magazinehas weathered financial troubles. Will send articles. Wants work printed in Boston, and would appreciate help.

did.unittitle: J. Wingate Thornton, Boston to Charles Campbell, 9 December 1858.

scopecontent.p: Has received a copy of Historical Magazinewith notice of Campell's 2nd edition of History of Virginia. Wants information about the Gookin or Gokin family as gathered from original records.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to David A. Claiborne, 10 December 1858.

scopecontent.p: Subscription business, and Campbell explained his motive for History of Virginia, "innate for dress."

did.unittitle: J. G. Ghiselin, Jr., Norfolk to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 13 December 1858.

scopecontent.p: Explanation of a delay in soliciting subscribers. List of subscribers attained to date enclosed on back of letter (18 names).

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell to J. Wingate Thornton, Petersburg, 14 December 1858.

scopecontent.p: Replies to Thornton's request for information on Gookin or Gokin. Campbell knew little and had no contact with sources which would mention the names.

did.unittitle: Bolivar Christian, Staunton to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 15 December 1858.

scopecontent.p: Discussion of Campbell's History of Virginia; names for subscription list of History of the Valley Settlers, particularly the Scotch Irish settlers.

did.unittitle: John Gilmary Shea, New York to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 15 December 1858.

scopecontent.p: C. B. Richardson showed Charles Campbell's circular on his History of Virginia; wonders if it will include Spanish settlement in the Chesapeake area. Has studied this and published it in History of the Catholic Missions Among the Indian Tribes of the U.S., and in School History of the United States. Offers assistance.

did.unittitle: P[eter] V. Daniel, Jr.,Washington to C[harles] Campbell, [Petersburg], 17 December 1858.

scopecontent.p: Requests a duplicate copy of the outline for the History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to Sterling Neblett, James Woodhouse & Co., and H. S. Baldwin, 17 December 1858.

scopecontent.p: Multi-draft of three notes pertaining to subscriptions for History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: D. S. Baldwin, [Richmond] to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 18 December 18[58][?].

scopecontent.p: Pertains to subscription lists for a volume Campbell wanted to publish.

did.unittitle: J. Wingate Thornton, Boston to Charles Campbell, 21 December 1858.

scopecontent.p: Suggests he check State Archives in Richmond for original records; State should have records edited. Edition of Stith's Historyis needed. Importance of verifying History.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to C. Benjamin Richardson, 21 December 1858.

scopecontent.p: Knows publishers find state histories unattractive; tries subscription plan, has 6 or 7 hundred names. Would have been easier if publishing information available. Has promise for publication. Would appreciate aid in superintending printing. Will call when in New York. Having book sterotyped. What would be cost. Wants neat, substantial volume or none.

did.unittitle: W. O. Goode, House of Representatives to Charles Campbell, 22 December 1858.

scopecontent.p: Has subscribed for a copy of History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: John Gilmary Shea, New York to Charles Campbell, 22 December 1858.

scopecontent.p: Lists five sources for information on Spanish settlement. Has never seen Mr. Greenhow's memoirs. Has Charles Campbell see John Gilmary Shea's article on the Susquehanna's in the Historical Magazineof October 1858?

did.unittitle: C. Benjamin Richardson, New York to Charles Campbell, 23 December [1858][?].

scopecontent.p: [Appears to be answer to Charles Campbell's letter of December 21]. Glad making progress with subscriptions. Discount to subscribers. Local histories do not generally pay. Lists costs, 1000 copies should cost about $1200. Offers to share half the expense and profits for superintending the publishing as long as subscription list increases. Can't afford to sustain a loss, due to troubles with his Historical Magazine.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell to J. Wingate Thornton, Petersburg, 24 December 1858.

scopecontent.p: Reply to Thornton's letter of 21st December Pertains to Thornton's search about Gookin family of Virginia.

did.unittitle: D. A. Claiborne, Halifax to Charles Campbell, 25 December 1858.

scopecontent.p: Subscription list business. Claiborne suggested Virginia people too little interested in literary affairs and too much in politics. Literary men the "true benefactors" of "Old Dominion."

did.unittitle: J. Wingate Thornton, Boston to Charles Campbell, 28 December 1858.

scopecontent.p: Suggests London Company records of national importance and should be published. Suggests Charles Campbell and the Virginia Historical Society to urge Congress to do so.

did.unittitle: P[eter] V. Daniel, Jr.,Washington to Charles Campbell, [Petersburg], 29 December 1858.

scopecontent.p: Transmits a list of subscribers he has gathered. Explains reason for his request of duplicate of outline for History.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to P[eter] V. Daniel, Jr.,[Washington], 30 December 1858.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for list of subscribers and for his efforts in obtaining them.

did.unittitle: John Gilmary Shea, New York to [Charles Campbell], 31 December 1858.

scopecontent.p: Sends information on Barcia book; can get more information Montreal where only copy is. Identifies St. Mary's Bay with the Chesapeake, and Axacan as some part of Virginia Notes on events between 1565-1573; Father Segura, Don Luiz.

did.unittitle: Newspaper story on Petersburg Library Association, [Late December 1858].

Letters,
1859.
Anna C[ampbell],Petersburg, Virginia to Charles [Campbell], [c. 1859].
Anna Campbell to Charles [Campbell], [c. 1859].

scopecontent.p: Hopes he will get his book published; thinks he could correct the proofs in New York; was working in the garden; wants to name the baby Fanny; have been two applicants for Anderson Seminary; wants him to find a textbook for her pupils; would like to get his teeth fixed.

did.unittitle: N. F. Cabell, Warminster to C[harles] Campbell, Petersburg, 3 January 1859.

scopecontent.p: Lists copies of Lee Papers he will send to Charles Campbell; asks for account of wars against the Turks.

did.unittitle: B. [B.] Minor,Fredericksburg to Charles Campbell, Richmond, 4 January 1859.

scopecontent.p: Only three subscriptions for Charles Campbell's History of Virginia. Samuel Gordon, Wm. S. Barton, and B. B. Minor. Has lost list of names, requests another so he can make better use of it.

did.unittitle: John Gilmary Shea, New York to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 6 January 1859.

scopecontent.p: Sends notes from Tanner book on St. Mary's R., etc., Societas Jesu Militans, including Spanish quote.

did.unittitle: Frank M. Imboden, Staunton to Charles Campbell, [Petersburg], 8 January 1859.

scopecontent.p: Subscription list arrangements.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to F[rank] M. Imboden,13 January 1859.

scopecontent.p: 600-700 subscribers to impending edition of History of Virginia. Explained his fondness for Virginia history.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to John Gilmary Shea, 13 January 1859.

scopecontent.p: Received John Gilmary Shea's letter containing information on the Spanish discovery of Axacum. Would appreciate any further information.

did.unittitle: L. S. Joynes, Richmond to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 14 January 1859.

scopecontent.p: Sends copies of documents relating to naval battle in Chesapeake Bay during American Revolution; published in Baltimore Sun. Sent copies to Dr. Palmer of Richmond to revise his account of the Virginia Navy. Hopes it may be helpful for Charles Campbell's History of Virginia. Condition of returning manuscript when finished.

did.unittitle: Frank M. Imboden, Staunton to Charles Campbell, 17 January 1859.

scopecontent.p: Subscription list information for History of Virginia. Expressed opinion that Virginians reluctant to support "new enterprises." Yet, "Southern enterprises" must be encouraged first.

did.unittitle: B. M. DeWitt, Richmond to [Charles] Campbell, 21 January 1859.

scopecontent.p: Wants Charles Campbell to send an article by return mail for the Index. Will send a "little something" as compensation.

did.unittitle: Hugh B. Grigsby, Norfolk to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 21 January 1859.

scopecontent.p: Will be happy to review his manuscript. Sympathizes with the difficulties of subscription but says it is the only way to avoid financial loss.

did.unittitle: Benson J. Lossing, Poughkeepsie, New York to Charles Campbell, [Petersburg], 21 January 1859.

scopecontent.p: Offers him some information designed to help him decide on a publisher for the new edition of the History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: John A. Gray, R. S. Green [?]; New York to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 22 January 1859.

scopecontent.p: Apologizes for delay of answer. 1000 of Charles Campbell's book would cost: non-stereotyped, $960.00; stereotyped, $1175.00.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to B. M. DeWitt, 22 January 1859.

scopecontent.p: Preparing 2nd ed. of History of Virginia. Would like to provide a regular column for B. M. DeWitt's paper, the Index, for a fixed fee. Likes the plan of the paper. Gives advice and comments on the press of the day.

did.unittitle: Frank W. Lea, Cleveland, Tennessee to M[ildred] W[alker] Campbell,25 January 1859.

scopecontent.p: Gives Callaway's new address in Georgia where he bought a farm; Callaway has given up courting Lavinia Henley.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to L. S. Joynes, M.D., 26 January 1859.

scopecontent.p: Thanks for account of Virginia Navy. Charles Campbell's Historywill have only summary of Revolution, but won't overlook "battle of the Barges".

did.unittitle: William C. Wickham, Hanover to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 27 January 1859.

scopecontent.p: Subscription business.

did.unittitle: Hugh B. Grigsby, Norfolk to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 2 February 1859.

scopecontent.p: Returns the manuscript of the new edition of the History of Virginiaon which he has made some corrections.

did.unittitle: N[athaniel] F[rancis] Cabell,[Warminster], Nelson County to [Charles Campbell], 3 February 1859.

scopecontent.p: Wants Charles Campbell's help in obtaining autographs for Mr. Randall.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to "Dear Sir", 4 February 1859.

scopecontent.p: Letter concerns the mss. sent for the Express. Disagrees with Irving's interpretation of Virginia history.

did.unittitle: Anna C[ampbell], Petersburg, Virginia to "cousin", 7 February 1859.

scopecontent.p: Is teaching; has another baby and has a "free girl" as a nurse; new baby is named Fanny; Charles Campbell is going to New York.

did.unittitle: N[athaniel] Francis Cabell,Nelson County to Charles Campbell, 7 February 1859.

scopecontent.p: Encloses some Revolutionary Era documents.

did.unittitle: I. P[age] Aylett,Montville to "cousin", 10 February 1859.

scopecontent.p: Extends invitation to visit.

did.unittitle: [Hugh B. Grigsby], Norfolk to [Charles Campbell], [Petersburg], 12 February 1859.

scopecontent.p: Returns his manuscript with corrections, suggestions and queries.

did.unittitle: John Esten Cooke, Richmond to C[harles] Campbell, [Petersburg], 12 February 1859.

scopecontent.p: Cannot suggest any new or original scenes for engravings for the new edition of the History of Virginia. Asks to have proof-sheets of new edition sent him.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to John Esten Cooke, [Richmond], 16 February 1859.

scopecontent.p: The new edition of the History of Virginiahas yet to go to press, but when it does, he will send him some proof-sheets.

did.unittitle: Lyman C. Draper, Madison, Wisconsin to Ch[arle]s Campbell, 22 February 1859.

scopecontent.p: He has been very busy, serving as Superintendent of Public Instruction for the state of Wisconsin. He hadn't expected to be elected, being a Democrat in a heavily Republican state; but now that he has been he has set about instituting reforms. Is glad to hear of a new edition of the History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: Henry Howe, Cincinnati to Cha[rle]s Campbell, Petersburg, 24 February 1859.

scopecontent.p: Has had some difficulty with violations of the law because of the selling of his books without a license, but he does not expect to be prosecuted. Decries the high cost of obtaining licenses, which makes it impossible to sell books in Virginia. Hopes the law will be changed.

did.unittitle: William Palmer, Richmond to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 25 February 1859.

scopecontent.p: Palmer had destroyed manuscript of his History of Virginia. Navy during Revolution, and didn't have time to outline the work for Campbell.

did.unittitle: Callaway Campbell, Cohuttah Springs, Murray County, Georgia to M[ildred] W[alker] Campbell,26 February 1859.

scopecontent.p: Bought 640 acres of land in Georgia and has moved his slaves to it; has not sold the Toqua farm; is learning to farm.

did.unittitle: N[athaniel] F[rancis] Cabell,Nelson County to Cha[rle]s Campbell, Petersburg, 28 February 1859.

scopecontent.p: Encloses a copy of a letter of Col. Arthur Campbell.

did.unittitle: Deposition of Mildred Walker Campbell before a Justice of the Peace, Petersburg, March 1859.

scopecontent.p: Affidavit as to the legal heirs of her Father Alexander Moore.

did.unittitle: Hugh B. Grigsby, Norfolk, [Virginia] to [Charles Campbell], 2 March 1859.

scopecontent.p: Has read his manuscript and corrected the punctuation; lists corrections to the manuscript.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to Hugh B. Grigsby, 4 March 1859.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for reviewing his manuscript. Answers certain question raised about it.

did.unittitle: Hugh B. Grigsby, Norfolk to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 6 March 1859.

scopecontent.p: Suggests corrections to his manuscript.

did.unittitle: Henry Howe, Cincinnati to Ch[arle]s Campbell, Petersburg, 8 March 1859.

scopecontent.p: Advises him against having his new edition of the Historypublished by himself. Advises him to accept an offer form a publisher who will assume all the risks.

did.unittitle: P[hilip] Slaughter,Warrenton to [Charles Campbell], 15 March 1859.

scopecontent.p: Randolph Lee has presented him with a copy of the History of Virginia. He has decided to edit a new edition of Hugh Jones' Present State of Virginiaand asks Campbell's help.

did.unittitle: D. S. Baldwin, [Richmond] to Charles Campbell, 16 March 18[59].

scopecontent.p: Details of agreement between Baldwin, a literary agent and Campbell.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. Carter,Shirley to Mildred [W. Campbell],17 March 1859.

scopecontent.p: Family news; thanks her for goods sent and received. A large party to be held at her house soon.

did.unittitle: Anna C[ampbell],Petersburg, Virginia to Charles [Campbell], 24 March 1859.

scopecontent.p: Brother William died; Charles Campbell in New York.

did.unittitle: Lyman C. Draper, Madison, Wisconsin to Ch[arle]s Campbell, 25 March 1859.

scopecontent.p: Sends him a copy of his school report, part of which will be published by Lippincott. Wisconsin has just established a town library system.

did.unittitle: Hugh B. Grigsby, Norfolk to Townsend Ward, Philadelphia, 28 March 1859.

scopecontent.p: Informs him that Campbell will be in Philadelphia soon, and asks him for assistance in getting the new edition of the History of Virginiapublished.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Philadelphia to "Dear Sir", 31 March 1859.

scopecontent.p: Just concluded contract for his History of Virginiato be published by Lippincott and Co. of Philadelphia; wants this announced in the Express.

did.unittitle: Townsend Ward, [?] to Charles Campbell, 31 March 1859.

scopecontent.p: Would be glad if Charles Campbell could spend an evening with him.

did.unittitle: Anna Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia to Charles [Campbell], 4 April 1859.

scopecontent.p: Glad that he has made the arrangements with Lippincott and Co. in Philadelphia; hopes he will get his "nerves up" for the dental operation; school is going well.

did.unittitle: Anna C[ampbell],Petersburg, Virginia to Charles [Campbell], 5 April 1859.

scopecontent.p: Charles Campbell's book to be published soon.

did.unittitle: Anna Campbell Petersburg, Virginia to "cousin", 7 April 1859.

scopecontent.p: Brother William died; Charles Campbell in New York; had a short piece published.

did.unittitle: C[harles] C[ampbell], Petersburg to Lyman C. Draper, [Madison, Wisconsin], 14 April 1859.

scopecontent.p: Is sorry he has been diverted from his historical research, but feels his work in education to be equally valuable. Lippincott is going to publish a new edition of the History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: Charlotte Wickham Lee, Arlington to Mildred [Campbell?],29 April 1859.

scopecontent.p: Thanks her for gift.

did.unittitle: Hugh B. Grigsby, Norfolk to C[harles] Campbell, 13 May 1859.

scopecontent.p: Has made some notes and corrections in the section on slavery in the History. Suggests omission of the statement that emancipation is desirable and expresses his own negative views of emancipation.

did.unittitle: Cal[laway] Campbell,Cohuttah Springs, Murray County, Georgia to Harrison and Co., 15 May 1859.
D.S. Baldwin, Richmond to Charles Campbell, 24 May 1859.

scopecontent.p: Baldwin requested an advance of Campbell's fee for handling subscription lists.

did.unittitle: Edmund Ruffin, Marlbourne to [Charles Campbell], 15 June 1859.

scopecontent.p: Ruffin proposed a second edition of a book of history. Asked Campbell for advice about publishers and terms of sale.

did.unittitle: Ja[me]s E. Heath,Richmond to Charles Campbell, 17 June 1859.

scopecontent.p: His "fracture" of two years ago still confines him to the "invalid's chair" and he writes with difficulty. Is glad that a new edition of the History of Virginia is coming out.

did.unittitle: E[lizabeth] B[land] Stovin,Airley, Fauquier County, Virginia to Cha[rle]s Campbell, 8 July 1859.

scopecontent.p: Wants to have Richard Bland remembered for his contributions; hopes Charles Campbell will help; hopes St. George Tucker and John Randolph Tucker will write about Theodorick Bland.

did.unittitle: Lavinia M[oore] Alsbrook,New York City to "Aunt" [Mildred W. Campbell], 12 July 1859.

scopecontent.p: Took a trip to New York and Northeast.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. C[arter],Shirley to Mildred [W. Campbell],29 July 1859.

scopecontent.p: She has been on a trip to visit her family. Family news: Landonia is very sick.

did.unittitle: C[harles] C[ampbell], Petersburg, Virginia to Anna [Campbell],[Trenton], 1 August 1859.

scopecontent.p: Is sorting papers, pasting letters in a book; is correcting proofs; his book almost finished.

did.unittitle: Sam[ue]l D. Campbell,Geneva, Coffe, County, Alabama to "cousin", 2 August 1859.

scopecontent.p: Asks about controversy with Sparks; hopes his second edition will go as far as the death of Washington; will vote soon on whether West Florida will be annexed to Alabama.

did.unittitle: C[harles] C[ampbell], Petersburg, Virginia to Anna [Campbell], 8 August 1859.

scopecontent.p: Charles Campbell's mother is taking care of his children; death of Dr. James W. Alexander; is indexing his History of Virginia; local news.

did.unittitle: Anna Campbell, Trenton to Charles [Campbell], 3 August 1859.

scopecontent.p: Children well; misses her dead brother; will not get estates proceeds soon; could order her teeth for $5.

did.unittitle: Hugh B. Grigsby, Charlotte Court House to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 13 August 1859.

scopecontent.p: Acknowledges receipt of proofs of the History of Virginia.Is making slow progress with his own writing.

did.unittitle: Callaway Campbell, Cohuttah Springs, Murray County, Georgia to Grandma [Mildred Walker Campbell], 14 August 1859.

scopecontent.p: Farm going well.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to Hugh B. Grigsby, 16 August 1859.

scopecontent.p: Will forward the rest of the proof sheets when they arrive. Is glad to hear he is working again. Suggests change in the state's licensing law which, he says, puts authors at the mercy of publishers.

did.unittitle: M[ildred] W. Campbell,Fauquier to Charles [Campbell], 16 August 1859.

scopecontent.p: News of his children, who are all healthy Letter received from Anna in Trenton, who will soon return.

did.unittitle: C[harles] C[ampbell], Petersburg, [Virginia] to Anna [Campbell],20 August 1859.
Mildred W. Campbell to Charles [Campbell], 22 August 1859.

scopecontent.p: News of his children, who are all well. Wheat crop is good.

did.unittitle: C[harles] C[ampbell], Petersburg, Virginia to Anna [Campbell],2 September 1859.

scopecontent.p: Family news; was elected Principal of Anderson Seminary; asks her advice whether to accept; difficulties with Board of Trustees.

did.unittitle: Anna Campbell, Riverdale to Charles [Campbell], 4 September 1859.

scopecontent.p: Fanny has whooping cough; her sore mouth better.

did.unittitle: Anna Campbell, Riverdale to Charles [Campbell], 6 September 1859.

scopecontent.p: Charles Campbell has been elected Principal; wants to ask Mother to live with them.

did.unittitle: Tho[ma]s H. Wynne,Richmond to Charles Campbell, [Petersburg], 11 September 1859.

scopecontent.p: Will make every effort to find his and his mother's missing baggage. Will soon tell him of his trip to New York. Hopes the new edition of the Historywill be a success.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. C[arter],Shirley to [Mildred W. Campbell], 22 September 1859.

scopecontent.p: Hopes she will come to visit, and bring Alexander Campbell's two sons with her. Transmits news of a friend in Iowa, dying of consumption. Glad to hear that Charles Campbell has joined the church.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. Carter,Shirley to M[ildred] W. Campbell,Petersburg, 17 November 1859.

scopecontent.p: Sends her sheets and towels to him for her. Also sends a lounge and some chairs to be repaired.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. C[arter]to [Mildred W. Campbell], [Late November (after-l9) 1859].

scopecontent.p: Thanks her for doing work for her; encloses $5.

did.unittitle: Mary F[airfax] Keller,[Alabama] to Sister [Mildred Campbell], 6 December 1859.

scopecontent.p: Taking care of many children; Mr. Bagby has not yet succeeded with the claim; family news.

did.unittitle: T[homas] H. Wynne,Richmond to Charles Campbell, [Petersburg], 21 December 1859.

scopecontent.p: Sends two books for him to look at leisure.

did.unittitle: James Woodhouse and Co., Richmond to Charles Campbell, 19 December 1859.

scopecontent.p: Saw notice that Charles Campbell's History of Virginiaalmost ready. In the fire of October 1 in their building, they lost the list of subscribers, but will insert notice when book is ready. Requests 50 copies.

did.unittitle: James Woodhouse and Co., Richmond to Charles Campbell, 23 December 1859.

scopecontent.p: Received letter from Lippincotts that they will provide copies of History of Virginia. Charles Campbell need not send any copies.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to James Woodhouse, 23 December 1859.

scopecontent.p: Address order for History of Virginiato Lippincott and Co., the publishers, who have the subscription list. Told them that James Woodhouse would be good for sale of 100 copies.

did.unittitle:
Letters,
1860.
Nanny K. S. Campbell to Charly [Charles Campbell], [c. 1860].

scopecontent.p: Saw Barnum's museum.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell] to Cally [Callaway Campbell], [c. 1860].

scopecontent.p: Sent him the new edition of History of Virginia; is living at Anderson Seminary; Anna debilitated by nursing Fanny, who should be weaned.

did.unittitle: Thom. H. Wynne to [?], 1860[?].

scopecontent.p: A listing of persons to whom Wynne sold copies of History of Virginia[The price of History of Virginiaindicated a reference to second edition of that work, which was published in 1860].

did.unittitle: T[homas] H. Wynne,Richmond to [Charles Campbell, Petersburg], 5 January 1860.

scopecontent.p: There will be a delay in the receipt of a box of books from Philadelphia, from Lippincott.

did.unittitle: J. D. Ghiselin, Jr., Norfolk to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 11 January 1860.

scopecontent.p: Ghiselin dissatisfied with terms of sale of History of Virginiaset by Lippincott and Co. 25% discount vs. 33% discount.

did.unittitle: James Woodhouse and Co., Richmond to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 11 January 1869.

scopecontent.p: Received two boxes addressed to Charles Campbell. Assume are copies of History of Virginiasent by Lippincotts. Should they be opened and books removed? Paid charges of $8.25. Agree price should be $3.00, but $2.50 for subscribers.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to James Woodhouse and Co., 13 January 1860.

scopecontent.p: Two boxes by James Woodhouse contain 169 copies of History of Virginia; give them to Mr. Baldwin or Mr. Wynne. Lippincotts has shipped boxes with James Woodhouse's copies, if haven't come, take out what need and replace when they arrive. Price is to be $3.00, $2.50 to subscribers.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to D. S. Baldwin, 13 January 1860.

scopecontent.p: Mr. Woodhouse has received copies of History of Virginia. Will attend to the delivery. Bills already made out. Price is $2.50 to subscribers. Mr. Teller may deduct his 5%, D. S. Baldwin his 20%.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to J. D. Ghiselin, Jr., [Norfolk], 14 January 1860.

scopecontent.p: Discussed terms of compensation, which Ghiselin, a literary agent, was to receive. History of Virginianot written for profit, but to serve "our time honored Virginia."

did.unittitle: T[homas] H. Wynne,Richmond to Charles Campbell, [Petersburg], 18 January 1860.

scopecontent.p: Lippincott has sent him two boxes of the new edition of the History of Virginia, destined for subscribers. Thinks Campbell may have to issue another edition to pay expenses of this one.

did.unittitle: James Woodhouse and Co., Richmond to Charles Campbell, 21 January 1860.

scopecontent.p: Saw that Lippincotts was selling History of Virginiaat $2.50. This settled the matter. Wished Charles Campbell had arranged to sell it at $3.00, but is too late now. The list of subscribers Charles Campbell sent is not half what they had obtained.

did.unittitle: T[homas] H. Wynne,Richmond to Cha[rle]s Campbell, [Petersburg], 21 January 1860.

scopecontent.p: Acknowledges receipt of personal copy of History of Virginia. Is about to embark on sale of it to his subscribers.

did.unittitle: Hugh B. Grigsby, Norfolk to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 24 January 1860.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for new copy of the History of Virginia. Promises a very favorable review of it in the Richmond Enquirer.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to Wyndham Robertson, 25 January 1860.

scopecontent.p: The letter questions the wisdom of a Virginia tax on books produced and sold in Virginia. Campbell felt the tax stifled the circulation of books, particularly locally produced books on Virginia topics.

did.unittitle: T[homas] H. Wynne,Richmond to C[harles] Campbell, [Petersburg], 26 January 1860.

scopecontent.p: Will try to boost sales of History. Reminds him to come to Richmond on Friday.

did.unittitle: Sarah Jane Johnson, Petersburg, Virginia to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 27 January 1860.

scopecontent.p: Student writes to teacher; enjoys school.

did.unittitle: T[homas] H. Wynne,Richmond to Charles Campbell, [Petersburg], 30 January 1860.

scopecontent.p: Sends a copy of today's Index, which contains a review of the History. Thanks him for mentioning his name in the History.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to John Esten Cooke, [Richmond], 2 February 1860.

scopecontent.p: Forwards him a copy of the History of Virginia, and thanks him for his favorable review of it in the Index.

did.unittitle: T. W. Imboden, Staunton to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 4 February 1860.

scopecontent.p: Subscription agent requested payment authorization for his labors.

did.unittitle: Callaway Campbell, Cohuttah Springs, Murray County, Georgia to "Grandma" [Mildred Walker Campbell], 5 February 1860.

scopecontent.p: Is going to build a house; will not try to court [Lavinia Henley] again; has not sold his Toqua farm.

did.unittitle: Charles Deane, Boston to Cha[rle]s Campbell, 11 February 1860.

scopecontent.p: Have seen Charles Campbell's new ed. of his History of Virginia; has procured it for his Historical Society. Sends copy of Wingfield's Narrative, which Deane has recently had printed. Deane owns most of the works of Smith and others to which he refers.

did.unittitle: Hill Carter, Shirley to Charles Campbell, 11 February 1860.

scopecontent.p: Carter sent payment for 10 copies of Campbell's History of Virginia, plus mentioned four other purchases of the book.
