did.unittitle: Hugh B. Grigsby, Norfolk to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 15 February 1860.

scopecontent.p: Has sent his review of the Historyto the Richmond Enquirer. Note in Charles Campbell's hand: "Answered Feb'y. 17th."

did.unittitle: T[homas] H. Wynne,Richmond to C[harles] Campbell, [Petersburg], 15 February 1860.

scopecontent.p: His agent is now selling the new edition of the History, but is having some difficulty.

did.unittitle: Mary B. C[arter],Shirley to Anna [B.] Campbell,17 February 1860.

scopecontent.p: Confusion over debts owed to Charles Campbell. Hopes his Historywill succeed.

did.unittitle: John R. Kelby, Suffolk to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 21 February 1860.

scopecontent.p: Had already purchased History of Virginiain bookstore.

did.unittitle: Wm. B. Harrison to Charles Campbell, 22 February 1860.

scopecontent.p: Sent payment for 2 copies of History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: Hugh B. Grigsby, Norfolk to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 22 February 1860.

scopecontent.p: His review of the Historyhas appeared, with some unfortunate typographical errors.

did.unittitle: T[homas] H. Wynne,Richmond to C[harles] Campbell, [Petersburg], 24 February 1860.

scopecontent.p: Sends a copy of a paper entitled The Treason of [Charles] Lee,asking him to read and evaluate it. Will send money from sales of the Historynext week.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to Hugh B. Grigsby, 25 February 1860.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for the favorable review of the History of Virginiain the Richmond Enquirer.

did.unittitle: Callaway Campbell, Cohuttah Springs, Murray County, Georgia to "Grandma" [Mildred Walker Campbell], 26 February 1860.

scopecontent.p: Does not want to return to Virginia "my boyhood I look upon as a horrid dream"; likes Georgia; will not resume the courtship, "I am no longer held spellbound."

did.unittitle: B. [B.] Minor,Fredericksburg to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 26 February 1860.

scopecontent.p: Pleased Charles Campbell included biographies of figures in History of Virginia. Might have given some help, gives examples; refers to Robert "King Carter, William Gooch, Thomas Fairfax, William Fairfax, Peter Leheup, John Carter." Sends information for Charles Campbell to use in next edition; B. B. Minor only wishes to defend Robert Carter's reputation. Corruption and confusion in every community. Also mention Gov. Benedict Leonard Calvert, Rev. Fontaine.

did.unittitle: Robert Murray, Suffolk to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 29 February 1860.

scopecontent.p: Subscription business and a request that Campbell transact a business matter for Murray.

did.unittitle: W[illiam] J. Harris,Nottoway to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 4 March 1860.

scopecontent.p: Sent purchase price for a copy of History of Virginia. Had been delayed in Richmond at Opposition Convention.

did.unittitle: William[?] Brodman to Charles Campbell, 5 March 1860.

scopecontent.p: Business arrangements about History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: P. C. Sinding, Philadelphia to Charles Campbell, [Petersburg], 6 March 1860.

scopecontent.p: Offered to act on Campbell's behalf as intermediary with Lippincott publishers.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to John Minor, 7 March 1860.

scopecontent.p: Acknowledges a complimentary letter received from Minor about Campbell's recent book [ 2nd ed. of History of Virginia]. Campbell offers his opinion on scholarly technique (unfavorable) and classical historians (favorable).

did.unittitle: T[homas] H. W[ynne],Richmond to Cha[rle]s Campbell, [Petersburg], 7 March 1860.

scopecontent.p: Asks for Campbell's understanding of the contract between himself and Mr. Baldwin on selling his books.

did.unittitle: L. Bremiss [?], John Rowlyn Newohand [?], Sam Osgood, Geo[rge] Folson,Geo[rge] Henry Moore,New York to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 9 March 1860.

scopecontent.p: Invites Charles Campbell to a Washington Irving birthday celebration.

did.unittitle: A. A. Gocke [?], Evergreen to [Charles Campbell], 10 March 1860.

scopecontent.p: Acknowledged receipt of a copy of History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: E. Ruffin, Jr., Beechwood to [Charles Campbell], [Petersburg], 19 March 1860.

scopecontent.p: Sent price of seven copies of History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: T[homas] H. Wynne,Richmond to C[harles] Campbell, [Petersburg], 20 March 1860.

scopecontent.p: Encloses receipt for money paid Mr. Baldwin for selling his books. He still has seven copies of the book.

did.unittitle: W[illiam] O. Newson,Camp 4th Alabama Vol[unteers]to Charles [Campbell], 7 April [c. 1860].

scopecontent.p: Asks him to keep some blankets.

did.unittitle: P. C. Sinding, Philadelphia to Charles Campbell, [Petersburg], 9 April 1860.

scopecontent.p: An exceedingly flattering letter about History of Virginia. Sinding talked to Lippincott & Co., about Campbell's book. Proposed a sale of History of Virginiain Copenhagen, Denmark.

did.unittitle: George Bancroft, New York to [Charles Campbell?], 23 April 1860.

scopecontent.p: Discussion of Smith's "True Relation."

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. C[arter],Shirley to [Mildred W. Campbell], 9 May 1860.

scopecontent.p: Asks her to make a "grass shirt." Has had three visitors from the North, observing plantation life in Virginia. They all had mistaken ideas to be corrected.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. Carter,Shirley to Mildred W. Campbell, Petersburg, 28 June 1860.

scopecontent.p: Hopes she will come and stay with her. She is going up to Richmond today. Family news.

did.unittitle: Lucy A. Moody, Petersburg to [Charles Campbell][?], 20 July 1860.

scopecontent.p: Is grateful for the chance to go to school on Poor Children's Scholarship.

did.unittitle: [Cal]laway Campbell,Cohuttah Springs, Murray County, Georgia to Grandma [Mildred Walker Campbell], 9 August 1860.

scopecontent.p: Sends $85 to settle with Harrison & Co.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. C[arter],Shirley to Mildred [W. Campbell],17 August 1860.

scopecontent.p: Is worried about her not coming: is she sick? Perhaps her coming to Shirley would do her good. Religious sentiments.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. Carter,Shirley to Mildred [W. Campbell],24 August 1860.

scopecontent.p: Sends her: some pears and apples. Describes her canning.

did.unittitle: Callaway Campbell, Cohuttah Springs, Murray County, Georgia to Father Charles Campbell, 1 September 1860.

scopecontent.p: Settled all his bills at Hampden Sydney; received a copy of the History of Virginia; Callaway arrested 4 forgers who then escaped from jail.

did.unittitle: A[nn] E[velin] Henley,Montvale Springs to Sister [Mildred Campbell], 9 September 1860.

scopecontent.p: Is taking the waters at Montvale Springs; family news.

did.unittitle: John Ward Dean, Boston, [Massachusetts] to Charles Campbell, 3 October 1860.

scopecontent.p: Charles Campbell elected a corresponding member of the New England Historic Genealogical Society.

did.unittitle: Amasa May [of J. B. Lippincott & Co.], Philadelphia to Charles Campbell, 24 October 1860.

scopecontent.p: Discusses difficulties encountered in bringing out second edition of Campbell's History of Virginia.

did.unittitle: Callaway Campbell, Cohuttah Springs, Murray County, Georgia to Grandma [Mildred Walker Campbell], November 1860.

scopecontent.p: Aunt Evalina Henley died; news of Henley family; has not built a house; Georgia politicians want to secede, but his county is Unionist; "Lincoln will I hope and believe make a good President"; "I look upon all Disunionists and seceders as traitors and demagogues"; "about half our politicians in the South ought to be hung forth with."

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. Carter,Shirley to Mildred [W. Campbell],6 November 1860.

scopecontent.p: Her daughter, Anne, is quite sick; asks her to postpone her visit. Other family news.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. C[arter],Shirley to Mildred [W. Campbell],27 December 1860.

scopecontent.p: Relates story of friend's daughter losing $10. Her son Robert and his family visited there on Christmas.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell to [Mildred W. Campbell][?], [1861-1865].

scopecontent.p: News of sister Betty and cousin, Mr. Aylett. Some houses destroyed by shelling; one shell falls on her property.

did.unittitle:
Letters,
1861.
Callaway Campbell, Cohuttah Springs, Murray County, Georgia to M[ildred] W[alker] Campbell,14 January 1861.
Lavinia [Henley] Cannon,Chota, [Tennessee] to Aunt [Mildred Campbell][?], 18 February 1861.

scopecontent.p: Mail irregular now; asks for picture of Aunt; mother has died; Sister Mary married Mr. Parker; family news.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. Carter,Shirley to Mildred [W. Campbell],18 February 1861.

scopecontent.p: Was sorry to miss her while she was in Petersburg. Hopes her daughter Annie will "come out on the Lord's side" before her death. Asks her opinion on the current political situation.

did.unittitle: [Callaway Campbell], Cohuttah Springs, Murray County, Georgia to Grandma [Mildred Walker Campbell], 17 March 1861.

scopecontent.p: Bad weather; has not yet built his house, but will build it soon.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. C[arter],Shirley to Mildred [W. Campbell],28 March 1861.

scopecontent.p: Family news. She is very much in favor of secession and hopes Virginia will follow the Carolina's example.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg, Virginia to John Ward Dean, Boston, Massachusetts, 17 April 1861.

scopecontent.p: Thanks the Society for his election to New England Historic and Genealogical Society.

did.unittitle: Callaway Campbell, Cohuttah Springs, Murray County, Georgia to M[ildred] W[alker] Campbell,6 May 1861.

scopecontent.p: His part of Georgia not very excited about political questions, but further south "the war spirit seems rampant"; Callaway against the Fire-Eaters' blames the war on "bad men of both sections"; has section of Georgia against secession, but Lincoln's "base and blind course" has destroyed hope for reconciliation and Callaway will back the South.

did.unittitle: H. S. Campbell, Warrenton, [Virginia] to Charles [Campbell], 29 June 1861.
Cal[laway] Campbell,Cohuttah Springs, Murray County, Georgia to Grandma [Mildred Walker Campbell], 31 June 1861.

scopecontent.p: South is united against "rascally Lincolnites"; Andrew Johnson, a "Corrupt old demagogue", has fled to Washington; idea that South could lose the war is "simply ridiculous"; Callaway has completely lost his unionist sentiments and is thinking about joining the army; rumored that Confederate Army advancing on Washington.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. C[arter],Shirley to Mildred W. Campbell, Petersburg, 3 July 1861.

scopecontent.p: Social news of Mrs. Kay and Mrs. Basset, Acquaintances. Family news.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell], Petersburg to Thomas H. Wynne, 31 July 1861.

scopecontent.p: Rejoices over Confederate victory at First Bull Run and the dismay it has caused in the North. Thinks that England and France will soon aid the South, realizing that the South is fighting for free trade.

did.unittitle: [Mary B. Carter], Shirley to Mildred [W. Campbell],23 September 1861.

scopecontent.p: Was in Petersburg on Friday and is sorry to have missed her. Family news. She has knit 20 pairs of socks for the soldiers and wants to knit 50.

did.unittitle: Callaway Campbell, Cohuttah Springs, Murray County, Georgia to Grandma [Mildred Walker Campbell], 26 September 1861.

scopecontent.p: Given up idea of volunteering for army; has built a house; Georgians united, but East Tennessee divided; expects war to last several years; blockade is causing suffering.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. C[arter],Shirley to Mildred [W. Campbell],19 October 1861.

scopecontent.p: Family news: explains why "the children" have not come to see her. Glad to hear she is going to stay with her son Alexander Campbell, but will miss her.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. C[arter],Shirley to [Mildred W.] Campbell,8 November 1861.

scopecontent.p: Her daughter Annie's child has died. It is a great grief to all.

did.unittitle: E[lizabeth] M. M[aben],Richmond to [Mildred W Campbell], 31 December [1861-1865].

scopecontent.p: News of Campbell Maben's Christmas with his fellow soldiers. She has been to President's reception. Jennie gave birth to a girl.

did.unittitle:
Letters,
1862.
Cal[laway] Campbell,Cohuttah Springs, Murray County, Georgia to Grandma [Mildred Walker Campbell], 14 February 1862.

scopecontent.p: Mr. Callaway doing pork packing for the government; wants to help his father financially once the farm is established; Mary McGhee's husband at Manassas; is following the war news and the South "never will be conquered."

did.unittitle: Enlistment papers for Henry Albert, 23 March [c. 1862].
Anna C[ampbell]to Charles [Campbell], 9 May 1862 [1864?].

scopecontent.p:
Hopes he will come back safely; hopes the militia will not have to fight.
Encloses a letter from Mary Campbell to "Pa". Yankees have been repulsed.

did.unittitle: Enlistment papers for James H. McCall in Confederate Army, 15 May 1862.
Magie A. S. Underwood, Almance City, North Carolina to William G. Biley, 31 May 1862.

scopecontent.p: Has seen his mother; wants Bill to kill all the Yankees and come home; "It is the hardest time that I ever seen"; "Grass is green, the rose is red, oh Bill, remember me when I am dead."

did.unittitle: Sam[ue]l D. Campbell,Geneva, Coffee County, Alabama to "Cousin", 10 June 1862.

scopecontent.p: Worried about the war; Geneva is very safe; daughter Cassandra is "deranged"; daughter Mary is at the Female College; has published four letters on Washington.

did.unittitle: Arthur H. Keller, Army of the Mississippi, Tupelo, Mississippi to "Aunt", 2 July 1862.

scopecontent.p: Army is moving quickly; anxious about battle at Richmond; is quartermaster of the 27th regiment, Alabama volunteers.

did.unittitle: A. Alexander Little, Richmond to Charles Campbell, 16 August [18]62.

scopecontent.p: Loss of negroes in Caroline County prompts inquiry as to how many were lost during the Revolution and the War of 1812. Interested in how long did the recovery of Virginia agriculture take.

did.unittitle: Hugh B. Grigsby, Charlotte Court House to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 25 August 1862.

scopecontent.p: Inquires into information about Pocahontas. Hopes for a decisive battle soon which will drive the Union forces out of Virginia. Fears success of Lincoln's plan to separate Virginia from rest of Confederacy.

did.unittitle: Callaway Campbell, Cohuttah Springs', Murray County, Georgia to M[ildred] W[alker] Campbell,1 November 1862.

scopecontent.p: Land prices in Georgia up; depressed by war news but South is "certain to conquer in the end"; Kentucky is "overwhelmingly for the South since Lincoln Emancipation Proclamation"; soldiers going to Chattanooga; crops good, but salt scarce; takes good care of his negroes but is strict with them.

did.unittitle: Mildred to "Grandma", 17 November 1862.

scopecontent.p: Fixed her bonnet; food scarce and expensive.

did.unittitle:
Letters,
1863.
Callaway [Campbell],Cohuttah Springs, Murray County, Georgia to Grandma [Mildred Walker Campbell], January 1863.

scopecontent.p: Big battle in Tennessee where North lost, "three men to our one"; local belief that the Yankees will overrun the area; rivers too low for the Federal gunboats; Missouri overrun by Federal troops and Dr. Pleasant Lea murdered by them; Dr. Lea's wife was a Yankee "of the real John Brown Oberlin School" and left him to go north before war broke out and "some think that she has had a hand in his death."

did.unittitle: H. S. C[ampbell]to "Ma", 18 January 1863.

scopecontent.p: Encamped near Bowling Green in winter quarters; his first battle was at Fredericksburg; describes battle "the whole air seem literally filled with missiles of death"; believes "all parties are now sick of this insane war."

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. Carter,Shirley to Mildred [W. Campbell],10 March 1863.

scopecontent.p: Social news of Mrs. Gary, an acquaintance. Tells her of her garden.

did.unittitle: Callaway C[ampbell],Cohuttah Springs, Murray County, Georgia to "Grandma" [Mildred Walker Campbell], 8 April 1863.

scopecontent.p: Mail is irregular; sends $100 to his father; is almost out of debt; has 23 negroes; hopes to help Father in the future; crop news; state is supporting many soldiers' families; South is in bad shape, but has no alternative but to carry on the war, and same for the North; war a stalemate, border states divides on the war; outcome of war uncertain.

did.unittitle: Lewis V. Hewit [?], Columbia, South Carolina to Cha[rle]s Campbell, 23 June 1863.

scopecontent.p: Decided to stay in Columbia; MTS. Campbell's bridge stock is a total loss; Columbia in bad shape and most people living with difficulty.

did.unittitle: Callaway Campbell, Cohuttah Springs, Murray County, Georgia to "Grandma" [Mildred Walker Campbell], 1 August 1863.

scopecontent.p: Crop news; happy to live out in the country; General Bragg's army at Chattanooga and very demoralized; news of Lee's retrograde movement, discouraging, gloomy prospects.

did.unittitle: Bessie Gwathmey, Hayfield to Mildred [W. Campbell],8 August 1863.

scopecontent.p: Aunt Bettie is feeling better; asks if she saw General Lee.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. Carter,Shirley to Mildred W. Campbell, Petersburg, 11 September 1863.

scopecontent.p: She has been quite ill; her family has also been ill but is largely recovered now. Speaks of large-scale crop failure at Shirley. Speaks of a dead relative as being "beyond the reach of the Yankees now."

did.unittitle: [Anna Campbell] to "Mother", 21 October 1863.

scopecontent.p: Has been unwell with neuralgia; Charles Campbell teaching Latin; flour selling at $75 a barrel.

did.unittitle: M[ary] B. C[arter],Shirley to Mildred W. Campbell, Petersburg, 26 November 1863.

scopecontent.p: Family news: daughter Landonia very sick. Asks God to help the army.

did.unittitle: Mary F. Keller, Tuscumbia, [Alabama] to James [Keller],14 December 1863.

scopecontent.p: Asks him to write; Yankees have taken her provisions and negroes have been lost; corn very-scarce; pork-scarce; "But we are not yet subjugated"; Col. Forrest has been staying at her house; Will Newsom was at Chickamaugua and with Longstreet; hopes for a speedy end to war.

did.unittitle:
Letters,
1864.
Anna C[ampbell]to Charles [Campbell], [1864?].

scopecontent.p: Charles Campbell getting used to camp life and has a tent; Charles Campbell should not encourage Nanny to visit the camp.

did.unittitle: Anna C[ampbell]to Charles [Campbell], [1864].

scopecontent.p: Charles Campbell serving as a guard.

did.unittitle: [?], New Orleans to M[ildred] Campbell,19 January 1864.
C[harles] Henley,Newton, Alabama to Mary [Sophia Campbell],29 February 1864.

scopecontent.p: Remembers the happy days in Geneva. Note from Cassandra M. Campbell enclosing the letter.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia to "Ma", 3 March 1864.

scopecontent.p: Should buy seeds; Yankees within 6 miles of Richmond.

did.unittitle: Mildred W. Campbell, Richmond to Charles [Campbell], 15 March 1864.

scopecontent.p: Unable to obtain books requested. Aleck's salary has doubled. David Keller is in the army which hopes to go to Kentucky next Spring.

did.unittitle: Nanny Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia to "Pa" [Charles Campbell], 9 May 1864.

scopecontent.p: Heard the cannons; heard he bore the march very well; went to the hospital.

did.unittitle: Anna C[ampbell]to Charles [Campbell], 13 May 1864.

scopecontent.p: Thinks Charles Campbell is an "excellent soldier"; is planting a garden.

did.unittitle: Anna C[ampbell]to Charles [Campbell], 14 May 1864.

scopecontent.p: Has no more tea; sent him a coat.

did.unittitle: Anna C[ampbell]to Charles Campbell, 19 May [1864].

scopecontent.p: Lost his check.

did.unittitle: Anna Campbell to Charles [Campbell], 19 May 1864.

scopecontent.p: Cousin Mary died; death of Julian Ruffin; is planting a garden.

did.unittitle: Mary, Charley and Nanny [Campbell], Petersburg, Virginia to "Pa", Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 23 May 1864.

scopecontent.p: Has been attending school; would like to visit.

did.unittitle: Cassandra M. Campbell, Geneva, Alabama to Charles Campbell, 31 May 1864.

scopecontent.p: Her father dead; few educated people in Geneva; feels safe from the yankees; many deserters in the area; has seen Charles Campbell's cousin, Charles T. Henley, who is a soldier.

did.unittitle: C[harles] C[ampbell], Petersburg, Virginia to "Ma", 1 October 1864.

scopecontent.p: Confederate hospital being moved; opened the Seminary; fuel prices high.

did.unittitle: Anna C[ampbell]to "Mother", 2 October 1864.

scopecontent.p: Fighting very close; would like to teach.

did.unittitle: Anna C[ampbell],New York to Charles [Campbell], 20 May [c. 1865-1870].

scopecontent.p: Was seasick on her trip.

did.unittitle: Martha D. Logan, Fincastle to "Cousin", 30 May 1865.

scopecontent.p: Death of her son Nat B. Logan.

did.unittitle: [Anna Campbell], Parkside, Riverdale to Charles [Campbell], 31 July 1865.

scopecontent.p: Will go to Trenton; proceeds from brother's estate mostly worthless; hopes he will get his teeth fixed.

did.unittitle: Anna Campbell, Pemberwicke to Charles [Campbell], 12 August 1865.

scopecontent.p: Has been taking homeopathic medicine; wants the children to go to school; make money by renting rooms, raising fruit; will come hope soon; asks about Anderson Seminary.

did.unittitle: Anna C[ampbell],Pemberwicke to Charles [Campbell], 17 August 1865.

scopecontent.p: Worried about the children being sick; tells Charles Campbell to give them Cholagogue and Rose's pills; will bring home 2-300 strawberry plants; letters to Richmond are now going directly.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell] to Cally [Callaway Campbell], Fall 1865.

scopecontent.p: Glad Cally will visit Virginia. Charles Campbell felt the South would win; living at Anderson Seminary.

did.unittitle: Callaway Campbell, Cohuttah Springs, Murray County, Georgia to Grandmother [Mildred Walker Campbell], 10 September 1865.

scopecontent.p: Has no post office yet; was worried about her relatives during the war; never joined the army; Northern Georgia devastated; wishes his negroes would leave now that they are free; Thomas H. Callaway is President of E. Tennessee and Georgia Railroad; Henley lands confiscated; Mary McGhee widowed; Arthur Henley bushwacked.

did.unittitle: Helen R. Mason, New York to [F. G.] Morrison,3 October 1865.

scopecontent.p: Glad that her sister married him.

did.unittitle:
Callaway Campbell, Cohuttah Springs, Murray County, Georgia to
Mary and Nanny [Campbell],28 October 1865.

Letters,
1866.
Charles Campbell to Dr. Thomas P. Atkinson, Petersburg, 25 January 1866.

scopecontent.p: Has received Atkinson's 4th article on history of Petersburg. Also genealogical material (Chapman Lee, B. Watkins, Hill Carter).

did.unittitle: E[lizabeth] M. M[aben],Richmond to [Mildred W. Campbell], 3 February [1866?].

scopecontent.p: Mr. Maben unwell. Received her knitting. News of her children.

did.unittitle: Cal[laway] Campbell,Cohuttah Springs, Murray County, Georgia to Grandmother [Mildred Walker Campbell], 16 June 1866.

scopecontent.p: Still no post office; lost his livestock in the war; still in debt; negroes all gone, he did not want them to stay because "they never paid in labor" and wanted to "keep clear of the freedman's bureau"; Henley boys not allowed in E. Tennessee because they were guerillas; has had his picture taken.

did.unittitle: Mary F[airfax] Keller,Tuscumbia, [Alabama] to Sister [Mildred Campbell], 9 July 1866[?].

scopecontent.p: Glad that the war is over; all the negroes gone except one woman; news of her children.

did.unittitle: A[lexander] S. C[ampbell]to [Mildred W. Campbell], 11 August 1866.

scopecontent.p: Sorry to hear doubts about re-election of Charles. After devastation of war, living for them is difficult. Family news; Molly's condition is still delicate.

did.unittitle: W. J. Dunlop, Rock Hill, South Carolina to [Charles] Campbell, 27 August 1866.

scopecontent.p: Thanks to Charles Campbell for taking care of his wife; has lost most of his estate as the result of the war; laments the last of the Confederacy; talk of going west for better opportunity; Mrs. Dunlop presently teaching in the Female Academy.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell] to [?], 6 September 1866.

scopecontent.p: Campbell's view of calamity of the war. Seeks advice about his to publish his war-time diary. Opinions of books of travels.

did.unittitle: [Rev.] William S. Plumer,Pottsville, Pennsylvania to [Charles Campbell], 17 September 1866.

scopecontent.p: Received Charles Campbell's letter of August 13. Charles Campbell has asked for advice on publishers-suggests that of Dr. Dabney's Life of Stonewall Jackson. Stereotyping very expensive. Sympathizes with loss of Charles Campbell's child.

did.unittitle: Hugh B. Grigsby, Charlotte Court House to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 21 September 1866.

scopecontent.p: Is discouraged over the political situation, fearing that "the most perfect civilization the world has ever seen has been lost." Suggests he continue his History of Virginiafrom the Revolution to the present, or at least publish his diaries of the war. Fears that the war has destroyed the literary market, at least in the South.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia to Messrs. Blelock and Co., [a publisher] of New York, 29 September 1866.

scopecontent.p: Campbell asks the publisher if he is interested in a diary Campbell kept during Civil War. Possible serial publication, for the diary is very extensive.

did.unittitle: Blelock and Co., Collyer, of New York to Charles Campbell, 9 October 1866.

scopecontent.p: Campbell had solicited this publisher's opinion on a diary. This letter is expression of interest by publisher.

did.unittitle: A[lexander] S. Campbellto Charles [Campbell], 29 October 1866.

scopecontent.p: Upon return from the army, he found his farm much damaged. Is managing to live comfortably; convinced worst is over. Advises him to seek new position in book industry, through aid of a friend, William Alexander of New York.

did.unittitle: [Charles] Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia to [?], New York, 30 October 18[6]6.

scopecontent.p: Letter pertains to Campbell's efforts to get information about a manuscript which he submitted to Harpers. Manuscript recommended to Harpers by Rev. Dr. James W. Alexander.

did.unittitle: A[nna] C[ampbell],Park Side, Riverdale to Charles [Campbell], 13 November 1866.

scopecontent.p: Visited Rahway and New York; got new clothes; looking for the meteor shower.

did.unittitle:
Letters,
1867.
Information on the Burk Family, [c. 1867].
Nanny Campbell, Trenton, New Jersey to "Pa" [Charles Campbell], [c. 1867].

scopecontent.p: Is keeping a diary; went to the dentist and had teeth pulled. Anna C[ampbell]to Charles [Campbell]. Went to the dentist; house-keeping instructions.

did.unittitle: [Charles Campbell] to [?], [1867].

scopecontent.p: Examines the question of the "Negro"; argues that Negroes are innately inferior, and that once freed of constraints, will inevitably regress to "indolence and barbarism" in their native state. Presents the argument that black slaves brought to America because white laborers couldn't withstand sun in the South. [Grouped with letters of Buckner H. Payne to Campbell of July 29, 1867; August 10, 1867; August 22, 1867. Payne an author of Ariel, a pamphlet on the Negro, for which he had solicited Campbell's opinion. This draft may be part of the reply.].

did.unittitle: R[obert] L[ewis] Dabneyto Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 28 January 1867.

scopecontent.p: Inquires into efforts by colonial House of Burgesses to exclude the slave trade. Asks for reference in Hening to Revolutionary charge that the King had endeavored to arm slaves against the colonists.

did.unittitle: Hugh B. Grigsby, Charlotte C[ourt] H[ouse]to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 9 April 1867.

scopecontent.p: Inquires into the history of the early settlement of Newport News.

did.unittitle: E[lizabeth] M. Maben,Richmond to Charles [Campbell], 1 June 1867.

scopecontent.p: Mildred [last name?] expects to marry June 6. Invites him and Anna to wedding. Mr. Maben's health very poor.

did.unittitle: Hugh B. Grigsby, Charlotte C[ourt] H[ouse]to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 24 June 1867.

scopecontent.p: Gives him a quote from George Mason on the slave trade. Compliments him on his recent article on Pocahontas. Speaks of other books he has seen.

did.unittitle: Anna Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia to "Mother", 11 July 1867.

scopecontent.p: Charles Campbell sick; servant left; garden ripening.

did.unittitle: R. Barnett, Vicksburg, Mississippi to Cha[rle]s Campbell, Petersburg, Virginia, 12 July 1867.

scopecontent.p: Information on James B. Burk.

did.unittitle: Tho[ma]s H. Wynne,Richmond to Charles Campbell, [Petersburg], 13 July 1867.

scopecontent.p: Next Tuesday he is meeting the president of the Maryland Historical Society for a tour of Yorktown and the vicinity. Asks him to join them.

did.unittitle: Buckner H. Payne, Nashville to Charles Campbell, Petersburg, 29 July 1867.

scopecontent.p: Sent Campbell a pamphlet on "The Negro", which was to be widely distributed, north and south. Asked for Campbell's opinion of the work.

did.unittitle: J[unia] [A.] Burk,Baton Rouge to [Charles Campbell], August 1867.

scopecontent.p: Information on Burk family.

did.unittitle: Junia A. Burk, Baton Rouge, to [Charles] Campbell, 2 August 1867.

scopecontent.p: Information on John D. Burk.

did.unittitle: Charles Deane, Cambridge to Charles Campbell, 2 August 1867.

scopecontent.p: Deane, who is printing Captain John Smith's last will and testament, asks for particulars of a book by Washington W. Smyth, cited in Charles Campbell's History of Virginia. Cites an error in Charles Campbell's volume. Added note in Charles Campbell's hand gives citation for his date. Deane will print other early papers. Added note on Smyth's book.

did.unittitle: B[uckner] W. Payne,Nashville to Campbell, 10 August 1867.

scopecontent.p: A discussion of Payne's Ariel, a pamphlet examining negroes. Different opinions upon it and a discussion of anti-slavery attitudes. Mentions Henry Ward Beecher, Mandell Phillips, Charles Sumner, Horace Greeley.

did.unittitle: B[uckner] H. Payne,Nashville to Campbell, 22 August 1867.

scopecontent.p: Examination of the negroe question in light of Biblical history, and also science (Prof. Aggassiz).

did.unittitle: Charles Deane, Cambridge to Charles Campbell, 23 August 1867.

scopecontent.p: Thanks for letter and enclosure of the 8th. Extended comparisons of the various accounts of Captain John Smith's rescue from the Indians and Pocahontas' part in that rescue, including primary and secondary accounts. Deane concludes that Smith exaggerated and embellished the story over time. Asks whether "corn" refers to shelled Indian corn.

did.unittitle: Sally Braxton Slaughter [?], Hazel Hill to Charles [Campbell], 27 August 1867.

scopecontent.p: Offers him a place to live.

did.unittitle: Anna [Campbell],Trenton, New Jersey to Charles [Campbell], 28 August 1867.

scopecontent.p: Had good trip; wishes he and Charlie could join them.

did.unittitle: Dennis Jones, Baton Rouge, Louisiana to [Charles] Campbell, 30 August [c. 1867].

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for his interest in J. D. Burk; Louisiana offers little future for him; Lt. Governor is a former slave; expects that "a gentleman and a Southerner will soon be debarred from all rights whatsoever," asks Charles Campbell to help get him a job in Petersburg.

did.unittitle: [Mary Campbell] to "Father" [Charles Campbell], Petersburg, Virginia, 1 September [c. 1867].

scopecontent.p: Has seen several Quakers. Also: Anna [Campbell] to Charles [Campbell]. Does not feel well; has given the children medicine; going to a china factory; has received all the money due for 1867.

did.unittitle: Anna C[ampbell],Lawrenceville, New Jersey to Charles [Campbell], 10 September 1867.

scopecontent.p: Expects to go to Port Chester; sends catsup recipe. Mary [Campbell]to Charles Campbell. Is making him slippers in size six.

did.unittitle: W[illia]m W[irt] Henry,Charlotte Co[urt] Ho[use],Virginia to Charles Campbell, 11 September 1867.

scopecontent.p: Asks for Charles Campbell's article on Patrick Henry.

did.unittitle: C[harles] C[ampbell], Petersburg, Virginia to Anna [Campbell],13 September 1867.

scopecontent.p: Went to Chelsea; fired the cook.

did.unittitle: Charles Campbell, Petersburg to W[illia]m W[irt] Henry,14 September 1867.

scopecontent.p: Sends him an article published in Richmond Dispatch. Is happy to learn he possesses documents which will "vindicate" his grandfather, Patrick Henry.

did.unittitle: Anna C[ampbell],Port Chester, [New York] to Charles [Campbell], 17 September 1867.

scopecontent.p: Went to Rye Beach; will visit New York; hopes he will consider carefully before resigning his present position; hopes they will move north.

did.unittitle: Charles Deane, Cambridge, Massachusetts to [Charles Campbell, Petersburg], 17 September 1867.
[Charles Campbell], Petersburg, Virginia to Geo[rge] H. Moore, 20 September 1867.
